event_description:
Join us as we celebrate the vibrant, dreamlike worlds of this Korean-Canadian artist, whose work invites quiet reflection and a deep connection to life’s dynamic flow.  

Ellee SY Lee is a Korean-Canadian artist whose semi-abstract landscape paintings explore a range of visual and emotional experiences. Immigrating to Canada as a teenager, she quickly discovered a love for art-making, with painting becoming a powerful and liberating way to connect with her subconscious and emotions.
event_name: Exhibition "In the Rhythm of Being" by Ellee SY Lee
short_description: Join us as we celebrate the vibrant, dreamlike worlds of this Korean-Canadian artist, whose work invites quiet reflectio
short_name: Exhibition "In the Rhythm of Being" by Ellee SY Lee

event_description:
This is a solo exhibition by Ukrainian-Canadian artist Olga Polstvin.

Olga is a multidisciplinary artist, cultural leader, and Master of Arts Leadership candidate at Queen’s University whose practice bridges painting, storytelling, and community engagement. Born in Kyiv, Ukraine, she carries forward the resilience and cultural memory of her heritage, weaving themes of belonging, healing, and identity into her work.
event_name: Through the Lens of Ukrainian Belonging

event_description:
Step into the glow, we're back for the sixth year! 

This year, guests can explore the magic like never before with a brand-new layout that lets you move freely between the immersive light show and Pumpkinville at your own pace. Wander through the illuminated maze of over 1.5 million LED and RGB lights, then pop into a vibrant fall fair featuring all new glowing photo ops, installations, midway rides, carnival games, and over 15,000 pumpkins. With new scenes, dazzling photo moments, and an entirely transformed setup, this is not just a walk, it's an adventure!

event_description:
Prepare to be mesmerized by the electrifying talent of violinist Nikki Chooi!

Renowned for his exceptional skill and passionate performances, enjoy this musical journey that showcases the power and beauty of the violin. 

With a program filled with masterworks from Ondřej Kukal, Pablo de Sarasate, Johann Sebastian Bach and Samuel Coleridge Taylor. Chooi’s commanding presence and flawless technique promise to deliver an unforgettable evening. Don’t miss this chance to witness one of today’s most dynamic and celebrated violinists in action. It's a concert you won't want to miss!
event_name: A Virtuosic Afternoon with Nikki Chooi
short_description:
Prepare to be mesmerized by the electrifying talent of violinist Nikki Chooi!

short_name: A Virtuosic Afternoon with Nikki Chooi

event_description:
Forget awkward dating apps and overpriced dinners, this show is the ultimate antidote to the dating blues. We're back with the ultimate interactive experience.

This fully improvised romantic comedy takes the quirks, crushes, and turn-ons of real audience members and spins them into a one-of-a-kind love story. You’ll hook up, break up, live the single life, and fall in love all over again without ever leaving your seat.

Directed by Paul Bates (The Second City, Dan For Mayor), this show boasts an all-star lineup of Toronto’s funniest comedians, including Christy Bruce (Schitt’s Creek), Alastair Forbes (Join Canada, Eh!), Natalie Metcalfe (The Second City), Aurora Browne (Baroness Von Sketch Show), Jan Caruana (Because News), Sharjil Rasool (Run the Burbs), and Kris Siddiqi (The Boys). With technical wizardry by Seann Murray, this show is a comedic rollercoaster you won’t want to miss.
short_description: Forget awkward dating apps and overpriced dinners, this show is the ultimate antidote to the dating blues. We're back wi

event_description:
Returning for its eleventh annual season, featuring more than 30 Canadian and international artists.

Under the new leadership of Festival Director Lily Sutherland and Artistic Director Robert Binet, the festival showcases three mixed Signature Programmes: AFROFUSION, HOMEGROWN, and KATHAK and BALLET. 

Festival highlights include performances from The Royal Ballet, Kathak sensations Tanveer Alam and Barkha Patel, and a world premiere from Artist-in-Residence Esie Mensah, among other local and international dance artists. 

New this year, Up Next at OCAD University spotlights groundbreaking artists in an audience directed experience, including timed entry and freedom to move throughout the space. Intimate Pairings offers the exhilaration of a front row seat in an easily enjoyable setting.

event_description:
Unlock the secrets to making these delightful French pastries. 

In this class you will learn how to prepare choux pastry and identify the key steps in perfecting your mixture, the technique used to perfectly pipe profiteroles, éclairs, and a demonstration of the Paris Brest. You will be shown the ideal baking technique to ensure your choux has the best texture, how to prepare the perfect pastry cream, how to fill your choux pastry, and the secret to preparing a glossy chocolate ganache.
event_name: Eclairs, Choux Pastry and Cream Puff Masterclass

Discover Hyunsun Park's captivating collection of gouache paintings that evoke empathy and connection. Each painting is a window into personal and shared experiences-- stories of survival, resilience, and the search for meaning.

Join the Artists for the opening reception on Saturday, August 9, 2 to 4 p.m. Light refreshments provided.

cost_notes: Soulpepper Theatre offers a Free 25 & Under program. See website for details.
event_description:
The past never really stays in the past.  

A group of old classmates self-declared the “Multi-Ethnic Reject Group” reunites to pre-game their twentieth high school reunion, but nostalgia quickly turns into something darker. 

As drinks flow and old wounds resurface, they confront the choices that shaped them, the friendships that endured or crumbled, and the presence of something, or someone they can’t escape. 

Sharp, theatrical, and deeply moving, this is a reckoning for elder millennials, caught between who they were, who they’ve become, and the world they never saw coming. When the night ends, will they still recognize themselves?

Back for the sixth year! 

Enjoy can’t-miss comedy with over 20 comics from across Toronto and beyond. Shows include Andrew Phung and Friends, Not Hamilton Improvised, Nkasi Ogbonnah’s Afronaut, and more. 

New this year, enjoy "Our Cities On Our Stages", Bad Dog Theatre’s groundbreaking symposium on inclusion and diversity. This full day of activities will dovetail into an improv presentation.

event_description:
Come to a joyful evening celebration filled with live music, aerial show, face painting, a craft table and, last but not least, hot chocolate and apple cider!

Enjoy The Enchanted Forest, performed by Hercinia Arts Collective – a magical story that features three birds and two forest spirits, brought to life through aerial arts, stilt dancing, physical theatre, with room for little ones to learn how to juggle.

We’re also thrilled to present a Roda de Samba with renowned musician Carlos Cardozo and his ensemble: Ian Felix, Matheus Coelho, André Valério, and Baiano. Get ready to move to the rhythm and enjoy the colourful energy of Brazil!

Say no more, come see for yourself and celebrate fall.

Enjoy a merry mix of classic sketches from our celebrated archives, hilarious new material, and the uproarious improv antics that have made us legendary. It’s a perfect way to add laughter and joy to your holiday season!

A hilarious immersive Broadway-style show that blends your favourite holiday movie tropes with high-octane pop showtunes. 

Directed by Tim Drucker of Friends Parody Musical, Trixie and Katya LIVE and choreographed by Brooke Engen of Hairspray, Beetlejuice, Rock of Ages, with additional creatives to be announced.

event_description:
Since 1975, we have been Canada’s favourite holiday tradition, spotlighting the creativity and talent of makers from across the country. This year, we proudly celebrate our 50th anniversary, honouring 
five decades of Canadian craft while looking ahead to an exciting new era.

More than just a marketplace, this is a cultural movement where creativity comes to life. Visitors can shop from over 700 artisans and makers, discover one-of-a-kind treasures and support Canadian small businesses, all while experiencing the festive magic of the season.

This year enjoy a brand-new vintage section, full of nostalgic finds, a European-style Christmas Market with festive gifts, décor, food and drink, an expanded Flavours section for food lovers and special Northwest Territories Pop-Up.
event_name: One Of a Kind Christmas Show | 50th Anniversary
short_description: Since 1975, we have been Canada’s favourite holiday tradition, spotlighting the creativity and talent of makers from acr
short_name: One Of a Kind Christmas Show | 50th Anniversary

event_description:
Step into the world of teas with a guided connoisseur-led tasting of classic, herbal, and signature tea blends. 

Enjoy chef-inspired food pairings, bite size snacks and delicacies while sipping the teas. Learn the art of making a chai latte with spices like cinnamon, cardamom, ginger, clove and pepper. Create 3 seasonal special lattes and make yourself a holiday tea cocktail.

Connect with a community of tea lovers over flavor, culture and wellness.
event_name: Holiday Tea Tasting Experience and Seasonal Chai Latte Masterclass

event_description:
Mozart’s effervescent overture to The Marriage of Figaro provides a delightful introduction to cellist Jaemin Han, who delivers dazzling virtuosity in Tchaikovsky’s Rococo Variations, in a sparkling tribute to 18th-century elegance. 

Carlos Simon’s Fate Now Conquers, inspired by Beethoven’s reflections on destiny, sets the stage for the composer’s Fifth Symphony, featuring the most iconic first four notes in classical music.
short_description: Mozart’s effervescent overture to The Marriage of Figaro provides a delightful introduction to cellist Jaemin Han, who d

event_description: Step into the past and discover what school was like in Upper Canada in the early 1800s! Back then, only a few children could go to class and one-room schoolhouses were the center of learning. Who got to go and when did schools finally become free for everyone? Come find out as you explore the skills kids once learned; reading, writing, and practical lessons for everyday life. Try your hand at printing letters in a sand tray, then progress to writing on a slate just like real students did long ago. A fun, hands-on adventure for kids, teens, and families!
event_name: Class From the Past: Holiday Workshops at Fort York
short_description: Step into the past and discover what school was like in Upper Canada in the early 1800s! Back then, only a few children
short_name: Class From the Past: Holiday Workshops at Fort York

event_description:
You are invited into the beating heart of contemporary craft and design, a space where tradition meets bold reinvention, and where the maker’s hand is ever-present. 

Through the exceptional work of our current Artists-in-Residence, this exhibition explores the enduring relevance of skilled making in a world dominated by speed, automation and disposability. 

We are a cornerstone of Canada’s craft landscape, a rare incubator where artists have the time, space and support to experiment, collaborate and grow their professional careers. From glass, metal and ceramics to textiles and contemporary design, the residents featured here are not only shaping objects – they are shaping culture.  

In this context, to “meet your maker” is to engage with the processes, politics and poetics of craft and design today. It’s a chance to stand face to face with emerging visionaries who transform raw mate

In this context, to “meet your maker” is to engage with the processes, politics and poetics of craft and design today. It’s a chance to stand face to face with emerging visionaries who transform raw mate
short_description: You are invited into the beating heart of contemporary craft and design, a space where tradition meets bold reinvention,

event_description:
A quiet lake in Ontario is making a lot of noise.

Sediments from the bottom of a small lake in Ontario are revealing a remarkable record of our impact on the planet.

Just outside Toronto, Ontario lies Crawford Lake, a significant site offering a unique, comprehensive 1,000-year record of human impacts - local, regional, and global.

event_description:
This is a contemporary form of environmental art created by artists who are  concerned about reducing waste, recycling, and making the world a better place, while raising awareness about environmental changes.

 It aims to showcases the beauty and creativity of using recycled, environmentally friendly or sustainable materials to create phenomenal artwork, using water-based paints, natural pigments and recycled materials to name a few elements. lt is art that advocates for the planet, catering to all ages and present in various mediums, including paintings, sculptures or fashion.

Presenting our second annual art exhibition, we will be utilizing selected artists to mentor African and Caribbean communities on the positioning of multicultural history and art within the Canadian cultural landscape.

The Southern Netherlands, better known today as Flanders, was home to revolutionary artists. 

These extraordinary painters found new ways to depict reality, portray humanity, and tell stories that created parallels to their world then and to our world today. This large-scale exhibition, featuring over 80 stunning art works and objects, medieval, renaissance, baroque paintings, sculptures and more, offering a doorway to art between 1400 to 1700. 

The exhibition's unique presentation introduces the visitor, through these rare, extraordinary artworks, to stories of enterprising townspeople, prosperous cities, and an ever-developing society.
event_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Masterworks

Our experienced chandler will teach you the basics of candle making, including the benefits of using soy wax, and the step-by-step process to create beautiful custom candles.

Select your scent from a variety of delightful, premium fragrances and essential oils to personalize your candles. 

All materials provided, including snacks and refreshments.

This workshop is great for beginners and candle enthusiasts alike. Come on your own or with friends. No experience needed. Guests must be ages 12 and up to participate.

event_description: Take a break in Old City Hall’s open-air courtyard — a hidden oasis in the heart of downtown. Bring your lunch, meet up with friends or simply enjoy the peaceful surroundings and heritage architecture. While you're here, look up to spot the clock tower's four gargoyles — part of the original 1899 design and removed in 1938 and reinstalled in 2002 using modern materials.

event_description:
Since 1975, we have been Canada’s favourite holiday tradition, spotlighting the creativity and talent of makers from across the country. This year, we proudly celebrate our 50th anniversary, honouring 
five decades of Canadian craft while looking ahead to an exciting new era.

More than just a marketplace, this is a cultural movement where creativity comes to life. Visitors can shop from over 700 artisans and makers, discover one-of-a-kind treasures and support Canadian small businesses, all while experiencing the festive magic of the season.

This year enjoy a brand-new vintage section, full of nostalgic finds, a European-style Christmas Market with festive gifts, décor, food and drink, an expanded Flavours section for food lovers and special Northwest Territories Pop-Up.
event_name: One Of a Kind Christmas Show | 50th Anniversary

Mozart’s effervescent overture to The Marriage of Figaro provides a delightful introduction to cellist Jaemin Han, who delivers dazzling virtuosity in Tchaikovsky’s Rococo Variations, in a sparkling tribute to 18th-century elegance. 

Carlos Simon’s Fate Now Conquers, inspired by Beethoven’s reflections on destiny, sets the stage for the composer’s Fifth Symphony, featuring the most iconic first four notes in classical music.

event_description:
Borders divide, the cosmos unites.

Canadian legend Robert Lepage returns to Canadian Stage after sold-out productions of 887 and Needles and Opium.

Set against the Cold War's fierce U.S.-Soviet rivalry, this gripping story explores the personal and political turmoil of an era defined by global tension with a uniquely Canadian perspective. Through the tale of two Quebec City brothers, Lepage's stunning use of multimedia and visual storytelling draws the audience into a world on the brink of change and portrays the impact of global conflict on the individual.
event_name: The Far Side of the Moon

short_name: The Far Side of the Moon

event_description:
Join us as we celebrate the vibrant, dreamlike worlds of this Korean-Canadian artist, whose work invites quiet reflection and a deep connection to life’s dynamic flow.  

Ellee SY Lee is a Korean-Canadian artist whose semi-abstract landscape paintings explore a range of visual and emotional experiences. Immigrating to Canada as a teenager, she quickly discovered a love for art-making, with painting becoming a powerful and liberating way to connect with her subconscious and emotions.
event_name: Exhibition "In the Rhythm of Being" by Ellee SY Lee
short_description: Join us as we celebrate the vibrant, dreamlike worlds of this Korean-Canadian artist, whose work invites quiet reflectio
short_name: Exhibition "In the Rhythm of Being" by Ellee SY Lee

event_description:
With infectious curiosity and a gift for revealing the deeper meaning within great works, Rob Kapilow has captivated audiences for decades. 

Enjoy his rendition of Dvořák’s Piano Quintet in A major, Op. 81, one of the most beloved works in the chamber music repertoire. He is joined by The Gryphon Trio to bring this rich, folk-infused masterpiece to life as Rob unpacks its melodies, structure, and emotional depth.

Whether you’re hearing this piece for the first time or the hundredth, you’ll come away with a newfound appreciation.
event_name: What Makes It Great® with Rob Kapilow and Gryphon Trio
short_description: With infectious curiosity and a gift for revealing the deeper meaning within great works, Rob Kapilow has captivated aud
short_name: What Makes It Great® with Rob Kapilow and Gryphon Trio

event_description: The diverse communities of all ages and all levels are invited at the Prairie Drive Park Community Garden Site​. It will be a gathering for socialization. After meet and greet, attendees will be escorted to Warden Woods Ravine to enjoy natural beauty, colorful sceneries of Fall and breath in fresh air to relax your mind and body. Attendees will be educated on how to take care of Ravine from damage and destruction. They will also be given briefing on the preservation and conservation of the landscape from construction and development.
event_name: Prairie Drive Park Resident Led Group

short_name: Prairie Drive Park Resident Led Group

event_description:
Join Jane Finch Centre's Artists-in-Residence, Taejah Daniel (Coach Milly), Vanna Nguyen and Rod Osei-Nuako (Reezy) for an outdoor art installation at Corner Commons. This Artist-in-Residence is held within Invitations to Better Worlds project and is a collaboration with the Department of Imaginary Affairs and Jane/Finch Centre. Through their residencies, the artists have brought to life their interpretations of a collective vision for better worlds for Jane and Finch. This project is an emergence of community engagement, storytelling, collective liberation, foresight and art. It is a practice in believing better worlds are possible.

A City of Toronto Cultural Hotspot Signature Project.
event_name: Invitations to Better Worlds: Artist Showcase + Meet & Greet

short_name: Invitations to Better Worlds: Artist Showcase + Meet & Greet

event_description:
The Southern Netherlands, better known today as Flanders, was home to revolutionary artists. 

These extraordinary painters found new ways to depict reality, portray humanity, and tell stories that created parallels to their world then and to our world today. This large-scale exhibition, featuring over 80 stunning art works and objects, medieval, renaissance, baroque paintings, sculptures and more, offering a doorway to art between 1400 to 1700. 

The exhibition's unique presentation introduces the visitor, through these rare, extraordinary artworks, to stories of enterprising townspeople, prosperous cities, and an ever-developing society.
event_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Masterworks

event_description:
Discover the captivating sounds of this standout talent in Ontario's vibrant music scene, during an intimate evening of soulful melodies and original songs. 

Matt is renowned for his expertise on the Hammond organ but is equally proficient on the piano, guitar, bass and mandolin. His voice, enriched by countless hours studying legends like Ray Charles and Steve Winwood, brings a deep and resonant quality to his performances that is both powerful and emotive.

Matt's music blends elements of vintage rock, alternative, roots, and a dash of soul/blues, creating a unique and compelling sound.

Our market aims to promote Ontario, Family Farms, area businesses, farm-fresh, local, produce and a range of products that reflect Scarborough’s rich diversity.

event_description:
We often picture Bach as a wise master, but in his late teens, he was as fiery as he was gifted. Determined to hear the great organist Dietrich Buxtehude, he set off on foot from Arnstadt to Lübeck, a staggering 400 km journey!

Hosted by CBC’s Tom Allen, the evening features harpist Lori Gemmel, pianist Jamie Parker, accordionist Michael Bridge, violinist Annalee Patipatanakoon, and the genre-expanding soprano Patricia O’Callaghan in a thrilling, wide-ranging performance.

One of three presentations in our new MUSE series (Music Unveiled, Stories, Explorations), Allens’ captivating production blends music and storytelling to bring this chapter of young Bach’s story to vivid life.

Enjoy a program of music by Johann Sebastian Bach, Dietrich Buxtehude, Sofia Gubaidulina, Sergei Rachmaninoff, Charles Gounod, and Tom Waits.
event_name: Tom Allen and Friends "J.S. Bach’s Long Walk in the Snow"
short_description: We often picture Bach as a wise master, but in his late teens, he was as fiery as he was gifted. Determined to hear the
short_name: Tom Allen and Friends "J.S. Bach’s Long Walk in the Snow"

event_description:
Experience the Small Business Forum 2025: Small Business, Big World - the City of Toronto’s free premier full-day event dedicated to celebrating and supporting small businesses. This year's Small Business Forum 2025 will offer: 
- main stage programming with keynote speakers and expert panels,
- speed mentorship workshops where business experts share their wisdom and answer your burning questions,
- a trade show hosting a diverse display of small business services and goods providers, and
- opportunities to network, build valuable connections, and expand your reach both within Toronto and internationally.

A more in-depth agenda and program guide is in development and will be shared at www.toronto.ca/BusinessForum

event_description:
Enjoy an evening of musical exploration, featuring new works by living composers from Canada and around the world. This unique, once-in-a-lifetime concert presents four commissioned pieces by some of today’s most compelling and emotionally resonant composers. 

Join us for the world premieres of new works by Andrew Balfour and Norbert Palej. Attend North American premiere of "Will Sing Life Again" by Ukrainian composer Bohdana Frolyaka, with the poignant setting of texts by acclaimed journalist Viktoria Amelina. The program concludes with "Scar Tissue", a major work created by Music TORONTO’s longtime composer-in-residence, Jeffrey Ryan, in collaboration with Giller Prize-winning author and poet Michael Redhill.
short_description: Enjoy an evening of musical exploration, featuring new works by living composers from Canada and around the world. This

event_description:
Borders divide, the cosmos unites.

Canadian legend Robert Lepage returns to Canadian Stage after sold-out productions of 887 and Needles and Opium.

Set against the Cold War's fierce U.S.-Soviet rivalry, this gripping story explores the personal and political turmoil of an era defined by global tension with a uniquely Canadian perspective. Through the tale of two Quebec City brothers, Lepage's stunning use of multimedia and visual storytelling draws the audience into a world on the brink of change and portrays the impact of global conflict on the individual.
event_name: The Far Side of the Moon

event_description:
Making its North American premiere, the globally celebrated masterpiece reveals the true story of Ip Man, the prestigious grandmaster of the martial art Wing Chun. The story recounts his influence on the martial art from its more than 300-year-old origins in Southern China, to global popularity, and his famous student Bruce Lee.

It features two gripping, inter-woven tales about the relentless pursuit of dreams while incorporating a pulse-pounding blend of acrobatic dance, precision martial arts and cinematic staging with dramatic lighting and breathtaking visuals. 

For audience members ages eight and up.

event_description:
Two internationally acclaimed  experiences, SÉANCE and FLIGHT, are coming. 

Staged inside purpose-built 40-foot shipping containers, these genre-defying works use complete darkness, 360° binaural audio, and precisely timed physical and environmental effects to create psychologically charged alternate realities.

The Toronto season brings two of the company’s most toured experiences to Canada for the first time. With over 700,000 attendees worldwide and appearances of their work at Venice Film Festival, Tribeca, SXSW, and Edinburgh Fringe, Toronto is now invited also to step inside the dark.

event_description:
We are pleased to bring you the fifth annual Greek International Film Festival Tour of Canada (GIFFT).

This is a Canadian national film festival that will take place in 11 Canadian cities simultaneously. Those cities include: Toronto, Vancouver, Edmonton, Calgary, Regina, Winnipeg, London (Ontario), Hamilton/Niagara, Ottawa, and Halifax.

GIFFT is a showcase and celebration of Greek cinema and filmmakers of Greek Heritage. This festival will provide exciting platform for directors, writers, producers, and actors of Greek Heritage to showcase their exceptional art across Canada.

We are pleased to bring you the fifth annual Greek International Film Festival Tour of Canada (GIFFT).

event_description:
Since 1975, we have been Canada’s favourite holiday tradition, spotlighting the creativity and talent of makers from across the country. This year, we proudly celebrate our 50th anniversary, honouring 
five decades of Canadian craft while looking ahead to an exciting new era.

More than just a marketplace, this is a cultural movement where creativity comes to life. Visitors can shop from over 700 artisans and makers, discover one-of-a-kind treasures and support Canadian small businesses, all while experiencing the festive magic of the season.

This year enjoy a brand-new vintage section, full of nostalgic finds, a European-style Christmas Market with festive gifts, décor, food and drink, an expanded Flavours section for food lovers and special Northwest Territories Pop-Up.

Step into the world of teas with a guided connoisseur-led tasting of classic, herbal, and signature tea blends. 

Enjoy chef-inspired food pairings, bite size snacks and delicacies while sipping the teas. Learn the art of making a chai latte with spices like cinnamon, cardamom, ginger, clove and pepper. Create 3 seasonal special lattes and make yourself a holiday tea cocktail.

Connect with a community of tea lovers over flavor, culture and wellness.

event_description:
A site-specific mural by Winnipeg-based artist Anna Binta Diallo, exploring themes of time, memory and interdependence through the metaphor of fossils. Using silhouettes of human forms assembled from found images, Diallo creates a visual narrative on the interconnectedness of the past, present and future. 

Originally exhibited at the Musée d’art contemporain de Montréal, it invites viewers to reflect on how contemporary actions and objects will serve as relics for future generations, emphasizing the importance and responsibility of shaping collective heritage.
short_description: A site-specific mural by Winnipeg-based artist Anna Binta Diallo, exploring themes of time, memory and interdependence t

event_description:
Colin Linden’s tale is the stuff of legends. Featuring in soundtracks like "O Brother Where Art Thou?" and "Inside Llewyn Davis", his music journey began when he was 11-year-olds meeting his music idol Howlin’ Wolf at a matinee show in his native Toronto.

“I’m an old man now, and I won’t be around much longer,” Wolf told him. “It’s up to you to carry it on.”

Linden still carries that frayed photograph in his wallet, along with a Sears 5/8” socket wrench in his pocket to play slide guitar. He has taken Wolf’s plea seriously, performing since he was 12 years old.
short_description: Colin Linden’s tale is the stuff of legends. Featuring in soundtracks like "O Brother Where Art Thou?" and "Inside Llewy

event_description: Step into the past and discover what school was like in Upper Canada in the early 1800s! Back then, only a few children could go to class and one-room schoolhouses were the center of learning. Who got to go and when did schools finally become free for everyone? Come find out as you explore the skills kids once learned; reading, writing, and practical lessons for everyday life. Try your hand at printing letters in a sand tray, then progress to writing on a slate just like real students did long ago. A fun, hands-on adventure for kids, teens, and families!
event_name: Class From the Past: Holiday Workshops at Fort York

event_description: Grate, pound and sift sugar and spices in the historic kitchen at Fort York National Historic Site and make an 1831 Gingerbread recipe to taste and take home to enjoy for the holidays. Share stories about ingredients and their histories, and be inspired by renewed gingerbread recipes made by Fort York's Chef in Residence, Jean Régis Raynaud.
event_name: Make, Bake & Take Gingerbread Workshops for Children

event_description:
"I Am Scarborough" is a community-engaged installation at Scarborough Museum, created by artist Kseniya Tsoy during her Toronto Arts Council Animating Historic Sites residency.

Over the course of several months, Scarborough residents and museum visitors came together to fold hundreds of origami butterflies and share their stories—their journeys, the lands their families come from, and their hopes and dreams.

Now gathered and suspended in flight, these butterflies embody the vibrant diversity of Scarborough—soaring high and envisioning a bright, shared future.

Experience their collective flight at Scarborough Museum through October 2025.
event_name: I am Scarborough - Installation at Scarborough Museum
short_description: "I Am Scarborough" is a community-engaged installation at Scarborough Museum, created by artist Kseniya Tsoy during her
short_name: I am Scarborough - Installation at Scarborough Museum

event_description:
An epic, music-charged bromance.

Two years after selling out its Canadian premiere, King Gilgamesh (and the Man of the Wild) returns. This moving, funny, and raucous Dora-winning production weaves together a modern Toronto bromance with the world’s oldest epic.
 
Created and performed by Ahmed Moneka and Jesse LaVercombe alongside Ahmed's 2025-Juno-nominated Arabic jazz band and directed by acclaimed New York and Chicago-based director Seth Bockley, this show has sold out runs and received critical praise in Minneapolis, Halifax, Chicago and New York.

event_description:
Making Home in Scarborough is a vibrant pop-up installation celebrating memory, identity, and belonging through cultural traditions and objects we hold dear to our hearts in generations past, present and future. 
 

Co-created through conversation and care, community members were invited to share a meaningful object, rooted in a heartfelt story. All speak to how home is made not only in buildings or borders, but in the places, people, and practices that give life meaning. 
 
As you explore the exhibition, we invite you to reflect: "What does home mean to you?" If you live in Scarborough, "What does Making Home in Scarborough Mean to you?" 
 
We are grateful for our community collaborators: Native Child and Family Services / Scarborough Child & Family Life Centre, Malvern Family Resource Centre, TDSB Newcomer Services (Malvern), Toby's Place, Scarborough Museum Youth Collective and Change Made.
event_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Making Home in Scarborough at Scarborough Museum

Our class caters to all walks of life and through communal activities we will explore the power of “Yes and..”, fundamentals of narrative construction, and dabble in a bit of theatre devising. We can't wait to meet you!

Register now.

Enjoy a safe and empowering space for racialized youth, ages 16–29 in Scarborough to connect, create, and thrive.
 
Through music, dance, visual arts, storytelling, and games, you’ll discover new ways to build resilience and self-identity, cope with stress, find positive outlets for self-expression and connect with peers who understand your journey.

event_description:
Wrapping up the 2025-26 season with works of eternal genius! 

The superb young Toronto pianist Vanessa Yu joins the ensemble in one of the greatest concertos of all time, Beethoven's noble Piano Concerto No. 5, the "Emperor". Music Director Nurhan Arman leads the orchestra in Dmitri Shostakovich's poignant and personal Chamber Symphony in C minor Op. 110a and finishes with the powerful reassurance of J.S. Bach's Contrapunctus 1 and 2 in beautifully transparent orchestral versions.
short_description:

event_description:
After bonding over a mutual love of The Beatles, drummer Chris Hooper introduced Kevin Kane to his younger brother Tom Hooper in 1977. 

While still attending elementary and junior high school in Kelowna, BC, the trio began learning to play their instruments together during regular Friday night jam sessions in the basement of the Hoopers’ suburban home.

Influenced in equal parts by the British invasion of the 60s and the DIY attitudes and immediacy of punk and new wave, the group took the name The Grapes of Wrath in 1983.

This year, Tom and Kevin are once again hitting the road as a duo to perform The Grapes’ music in an intimate and unplugged setting, telling the stories behind the songs and putting the focus on the harmonies and melodies of their timeless music.
event_name: The Grapes of Wrath Acoustic Duo
short_description: After bonding over a mutual love of The Beatles, drummer Chris Hooper introduced Kevin Kane to his younger brother Tom H
short_name: The Grapes of Wrath Acoustic Duo

event_description:
This internationally touring band of celebrated songwriters greet every stage with a genuine, quirky presence and unbottled chemistry. Their sibling harmonies and familial banter quickly connect them to their audience.

Whether playing an intimate house concert or a sold-out show at a Performing Arts Centre, these classically trained vocalists make it their mission to employ three-part harmony and honest storytelling as the mighty tools that soften and connect us.
short_description: This internationally touring band of celebrated songwriters greet every stage with a genuine, quirky presence and unbott

event_description:
Beginning July 1st at Scarborough Museum, experience Washed Up by Hatecopy. The project captures the essence of liminal spaces that serve as cultural hubs for the South Asian immigrant communities, using the washing machine as a vessel to carry textiles that signify our roots and drawing visitors into an environment that intertwines the past, present, and future; acknowledging the dirty laundry of Canadian History and “Truth,” and reclaiming both seen and unseen spaces.

Maria Qamar (b. 1991) is a Toronto-based pop artist whose work is focused in the South Asian diaspora and immigrant communities and their cultural experiences. The work specializes in themes regarding feminism, social change, humour, pop culture, politics and romance. The artist has been recognized both nationally and internationally with exhibits and features in the Museum of Contemporary Arts, the National Arts Centre, Sotheby’s, Phillips Auction, and the AGO.
event_name: Washed Up: Pop-Up Installation at Scarborough Museum

short_name: Washed Up: Pop-Up Installation at Scarborough Museum

event_description:
What does home mean to you? Discover rarely seen artifacts from the City’s collections and items from community members. Explore the many ways we define, create and carry home with us. From a First World War soldier’s return ticket home to a precious family object stewarded by multiple generations, encounter belongings, voices and stories of Toronto artists, makers, entrepreneurs and community leaders as they share their unique perspectives on belonging, identity and place. These powerful objects offer fresh, heartfelt perspectives on what it means to find, make or remember home.

At Home in Toronto includes the artworks of Rebecca Baird, Carl Beam, Fred Hagan, Robert Houle, Luis Jacob, Kit Li, Raoul Olou, Yasmine Louis and Natalie Wood, as well as loaned works by local artists Doug Brown and Frantz Brent-Harris.
short_description: What does home mean to you? Discover rarely seen artifacts from the City’s collections and items from community members.

event_description: Join us for a spine-chilling paranormal adventure where intimate groups of 12 or fewer will have exclusive access to investigate haunted heritage buildings – including the notorious Half Way House – in the dark! Feel the chill of the night and listen to the whispers of the past as we employ ancient and modern techniques to attempt to establish contact with the lingering spirits that call the Village home. ‘Alone in the Dark’ is as real as it gets, nothing is hidden or staged. This unforgettably eerie evening will delight ghost story enthusiasts, fearless paranormal investigators, history aficionados, urban explorers, and anyone with a curiosity about the unknown. Book your spot now—spaces fill fast! All participants must be 16 or older.
event_name: Alone in the Dark – The Village at Black Creek

event_description:
Experience Toronto like never before with this double-decker night tour. Step aboard an iconic open-top bus and embark on an enchanting journey through the sparkling city lights. Marvel at Toronto's iconic landmarks as they come to life under the night sky.

From the towering CN Tower to the historic Old Town, dive into the sights at your guide illuminates the city's rich history and vibrant culture. With panoramic views from the open-air top deck, capture breathtaking sights and create unforgettable memories.

Enjoy an evening of wonder and discovery on a double-decker night tour of Toronto with guaranteed seating on the upper level.

cost_notes: Engravings are limited to Masashi knives, one per person, first come, first served.
event_description:
Masashi Yamamoto, one of Japan’s most renowned blacksmiths, will make a rare Canadian appearance!

Known for his razor-sharp blades and meticulous craftsmanship, Yamamoto will showcase traditional forging, hand-engrave knives from his exclusive collection, and meet fans and culinary professionals. 

Guests can enjoy a live forging demonstration, chef-led knife skills, appearances by local food creators, and light refreshments. This is a unique opportunity to witness a Japanese master at work and explore the artistry of bladesmithing.
event_name: Master Blacksmith Masashi Yamamoto Demonstrates Live Knife Forging

event_description:
A folk troubadour for the post-truth age, his outspoken lyrics and soaring voice are connecting with millions of listeners around the world. He blends the urgent issues of the day with deeply personal narratives in nostalgic folk arrangements that invite you to sing along.

Explosive growth on social media has seen him reach over 50 million people in just the last few months, with his controversial rewrites of classic songs like God Rest Ye Merry Billionaires, Away In Bomb Shelters, and What's Up America? being adopted as anthems for justice and democracy. Making waves with his captivating live performances, he's opened for Dermot Kennedy, Sarah McLachlan, Walk Off the Earth, Blue Rodeo, The Strumbellas, and played festival stages across North America.
short_description: A folk troubadour for the post-truth age, his outspoken lyrics and soaring voice are connecting with millions of listene

event_description:
You are invited into the beating heart of contemporary craft and design, a space where tradition meets bold reinvention, and where the maker’s hand is ever-present. 

Through the exceptional work of our current Artists-in-Residence, this exhibition explores the enduring relevance of skilled making in a world dominated by speed, automation and disposability. 

We are a cornerstone of Canada’s craft landscape, a rare incubator where artists have the time, space and support to experiment, collaborate and grow their professional careers. From glass, metal and ceramics to textiles and contemporary design, the residents featured here are not only shaping objects – they are shaping culture.  

In this context, to “meet your maker” is to engage with the processes, politics and poetics of craft and design today. It’s a chance to stand face to face with emerging visionaries who transform raw mate

event_description:
This is our seventh solo exhibition of work by Canadian artist Sarah Anne Johnson.

This journey is presented in two chapters: “Cedar Forest” and “Mountain”. Both series expound on the artist’s “Woodland” series, offering new dimensions and depth to an already impressive body of work. 

“Mountain” offers a quiet, personal reflection on horseback trek through Jasper National Park, while “Cedar Forest” draws viewers into the mesmerizing cedar groves of British Columbia. These series exist in beautiful harmony as a meditation on the natural world, and what it mean means to experience it fully.
event_name: A Mountain and a Forest by Sarah Anne Johnson
short_description:
This is our seventh solo exhibition of work by Canadian artist Sarah Anne Johnson.

event_description: Kensington Flea is back for the 2025 season, bringing the vibrant spirit of local entrepreneurship to the heart of Kensington Market every weekend. The market features an exciting lineup of independent artisans, small businesses, vintage curators & emerging designers — all coming together to celebrate the best of Toronto’s creative culture.

event_description:
In commemoration of the 80th anniversary of the end of World War II and the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. 

The series consists of 29 posters, headed by KAMEKURA Yūsaku’s masterpiece “Burning Butterflies” 1983, continued with an unbroken sequence of works of high artistic excellence. 

In addition, 49 posters will be displayed with global messages from our collection, and Toronto’s poster collection accompany the Hiroshima Appeals posters, focusing on the shared unique nature of their design creation in being non-commercial, abstract, conceptual, and reflecting on global issues and subjects.
event_name: Hiroshima Appeals: A Poster Exhibition of Global Messages
short_description: In commemoration of the 80th anniversary of the end of World War II and the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.
short_name: Hiroshima Appeals: A Poster Exhibition of Global Messages

event_description:
I’m So Glad We Had This Time Together, by 2024 Toronto Book Award winner Maurice Vellekoop, is a graphic memoir tracing his journey from a queer boy in a strict Christian home to a renowned artist. Set in 1970s Toronto, it delves into family, faith, sexuality, and art’s transformative power, blending humor and poignancy. This event will be moderated by Chris Middleton.

By the Lake Book Club hosts six Tuesday-night events from February to December with top Canadian authors and Humber Polytechnics alumni. Each in-person event features readings, discussions, Q&A, book signings, and ASL interpretation, while virtual sessions include live subtitles and audio access.
event_name: I’m So Glad We Had This Time Together by Maurice Vellekoop – By the Lake Book Club
short_description: I’m So Glad We Had This Time Together, by 2024 Toronto Book Award winner Maurice Vellekoop, is a graphic memoir tracing
short_name: I’m So Glad We Had This Time Together by Maurice Vellekoop –

event_description:
Laura Piccinin, the creator of "LESBIHONEST", “Every Silver Lining”, and “Apothecary”, and winner of Just for Laughs'  "Outstanding English Comedy Award", brings a new, 90-minute comedic tale of outdoorsy adventure.

In "WOMAN, ALONE" as she dares to walk 336km along the East Coast of Newfoundland. While on her journey of trying not to get killed in the woods, she recounts the stories of her life, and the decisions she’s made in the face of danger (real or perceived) along the way. This sentimental and hilarious show reminds audiences to get out of their own way and GO do that thing that they really, really want to do.
short_description: Laura Piccinin, the creator of "LESBIHONEST", “Every Silver Lining”, and “Apothecary”, and winner of Just for Laughs'  "

event_description:
You are invited into the beating heart of contemporary craft and design, a space where tradition meets bold reinvention, and where the maker’s hand is ever-present. 

Through the exceptional work of our current Artists-in-Residence, this exhibition explores the enduring relevance of skilled making in a world dominated by speed, automation and disposability. 

We are a cornerstone of Canada’s craft landscape, a rare incubator where artists have the time, space and support to experiment, collaborate and grow their professional careers. From glass, metal and ceramics to textiles and contemporary design, the residents featured here are not only shaping objects – they are shaping culture.  

In this context, to “meet your maker” is to engage with the processes, politics and poetics of craft and design today. It’s a chance to stand face to face with emerging visionaries who transform raw mate
short_description: You are invited into the beating heart of contemporary craft and design, a space where tradition meets bold reinvention,

event_description:
Welcome to Le Dolci’s exclusive 5-day Parisian Baking Series: Desserts from Paris! Perfect for beginners, this hands-on course runs 5 hours daily (plus a 30-minute lunch) and teaches the art of French pastry.

Day 1: Master fruit and chocolate tarts.
Day 2: Create flaky croissants and pain au chocolat.
Day 3: Learn enriched doughs like brioche and babka.
Day 4: Pipe and fill éclairs and cream puffs with choux pastry.
Day 5: Perfect macarons and soufflés.

Guided by expert chefs, you'll gain practical skills and pastry theory. Join us and bring the sweet taste of Paris to life!

event_description:
A quiet lake in Ontario is making a lot of noise.

Sediments from the bottom of a small lake in Ontario are revealing a remarkable record of our impact on the planet.

Just outside Toronto, Ontario lies Crawford Lake, a significant site offering a unique, comprehensive 1,000-year record of human impacts - local, regional, and global.

event_description: Join us as we explore the supernatural side of Toronto’s historic and haunted pioneer village Featuring some of the oldest buildings in the city it is the perfect creepy backdrop for a night of spine-tingling ghost stories. Many of which have occurred to previous village guests and Haunted Walk tour guides. It is easily one of the most active sites we tour and is a must-do for paranormal enthusiasts. Not recommended for children or easily frightened adults.
event_name: Ghosts of the Village at Black Creek

event_description:
The Toronto Music Garden will be transformed into a celebration of sound and light during a series of free live performances featuring Land of Talk, Sean Jones, Soulpepper Academy, Begonia, Amanda Rheaume, The North Sound, Charlotte Cornfield, Tanika Charles and The Recipee Band complemented by glowing interactive lights.

Bring a blanket or lawn chair, settle in by the water, and take in the magic of music, lights and community at the waterfront.

Part of Water/Fall Festival.

event_description:
What makes for a delightful picnic? Food and drink? Poetry? Music? 

Immerse yourself into the pleasures, pastimes, and artistic heritage of Iran during the Safavid dynasty (1501-1736). A royal picnic, depicted on a large, treasured tile arch from the collections, is complemented by exceptional objects from the period.

event_description:
A quiet lake in Ontario is making a lot of noise.

Sediments from the bottom of a small lake in Ontario are revealing a remarkable record of our impact on the planet.

Just outside Toronto, Ontario lies Crawford Lake, a significant site offering a unique, comprehensive 1,000-year record of human impacts - local, regional, and global.

All children and youth under 16 must be accompanied by an adult ticketholder. 
Tickets may be purchased using the online registration system for City of Toronto Recreation programs. If you do not already have an account, you will be prompted to create one.
event_description: Experience the magic of the season with a tour of Spadina Museum by lamplight. See the lavish 55-room mansion fully decorated for the holidays, just as it was in the 1920s. An experienced guide will lead you through this rare opportunity to explore the house by night. As you arrive, take in a 1920s silent film and enjoy a glass of non-alcoholic punch recreated from a historic recipe. Light up the season with the magic of the winter solstice, spreading joy, peace and festive cheer at Toronto History Museums!
event_name: Holiday Lamplight Tours at Spadina Museum

This is a celebration of the natural world, combining music, movement and spoken text. 

Featuring the world premiere of Toronto composer Shahriar Aslani's "Folk Songs from North Iran", plus stunning and rarely-heard works by Tormis, Dvořák, Saint-Saëns, Leslie Uyeda, Adolphus Hailstork, and more. 

Join us for a pre-concert chat with Artistic Director Thomas Burton.
event_name: Orpheus Choir: The Earth I Know

event_description:
Discover how homes shape identity through the Austin family story and contemporary art at Spadina Museum. Reimagine history, reframe home.

“Home at Spadina Museum” considers how people are influenced by their home. We look at those who make it a home and those who live in it are shaped by domestic spaces. Through interpretation of the Austin family and into contemporary art, we will analyze what makes a home. Re-Imagining the Historic House Museum: A Workplace for Women. 

Step into “Home at Spadina Museum” and explore how homes are shaped by the people who live and work in them. From the Austin family to contemporary art, discover untold stories of women’s labour, care, and community. Reimagine the historic house as both a home and a workplace.

As you explore the exhibition, we invite you to reflect: "What does home mean to you?"

We are grateful to our community partners, Augusto Bitter and the Women’s Art Association of Canada.
event_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Home at Spadina Museum

event_description:
Celebrate the works of acclaimed Irish playwright, Conor McPherson.

The Weir looks in a small rural pub in the West of Ireland, where local lads spin tales of the supernatural, as they vie for the attention of a young woman who recently moved into the area. Little do they know that she has her own personal and compelling story to weave...

Directed by Co-artistic Producer, Rod Ceballos and features Richard Harte (The Boys in the Photograph), Mairi Babb (WAR HORSE), David Mackett (The Good Thief), and Enda Reilly (Toronto Bloomsday Festival).
short_description:
Celebrate the works of acclaimed Irish playwright, Conor McPherson.

The Weir looks in a small rural pub in the West of

event_description:
Curated by Yantong Li, a Master of Visual Studies Curatorial Studies graduate student. 

Featured artists Kent Chan, Alvin Luong, and Solveig Qu Suess interrogate the way we currently consume media about environmental precarity, inviting viewers to engage in a dialogue and sit with representations of catastrophe that deemphasize the spectacular and dramatic. 

Dwelling Under Distant Suns highlights the struggle to make visible the increasingly unpredictable landscape of the climate crisis and other human-led impacts on the environment. Using speculative storytelling and myth-making through film-based works, this exhibition brings a sense of immediacy to our planet’s growing climate crisis and the environmental dangers that feel distant or out of sight.
event_name: Art Museum at the University of Toronto: Dwelling Under Distant Suns
short_description:
Curated by Yantong Li, a Master of Visual Studies Curatorial Studies graduate student. 

Featured artists Kent Chan, Alv
short_name: Art Museum at the University of Toronto: Dwelling Under Dist

event_description: Introducing “Hidden Toronto” – the new light-hearted walking tour from the creators of The Haunted Walk that’s gonna have you chuckling with laughter and shaking your head in disbelief. Join our crew of storytelling guides as we take you on a 90-minute adventure through the hidden side of Toronto. From movie mistakes to our infamous clown riot, these fun tales of mischief and mayhem make up the fascinating story of our city. Guffaw and gasp through the city’s streets as our fun and engaging tour guides spill the beans on those little-known stories and secrets that define Toronto’s hidden personality. “Hidden Toronto” is a fun and engaging good-natured adventure, perfect for first-time visitors and locals alike.
short_description: Introducing “Hidden Toronto” – the new light-hearted walking tour from the creators of The Haunted Walk that’s gonna hav

event_description:
Curated by Mikinaak Migwans, Earthwork redefines a term that until now has referred to a type of artistic practice associated within the larger conceptual framework of land art. 

In this exhibition, Migwans shifts our understanding of earthwork to refer to a way of working, rather than the making of singular objects, reclaiming the art historical framing from an Indigenous perspective. It considers multiple layers of engagement with the land, including a history of land defense movements, medicine walks, and ancestral practices of prescribed burns, alongside contemporary art.

Featured artists include Michael Belmore, BUSH Gallery (Gabrielle L’Hirondelle Hill, Peter Morin, Tania Willard), Faye HeavyShield, Art Hunter, Alex Jacobs-Blum, Mike MacDonald, Lisa Myers, Edward Poitras, and Protect the Tract Collective.
event_name: Art Museum at the University of Toronto: Earthwork
short_description: Curated by Mikinaak Migwans, Earthwork redefines a term that until now has referred to a type of artistic practice assoc
short_name: Art Museum at the University of Toronto: Earthwork

Step into a world of elegance, artistry, and pure musical magic as soprano superstar Renée Fleming makes her Koerner Hall debut in the most anticipated cultural evening of the season!

Enjoy an exclusive pre-concert cocktail reception and exquisite dinner set the stage for an unforgettable evening.
event_name: An Intimate Evening with Renée Fleming

event_description:
Making Home in Scarborough is a vibrant pop-up installation celebrating memory, identity, and belonging through cultural traditions and objects we hold dear to our hearts in generations past, present and future. 
 

Co-created through conversation and care, community members were invited to share a meaningful object, rooted in a heartfelt story. All speak to how home is made not only in buildings or borders, but in the places, people, and practices that give life meaning. 
 
As you explore the exhibition, we invite you to reflect: "What does home mean to you?" If you live in Scarborough, "What does Making Home in Scarborough Mean to you?" 
 
We are grateful for our community collaborators: Native Child and Family Services / Scarborough Child & Family Life Centre, Malvern Family Resource Centre, TDSB Newcomer Services (Malvern), Toby's Place, Scarborough Museum Youth Collective and Change Made.
event_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Making Home in Scarborough at Scarborough Museum
short_description: Making Home in Scarborough is a vibrant pop-up installation celebrating memory, identity, and belonging through cultural
short_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Making Home in Scarborough at Scarborough Mu

Co-created through conversation and care, community members were invited to share a meaningful object, rooted in a heartfelt story. All speak to how home is made not only in buildings or borders, but in the places, people, and practices that give life meaning. 
 
As you explore the exhibition, we invite you to reflect: "What does home mean to you?" If you live in Scarborough, "What does Making Home in Scarborough Mean to you?" 
 
We are grateful for our community collaborators: Native Child and Family Services / Scarborough Child & Family Life Centre, Malvern Family Resource Centre, TDSB Newcomer Services (Malvern), Toby's Place, Scarborough Museum Youth Collective and Change Made.
event_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Making Home in Scarborough at Scarborough Museum
short_description: Making Home in Scarborough is a vibrant pop-up installation celebrating memory, identity, and belonging through cultural
short_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Making Home in Scarborough at Scarborough Mu

event_description:
Photography comes alive! 

Professional dancers, musicians and poets interpret the work of nine different photographers. View the awesome synergy created in these performances, known as Ekphrasis!  

Exhibit is open for viewing by appointment, please contact.
short_description:
Photography comes alive! 

Professional dancers, musicians and poets interpret the work of nine different photographers.

event_description:
The Ethennonnhawahstihnen' branch and its neighbourhood are home to a variety of trees. Join City of Toronto Urban Forestry staff to explore the natural world on a local neighbourhood walk. Learn how to recognize different species and fun facts about their cultural and ecological importance.

Children under 12 must be accompanied by a parent/caregiver. Please note that the tour will start and end at the library branch and will be guided by the City of Toronto Urban Forestry staff. There may be uneven, unpaved surfaces along the route outside and around the neighbourhood.

Please dress and prepare accordingly for this outdoor program (e.g. gloves/mittens, hats, sunscreen, water, comfortable shoes). This program takes place rain or shine. In the event of severe inclement weather, please register with the branch to be notified of an alternative date. Registration is required. Please contact the branch by phone or in person to register.
event_name: Trees Around the Branch Tour at Ethennonnhawahstihnen' Library
short_description: The Ethennonnhawahstihnen' branch and its neighbourhood are home to a variety of trees. Join City of Toronto Urban Fores
short_name: Trees Around the Branch Tour at Ethennonnhawahstihnen' Libra

event_description:
Let the WILD Rumpus Begin!

Hot on the heels of last year’s sold-out sensation, Max and the Wild Things roar back to the YPT stage. Embark on a magical interactive journey as you help transform Max’s bedroom into the legendary land of the Wild Things! Crowned their king, Max faces a big decision: rule the rumpus or return home? Based on Maurice Sendak’s beloved storybook, this adaptation is an interactive experience. 

Audience members will be seated around the performance area on three large mats, with limited chairs provided at the back for grownups who may require a seat.

event_description: A brand-new comedy show clocking in to roast the unrelenting day-to-day grind. From incompetent managers and weird co-workers to impossible customers and inboxes that are like an all-you-can-eat buffet of stupidity, no job is safe. Whether you’re hustling in the gig economy, surviving the 9-to-5, or just trying to make it through one more Zoom call without consuming a vat of medical-grade caffeine, The Second City’s cast of comedic professionals are here working overtime with their world-famous brand of sketch and improv comedy. Don’t call in sick… you’ll want to be here for this shift.
short_description: A brand-new comedy show clocking in to roast the unrelenting day-to-day grind. From incompetent managers and weird co-wo

event_description:
Curated by Manar Abo Touk, this is a multidisciplinary group exhibition that reimagines the gallery as a living garden, a shared space of care, restoration, and quiet resistance.

Bringing together artists who work with natural, digital, and tactile materials to navigate experiences of displacement, intergenerational grief, and mental health.

Informed by diasporic, feminist, and ecological perspectives, the exhibition explores themes of collective tending, healing practices, and the everyday rituals that sustain us.
event_name: Being Scene 2025 Curated Exhibition: Tending to What Remains
short_description: Curated by Manar Abo Touk, this is a multidisciplinary group exhibition that reimagines the gallery as a living garden,
short_name: Being Scene 2025 Curated Exhibition: Tending to What Remains

event_description:
Join us on a chilling and thrilling journey through the dark history of the city as we delve into the world of ghosts, graveyards, hangings, and haunts.

 Prepare to be captivated by spine-tingling ghost stories about haunted theatres, unsolved mysteries, secrets hiding in plain sight, and spooky historic buildings. Our outdoor tour will take you on a hair-raising paranormal adventure, departing from the courtyard in front of the Hockey Hall of Fame. 

Get ready to see the city in a whole new light, or rather, darkness, as you uncover the eerie and supernatural tales that lurk in its shadows.

event_description:
Guests of all ages are invited to enjoy a cozy, seasonal celebration that combines sustainability, creativity, and connection.

In exchange for a non-perishable food item or a monetary donation to the Daily Bread Food Bank, enjoy a seasonal coffee bar, mini pumpkin painting, live msuic and cozy lounge vigs and free portraits

This seasonal event brings together everything we love about autumn: cozy vibes, creativity, giving back, and community!

event_description:
A spoken word poetry program for youth in the Jane and Finch community. Youth will learn the fundamentals of spoken word with Jayda Marley and Naiesha Marques and have the opportunity to present what they have learned at a final showcase for family and friends. 

A City of Toronto Cultural Hotspot Signature Project.
event_name: Pass the Mic: Shaping Radical Futures
short_description: A spoken word poetry program for youth in the Jane and Finch community. Youth will learn the fundamentals of spoken word
short_name: Pass the Mic: Shaping Radical Futures

event_description:
Welcoming audiences into an energetic visions of stories where memory, resistance, and imagination intertwine. 

This year’s line-up follows the rhythms of identity, from the pulsing beats of Afro-Antillean music to the quiet landscapes of childhood wonder to journeys across mountains, cities, and deserts in search of home and the intimate crossings of generations, friendships and dreams. 

In these films, rupture gives way to transformation, and every frame holds the promise of renewal. We honour voices that refuse to be silenced, visions that reshape reality, and connections that reach across borders. 

This is both a celebration and a reflection, a space where stories become bridges, and where watching together creates imagination and opens innovation.
event_name: aluCine Latin Film and Media Arts Festival Toronto
short_description:
Welcoming audiences into an energetic visions of stories where memory, resistance, and imagination intertwine. 

This ye
short_name: aluCine Latin Film and Media Arts Festival Toronto

event_description:
The must-see event of the Halloween season is back! From the creators of the sold-out sensation, Tales of the Grotesque (2023 - 2024), comes a new anthology of gothic horror. Experience what critics call a “devilish delight!” With fresh characters, familiar tales, and unique terrors, we bring literature’s most depraved characters to life… and death.

After a lady of the night is murdered, a mad doctor strikes a pact with the Devil to raise her from the dead. But when he comes face-to-face with her killer at a masquerade, all hell breaks loose. Descend into madness with Victor Frankenstein, Henry Jekyll, and Dorian Gray as they discover the consequences of playing God and the monstrous repercussions when the Devil comes to collect. 

An immersive horror opera set within the oldest surviving building from the Town of York, we invite you to explore Victorian Toronto through the eyes of history’s most disturbed authors, though it might just cost your soul.
short_description: The must-see event of the Halloween season is back! From the creators of the sold-out sensation, Tales of the Grotesque

event_description:
In commemoration of the 80th anniversary of the end of World War II and the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. 

The series consists of 29 posters, headed by KAMEKURA Yūsaku’s masterpiece “Burning Butterflies” 1983, continued with an unbroken sequence of works of high artistic excellence. 

In addition, 49 posters will be displayed with global messages from our collection, and Toronto’s poster collection accompany the Hiroshima Appeals posters, focusing on the shared unique nature of their design creation in being non-commercial, abstract, conceptual, and reflecting on global issues and subjects.
event_name: Hiroshima Appeals: A Poster Exhibition of Global Messages
short_description: In commemoration of the 80th anniversary of the end of World War II and the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.
short_name: Hiroshima Appeals: A Poster Exhibition of Global Messages

event_description:
This family-friendly exhibition invites you to uncover fresh perspectives, groundbreaking research and the astounding diversity of this ancient group of fishes.

Visitors will delve into the anatomy, behaviour, and history of sharks, from familiar favourites like tiger sharks and great whites to lesser-known species like the dwarf lanternshark—a tiny, light-producing marvel small enough to hold in your hand.

Through dozens of interactives and life-sized models, including a life-size head of the huge extinct Megalodon, join us for a unique look at these magnificent creatures, their habitats, hunting techniques, and the conservation threats that they face.
short_description: This family-friendly exhibition invites you to uncover fresh perspectives, groundbreaking research and the astounding di

event_description:
This family-friendly exhibition invites you to uncover fresh perspectives, groundbreaking research and the astounding diversity of this ancient group of fishes.

Visitors will delve into the anatomy, behaviour, and history of sharks, from familiar favourites like tiger sharks and great whites to lesser-known species like the dwarf lanternshark—a tiny, light-producing marvel small enough to hold in your hand.

Through dozens of interactives and life-sized models, including a life-size head of the huge extinct Megalodon, join us for a unique look at these magnificent creatures, their habitats, hunting techniques, and the conservation threats that they face.

event_description:
Join Jane Finch Centre's Artists-in-Residence, Taejah Daniel (Coach Milly), Vanna Nguyen and Rod Osei-Nuako (Reezy) for an outdoor art installation at Corner Commons. This Artist-in-Residence is held within Invitations to Better Worlds project and is a collaboration with the Department of Imaginary Affairs and Jane/Finch Centre. Through their residencies, the artists have brought to life their interpretations of a collective vision for better worlds for Jane and Finch. This project is an emergence of community engagement, storytelling, collective liberation, foresight and art. It is a practice in believing better worlds are possible.

A City of Toronto Cultural Hotspot Signature Project.
event_name: Invitations to Better Worlds: Artist Showcase + Meet & Greet

short_name: Invitations to Better Worlds: Artist Showcase + Meet & Greet

event_description:
This is a contemporary form of environmental art created by artists who are  concerned about reducing waste, recycling, and making the world a better place, while raising awareness about environmental changes.

 It aims to showcases the beauty and creativity of using recycled, environmentally friendly or sustainable materials to create phenomenal artwork, using water-based paints, natural pigments and recycled materials to name a few elements. lt is art that advocates for the planet, catering to all ages and present in various mediums, including paintings, sculptures or fashion.

Presenting our second annual art exhibition, we will be utilizing selected artists to mentor African and Caribbean communities on the positioning of multicultural history and art within the Canadian cultural landscape.

event_description:
Step back in time with a free visit to Spadina Museum, beautifully decorated for a 1920s Christmas. Visitors can enjoy the opulent holiday décor and period ambiance that once filled the home of the wealthy Austin family. Twinkling lights, antique ornaments, and rooms set for a classic Jazz Age celebration bring the spirit of the season to life.
As you stroll through the mansion, interpretive displays offer insights into the lavish holiday traditions of Toronto’s elite in the 1920s. In contrast, visitors will also learn about the experiences of the city’s less fortunate citizens during the same era—those who faced poverty, unemployment, and food insecurity during a time of great social and economic change.
From a grand dining room prepared for a festive feast to modest depictions of how the servants of the household marked the holidays, the experience paints a full picture of a Toronto Christmas in the early 20th century.
event_name: Jazz Age Christmas at Spadina Museum

short_name: Jazz Age Christmas at Spadina Museum

event_description:
Join us for an unforgettable night of music and storytelling featuring three standout artists, each with a distinct voice and powerful presence hosted by Toronto’s own drag superstar, Miss Moco.

Emm Gryner is a 3-time JUNO nominee whose career spans decades and genres. From performing at Glastonbury Festival to recording with icons like David Bowie and Def Leppard, Emm’s music is raw, honest, and deeply resonant.

Andrew Spice, a classically trained pianist, vocalist and songwriter from rural Manitoba, blends classical foundations with 90s confessional songwriting influences. Drawing comparisons to Tori Amos and Fiona Apple, Andrew’s emotionally rich performances are cathartic and captivating.

Gentleman Reg is an indie pop icon with a voice “from the heavens” and a storied history in Canadian music.
event_name: Emm Gryner, Andrew Spice and Gentleman Reg
short_description: Join us for an unforgettable night of music and storytelling featuring three standout artists, each with a distinct voic
short_name: Emm Gryner, Andrew Spice and Gentleman Reg

event_description:
Join us as we celebrate the vibrant, dreamlike worlds of this Korean-Canadian artist, whose work invites quiet reflection and a deep connection to life’s dynamic flow.  

Ellee SY Lee is a Korean-Canadian artist whose semi-abstract landscape paintings explore a range of visual and emotional experiences. Immigrating to Canada as a teenager, she quickly discovered a love for art-making, with painting becoming a powerful and liberating way to connect with her subconscious and emotions.
event_name: Exhibition "In the Rhythm of Being" by Ellee SY Lee
short_description: Join us as we celebrate the vibrant, dreamlike worlds of this Korean-Canadian artist, whose work invites quiet reflectio
short_name: Exhibition "In the Rhythm of Being" by Ellee SY Lee

event_description:
Pop singer-songwriter Dragonette, film composer Jonathan Goldsmith, and The Henrys frontman Don Rooke put their distinctive musical backgrounds together to form a genre-blurring trio united by the playful constraint of crafting songs under two minutes.

Martina Sorbara, better known as the electro-pop outfit Dragonette, has lived multiple musical lifetimes over the past 15 years. A Juno Award-winning artist and sought-after songwriter, Sorbara has scored numerous global hits, including "Pick Up the Phone," "Let it Go," and the chart-topping "Hello" with Martin Solveig.

event_description:
We are pleased to bring you the fifth annual Greek International Film Festival Tour of Canada (GIFFT).

This is a Canadian national film festival that will take place in 11 Canadian cities simultaneously. Those cities include: Toronto, Vancouver, Edmonton, Calgary, Regina, Winnipeg, London (Ontario), Hamilton/Niagara, Ottawa, and Halifax.

GIFFT is a showcase and celebration of Greek cinema and filmmakers of Greek Heritage. This festival will provide exciting platform for directors, writers, producers, and actors of Greek Heritage to showcase their exceptional art across Canada.

We are pleased to bring you the fifth annual Greek International Film Festival Tour of Canada (GIFFT).

A quiet lake in Ontario is making a lot of noise.

Sediments from the bottom of a small lake in Ontario are revealing a remarkable record of our impact on the planet.

Just outside Toronto, Ontario lies Crawford Lake, a significant site offering a unique, comprehensive 1,000-year record of human impacts - local, regional, and global.

event_description: Join us as we explore the supernatural side of Toronto’s historic and haunted pioneer village Featuring some of the oldest buildings in the city it is the perfect creepy backdrop for a night of spine-tingling ghost stories. Many of which have occurred to previous village guests and Haunted Walk tour guides. It is easily one of the most active sites we tour and is a must-do for paranormal enthusiasts. Not recommended for children or easily frightened adults.
event_name: Ghosts of the Village at Black Creek

event_description: Every tree begins with a seed, but the origin of seeds is a much older story. From the smallest pine cone to giant coconuts, tree seeds have been shaping our planet for millions of years. Join Anna Ketchum from the City of Toronto's Urban Forestry department for a webinar on the incredible evolution of tree seeds. You'll learn how seeds first evolved, why they come in so many different shapes and sizes, and how they've enabled trees to disperse, persist, and adapt to a wide range of environmental conditions.
event_name: Tree Seeds: Form, Flight, and Evolution Webinar
short_description: Every tree begins with a seed, but the origin of seeds is a much older story. From the smallest pine cone to giant cocon
short_name: Tree Seeds: Form, Flight, and Evolution Webinar

event_description:
Visionary, uncompromising, and ever-evolving, Jane Siberry is one of Canada's most original and influential singer-songwriters. Best known for transcendent works like "Calling All Angels", "Love Is Everything", and the iconic "Mimi On The Beach", she has created a singular body of work that defies categorization. 

Her haunting contribution to The Crow soundtrack, "It Won't Rain All The Time", continues to resonate more than ever three decades later.

Despite a prolific career, Siberry reflects: "I feel like I'm inching my way toward my prime."
short_description: Visionary, uncompromising, and ever-evolving, Jane Siberry is one of Canada's most original and influential singer-songw

event_description:
Join us on a chilling and thrilling journey through the dark history of the city as we delve into the world of ghosts, graveyards, hangings, and haunts.

 Prepare to be captivated by spine-tingling ghost stories about haunted theatres, unsolved mysteries, secrets hiding in plain sight, and spooky historic buildings. Our outdoor tour will take you on a hair-raising paranormal adventure, departing from the courtyard in front of the Hockey Hall of Fame. 

Get ready to see the city in a whole new light, or rather, darkness, as you uncover the eerie and supernatural tales that lurk in its shadows.

short_name: Jazz Age Christmas at Spadina Museum

event_description:
Two internationally acclaimed  experiences, SÉANCE and FLIGHT, are coming. 

Staged inside purpose-built 40-foot shipping containers, these genre-defying works use complete darkness, 360° binaural audio, and precisely timed physical and environmental effects to create psychologically charged alternate realities.

The Toronto season brings two of the company’s most toured experiences to Canada for the first time. With over 700,000 attendees worldwide and appearances of their work at Venice Film Festival, Tribeca, SXSW, and Edinburgh Fringe, Toronto is now invited also to step inside the dark.

event_description: Celebrating 31 years at Mel Lastman Square this season! We welcome your tried and true Farm and Artisanal Vendor favourites, sprinkled with a few new, excitingly delicious, grab and go options for lunch or dinner. Let's eat, drink, and make merry while celebrating the diversity and richness of our local and regional blessings. We look forward to meeting, and thank you for your support!
short_description: Celebrating 31 years at Mel Lastman Square this season! We welcome your tried and true Farm and Artisanal Vendor favouri

event_description:
Curated by Mikinaak Migwans, Earthwork redefines a term that until now has referred to a type of artistic practice associated within the larger conceptual framework of land art. 

In this exhibition, Migwans shifts our understanding of earthwork to refer to a way of working, rather than the making of singular objects, reclaiming the art historical framing from an Indigenous perspective. It considers multiple layers of engagement with the land, including a history of land defense movements, medicine walks, and ancestral practices of prescribed burns, alongside contemporary art.

Featured artists include Michael Belmore, BUSH Gallery (Gabrielle L’Hirondelle Hill, Peter Morin, Tania Willard), Faye HeavyShield, Art Hunter, Alex Jacobs-Blum, Mike MacDonald, Lisa Myers, Edward Poitras, and Protect the Tract Collective.
event_name: Art Museum at the University of Toronto: Earthwork
short_description: Curated by Mikinaak Migwans, Earthwork redefines a term that until now has referred to a type of artistic practice assoc
