Wax is mostly known as a rapper. He is also a producer, songwriter, singer (kinda), comedian, and all around creative dude. 

He has been making music for many many years now. Wax's songs have a wide range of styles and cater to many different types of fans and haters. Some are advanced technical displays of rap wordplay, some are heartfelt tales of struggle, some are inspirational numbers containing optimistic advice and or guidance.

event_description:
Join us on a chilling and thrilling journey through the dark history of the city as we delve into the world of ghosts, graveyards, hangings, and haunts.

 Prepare to be captivated by spine-tingling ghost stories about haunted theatres, unsolved mysteries, secrets hiding in plain sight, and spooky historic buildings. Our outdoor tour will take you on a hair-raising paranormal adventure, departing from the courtyard in front of the Hockey Hall of Fame. 

Get ready to see the city in a whole new light, or rather, darkness, as you uncover the eerie and supernatural tales that lurk in its shadows.

event_description:
An outdoor dance workshop exploring the basic fundamentals of different international dance styles. This six week program is a fun, interactive and high energy environment to learn new dance moves and connect with local community members. Dance styles will alternate so that each dance style is offered twice, allowing new and returning participants to build their skills:

Sept 4 & Sept 25 – Hip Hop (Definitely Dance)
Sept 11 & Oct 2 – Ugandan Kigandan Dance (Shifah Halima)
Sept 18 & Oct 9 –  Salsa Line Dancing (Dance Life Studios)

A City of Toronto Cultural Hotspot SPARK Project.
short_description: An outdoor dance workshop exploring the basic fundamentals of different international dance styles. This six week progra

event_description:
Beginning July 1st at Scarborough Museum, experience Washed Up by Hatecopy. The project captures the essence of liminal spaces that serve as cultural hubs for the South Asian immigrant communities, using the washing machine as a vessel to carry textiles that signify our roots and drawing visitors into an environment that intertwines the past, present, and future; acknowledging the dirty laundry of Canadian History and “Truth,” and reclaiming both seen and unseen spaces.

Maria Qamar (b. 1991) is a Toronto-based pop artist whose work is focused in the South Asian diaspora and immigrant communities and their cultural experiences. The work specializes in themes regarding feminism, social change, humour, pop culture, politics and romance. The artist has been recognized both nationally and internationally with exhibits and features in the Museum of Contemporary Arts, the National Arts Centre, Sotheby’s, Phillips Auction, and the AGO.
event_name: Washed Up: Pop-Up Installation at Scarborough Museum

Join us for the reception with artist present. 

Grace Wang‘s exhibition is an intensely personal journey into the quiet mysteries of nature and existence. Through dreamlike, layered images created with in-camera multiple exposures on film, Wang evokes fleeting moments of memory and time — an intimate meditation on a world both beautiful and unknowable.

event_description:
Making Home in Scarborough is a vibrant pop-up installation celebrating memory, identity, and belonging through cultural traditions and objects we hold dear to our hearts in generations past, present and future. 
 

Co-created through conversation and care, community members were invited to share a meaningful object, rooted in a heartfelt story. All speak to how home is made not only in buildings or borders, but in the places, people, and practices that give life meaning. 
 
As you explore the exhibition, we invite you to reflect: "What does home mean to you?" If you live in Scarborough, "What does Making Home in Scarborough Mean to you?" 
 
We are grateful for our community collaborators: Native Child and Family Services / Scarborough Child & Family Life Centre, Malvern Family Resource Centre, TDSB Newcomer Services (Malvern), Toby's Place, Scarborough Museum Youth Collective and Change Made.
event_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Making Home in Scarborough at Scarborough Museum
short_description: Making Home in Scarborough is a vibrant pop-up installation celebrating memory, identity, and belonging through cultural
short_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Making Home in Scarborough at Scarborough Mu

event_description:
Every month, we're featuring two celebrated troupes performing polished 30-minute shows for a two night run. Hosted and produced by Taylor Hreljac and Gabe Meacher, this series presents sketch comedy’s best troupes in their best light. 

"We're so excited to be supporting Spotlight at The Second City. Last month, they brought in two sold out audiences to see some hilarious comedy! This new initiative is exactly what the Toronto comedy scene needs: a platform for fresh new sketch comedy to come to life,"  said Susan Waycik, Managing Producer, The Second City Toronto.

This month we're proud to present "$20 Sandwich", featuring Brennan Ashbridge, Tony Hall, Shaun Hunter and Chase Jeffels. They are a sketch troupe known for their viral reels that have amassed 10s of millions of views across TikTok and Instagram. Also presenting the hilarious Sarah Bennett.
short_description: Every month, we're featuring two celebrated troupes performing polished 30-minute shows for a two night run. Hosted and

event_description:
This Halloween, Montgomery's Inn invites visitors after dark to uncover eerie tales about the past inhabitants of the Inn and the Old Town of Islington. Visitors will explore the historic house and the Islington burying grounds, learn about Victorian death practices, and find new ways to connect with Toronto's past.

This guided tour of the historic house will be followed by a walking tour of the nearby Islington Burying grounds. Following the walking tour, guests will return to the historic house for refreshments by the fire.

Trigger warning: topics such as illness, death and other difficult topics will be discussed during this event.

This program is for ages 12 and up. Youth 12-16 years of age much be accompanied by an adult ticketholder.

Non-resident surcharge will not apply.

TICKETS ARE NON-REFUNDABLE.

event_description:
This is a solo exhibition by Ukrainian-Canadian artist Olga Polstvin.

Olga is a multidisciplinary artist, cultural leader, and Master of Arts Leadership candidate at Queen’s University whose practice bridges painting, storytelling, and community engagement. Born in Kyiv, Ukraine, she carries forward the resilience and cultural memory of her heritage, weaving themes of belonging, healing, and identity into her work.
event_name: Through the Lens of Ukrainian Belonging

event_description:
Join the Highland Creek Lead Stewards for an evening of hands-on stewardship in the ravines and natural areas. 

Together, we’ll care for this vital green space by learning about local ecology, removing invasive species, and supporting the health of native plants and wildlife habitats.

Join us and learn about plants and trees, spend time outdoors in nature, meet fellow nature lovers, remove invasive plants and plant native plant gardens. 

No experience necessary. Bring your enthusiasm for nature, dress for the weather, and help make a positive impact in one of Toronto’s most treasured ravines!
short_description:
Join the Highland Creek Lead Stewards for an evening of hands-on stewardship in the ravines and natural areas. 

Togethe

A spoken word poetry program for youth in the Jane and Finch community. Youth will learn the fundamentals of spoken word with Jayda Marley and Naiesha Marques and have the opportunity to present what they have learned at a final showcase for family and friends.

A spoken word poetry program for youth in the Jane and Finch community. Youth will learn the fundamentals of spoken word with Jayda Marley and Naiesha Marques and have the opportunity to present what they have learned at a final showcase for family and friends. 

A City of Toronto Cultural Hotspot Signature Project.

event_description:
In the chaos of urban life, we often forget to take a moment to breathe. Take in a moment of stillness, as we inviting visitors to stand beneath something that feels alive.

The outdoor installation, made from a suspended grid of copper leaves, reimagines the shelter of a forest canopy with each leaf individually cut and hung to form a floating canopy above. By day, the leaves catch the light and scatter soft shadows across the ground. By night, lighting transforms the installation, casting intricate patterns on surrounding surfaces and shifting the atmosphere of the space entirely. As wind moves through the piece, the leaves gently sway and rustle, adding a subtle layer of sound to the experience.

Responding to its surroundings and shifting with the light, weather and movement of people passing beneath it, this work offers a dynamic and reflective space in the heart of the city. 

Designed by RAW Works, with Roland Rom Colthoff, Suleman Khan, Elmira Yousefi and Aaron Hendershot.

event_description: Join the Ontario Society of Artists in honoring its Life Members, acknowledging their significant contributions to both the Society and the wider art community. These distinguished members actively teach, exhibit their work, sustain their artistic practices and generously volunteer their time. Representing diverse disciplines, including painting, sculpture, printmaking and photography, the Life Members embody the creative spirit and dedication that enrich the arts.
event_name: Celebrating the Art of the Ontario Society of Artists Life Members

event_description:
Step into the glow, we're back for the sixth year! 

This year, guests can explore the magic like never before with a brand-new layout that lets you move freely between the immersive light show and Pumpkinville at your own pace. Wander through the illuminated maze of over 1.5 million LED and RGB lights, then pop into a vibrant fall fair featuring all new glowing photo ops, installations, midway rides, carnival games, and over 15,000 pumpkins. With new scenes, dazzling photo moments, and an entirely transformed setup, this is not just a walk, it's an adventure!

event_description:
A site-specific mural by Winnipeg-based artist Anna Binta Diallo, exploring themes of time, memory and interdependence through the metaphor of fossils. Using silhouettes of human forms assembled from found images, Diallo creates a visual narrative on the interconnectedness of the past, present and future. 

Originally exhibited at the Musée d’art contemporain de Montréal, it invites viewers to reflect on how contemporary actions and objects will serve as relics for future generations, emphasizing the importance and responsibility of shaping collective heritage.
short_description: A site-specific mural by Winnipeg-based artist Anna Binta Diallo, exploring themes of time, memory and interdependence t

cost_notes: Ticket includes admission to the museum. ROM Members please contact for discount options.
event_description:
Famous adventuring heiress Indie Santiago was visiting an archaeological dig in the Accona desert when she went missing...along with a recently unearthed artifact! Scour ancient civilizations, unravel a tale through the ages and discover the secrets of the missing artifact to find out, where in the world is Indie Santiago? 

Please note at least one player per team must bring a phone with our scavenger hunt app downloaded for submitting answers and creative team photos and videos during the adventure, but the more the merrier!
event_name: The Adventures of Indie Santiago: A Mystery Scavenger Hunt
short_description: Famous adventuring heiress Indie Santiago was visiting an archaeological dig in the Accona desert when she went missing.
short_name: The Adventures of Indie Santiago: A Mystery Scavenger Hunt

event_description:
Curated by Mikinaak Migwans, Earthwork redefines a term that until now has referred to a type of artistic practice associated within the larger conceptual framework of land art. 

In this exhibition, Migwans shifts our understanding of earthwork to refer to a way of working, rather than the making of singular objects, reclaiming the art historical framing from an Indigenous perspective. It considers multiple layers of engagement with the land, including a history of land defense movements, medicine walks, and ancestral practices of prescribed burns, alongside contemporary art.

Featured artists include Michael Belmore, BUSH Gallery (Gabrielle L’Hirondelle Hill, Peter Morin, Tania Willard), Faye HeavyShield, Art Hunter, Alex Jacobs-Blum, Mike MacDonald, Lisa Myers, Edward Poitras, and Protect the Tract Collective.
event_name: Art Museum at the University of Toronto: Earthwork

event_description:
A ‘"Crossing" could be an intersection of ideas and viewpoints represented in the abstract, or the crossing of physical space via a road or bridge, or the crossing of an ocean towards a new life. 

It could mean crossing into a different emotional state, when inspired or uplifted, or even a new state of being in a different plane of existence.
short_description: A ‘"Crossing" could be an intersection of ideas and viewpoints represented in the abstract, or the crossing of physical

event_description:
The must-see event of the Halloween season is back! From the creators of the sold-out sensation, Tales of the Grotesque (2023 - 2024), comes a new anthology of gothic horror. Experience what critics call a “devilish delight!” With fresh characters, familiar tales, and unique terrors, we bring literature’s most depraved characters to life… and death.

After a lady of the night is murdered, a mad doctor strikes a pact with the Devil to raise her from the dead. But when he comes face-to-face with her killer at a masquerade, all hell breaks loose. Descend into madness with Victor Frankenstein, Henry Jekyll, and Dorian Gray as they discover the consequences of playing God and the monstrous repercussions when the Devil comes to collect. 

An immersive horror opera set within the oldest surviving building from the Town of York, we invite you to explore Victorian Toronto through the eyes of history’s most disturbed authors, though it might just cost your soul.
short_description: The must-see event of the Halloween season is back! From the creators of the sold-out sensation, Tales of the Grotesque

event_description:
Through the use of sculpture, photography, video, and installation, this exhibition is a blend of different people and perspectives forming a kind of visual and sonic cacophony. It’s a nod to global (or even galactic) unity, and to the idea that despite all the noise and division, we’re more alike than not. 

In her Canadian debut, Intergalactic Planetary brings together imagery and works inspired by cities including Shanghai, Chongqing, Berlin, Tokyo, Bangkok and locations across the United States. Snelling explains, “Through this work, I ask: how can we move beyond our fears, borders, and egos to become more humane? Perhaps by staying curious, open, and willing to see each other more fully, we can take a small step toward connection, and even a glimmer of peace for the future”.

Join us on Nuit Blanche to view the exhibition's works, while DJ beats set the mood with dynamic sounds and enjoy two exhibition-inspired cocktails-one coffee-based and the other with an intergalactic twist.
short_description: Through the use of sculpture, photography, video, and installation, this exhibition is a blend of different people and p

event_description:
You are invited to an afternoon of guided tours through some of Toronto’s most interesting galleries and artist-run centres. Explore the current exhibitions and learn about the artists and their work. 

Bring a friend, the more the merrier! We will be walking through all these galleries together as a group, starting at our first location - Patel Brown.
short_description: You are invited to an afternoon of guided tours through some of Toronto’s most interesting galleries and artist-run cent

event_description:
You are invited into the beating heart of contemporary craft and design, a space where tradition meets bold reinvention, and where the maker’s hand is ever-present. 

Through the exceptional work of our current Artists-in-Residence, this exhibition explores the enduring relevance of skilled making in a world dominated by speed, automation and disposability. 

We are a cornerstone of Canada’s craft landscape, a rare incubator where artists have the time, space and support to experiment, collaborate and grow their professional careers. From glass, metal and ceramics to textiles and contemporary design, the residents featured here are not only shaping objects – they are shaping culture.  

In this context, to “meet your maker” is to engage with the processes, politics and poetics of craft and design today. It’s a chance to stand face to face with emerging visionaries who transform raw mate
short_description: You are invited into the beating heart of contemporary craft and design, a space where tradition meets bold reinvention,

event_description:
A quiet lake in Ontario is making a lot of noise.

Sediments from the bottom of a small lake in Ontario are revealing a remarkable record of our impact on the planet.

Just outside Toronto, Ontario lies Crawford Lake, a significant site offering a unique, comprehensive 1,000-year record of human impacts - local, regional, and global.
short_description:

event_description:
Discover how homes shape identity through the Austin family story and contemporary art at Spadina Museum. Reimagine history, reframe home.

“Home at Spadina Museum” considers how people are influenced by their home. We look at those who make it a home and those who live in it are shaped by domestic spaces. Through interpretation of the Austin family and into contemporary art, we will analyze what makes a home. Re-Imagining the Historic House Museum: A Workplace for Women. 

Step into “Home at Spadina Museum” and explore how homes are shaped by the people who live and work in them. From the Austin family to contemporary art, discover untold stories of women’s labour, care, and community. Reimagine the historic house as both a home and a workplace.

As you explore the exhibition, we invite you to reflect: "What does home mean to you?"

We are grateful to our community partners, Augusto Bitter and the Women’s Art Association of Canada.
event_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Home at Spadina Museum

short_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Home at Spadina Museum

event_description:
The most talked about play of the decade.

Sharp, provocative, and wildly entertaining theatrical sensation that has sparked conversations from Broadway to London. Now making its Canadian premiere, this electrifying play by Jeremy O. Harris turns up the heat on love, race, and relationships in ways that are bold, unexpected, and impossible to forget.  

A daring, seductive, and razor-sharp satire, audiences will be on a journey where pleasure and history meet, flipping assumptions and igniting sparks along the way. It’s a show that’s as playfully cheeky as it is thought-provoking, designed to make you feel, think, and maybe even blush.

event_description:
Hear chilling and eerie tales on a lantern tour of Fort York and its historic surroundings. Learn about a haunted lighthouse and the bloody Battle of York. Explore the military burial ground. Tour the creepy shadows and 200-year-old buildings of Fort York at night and learn of the fort’s history and its many paranormal mysteries.

Recommended for ages 12 and up. Youth 12 to 16 must be accompanied by an adult. 

Part of the tour takes place outside, so please dress for the weather. The tour includes walking outside and in the dark, and crossing busy streets.
This program requires accessibility of stairs and uneven ground.
event_name: Fort York After Dark: Lantern Tours

event_description:
Hear chilling and eerie tales on a lantern tour of Fort York and its historic surroundings. Learn about a haunted lighthouse and the bloody Battle of York. Explore the military burial ground. Tour the creepy shadows and 200-year-old buildings of Fort York at night and learn of the fort’s history and its many paranormal mysteries.

Recommended for ages 12 and up. Youth 12 to 16 must be accompanied by an adult. 

Part of the tour takes place outside, so please dress for the weather. The tour includes walking outside and in the dark, and crossing busy streets.
This program requires accessibility of stairs and uneven ground.
event_name: Fort York After Dark: Lantern Tours
short_description: Hear chilling and eerie tales on a lantern tour of Fort York and its historic surroundings. Learn about a haunted lighth

Step into an immersive visual experience where material becomes memory, and memory becomes art. 

A compelling mixed media art exhibition that explores emotion, expression, and the sense of belonging through abstract and landscape works. From fragmented shorelines to colour-washed horizons and textured echoes of time, the exhibition invites viewers into a space of contemplation and connection, where personal and collective memories surface through layered materials and imaginative forms.

event_description:
Forget awkward dating apps and overpriced dinners, this show is the ultimate antidote to the dating blues. We're back with the ultimate interactive experience.

This fully improvised romantic comedy takes the quirks, crushes, and turn-ons of real audience members and spins them into a one-of-a-kind love story. You’ll hook up, break up, live the single life, and fall in love all over again without ever leaving your seat.

Directed by Paul Bates (The Second City, Dan For Mayor), this show boasts an all-star lineup of Toronto’s funniest comedians, including Christy Bruce (Schitt’s Creek), Alastair Forbes (Join Canada, Eh!), Natalie Metcalfe (The Second City), Aurora Browne (Baroness Von Sketch Show), Jan Caruana (Because News), Sharjil Rasool (Run the Burbs), and Kris Siddiqi (The Boys). With technical wizardry by Seann Murray, this show is a comedic rollercoaster you won’t want to miss.

event_description:
This  fall celebration combines the best of Oktoberfest and Pumpkinfest, creating the ultimate weekend of fun, flavor, and festivity for all! 

Experience thrilling midway rides like the Berry-Go-Round, Swing Carousel, and the Trackless Train. Raise your steins at the exclusive beer garden, and capture seasonal memories at the pumpkin patch. 

The weekend is packed with entertainment, starting with Hip-hop and Rap Battle Friday, then Battle of the Bands  with eight talented groups, capped off by a special performance from guest artist Jason Fernandez. Enjoy Family Day, featuring balloon artists, face painting, and kids’ shows. Sample and shop food and specialty vendors offering delicious eats, Christmas lanterns, décor, and unique gifts.
short_description: This  fall celebration combines the best of Oktoberfest and Pumpkinfest, creating the ultimate weekend of fun, flavor, a

event_description:
Guests of all ages are invited to enjoy a cozy, seasonal celebration that combines sustainability, creativity, and connection.

In exchange for a non-perishable food item or a monetary donation to the Daily Bread Food Bank, enjoy a seasonal coffee bar, mini pumpkin painting, live msuic and cozy lounge vigs and free portraits

This seasonal event brings together everything we love about autumn: cozy vibes, creativity, giving back, and community!
short_description: Guests of all ages are invited to enjoy a cozy, seasonal celebration that combines sustainability, creativity, and conne

event_description:
A site-specific mural by Winnipeg-based artist Anna Binta Diallo, exploring themes of time, memory and interdependence through the metaphor of fossils. Using silhouettes of human forms assembled from found images, Diallo creates a visual narrative on the interconnectedness of the past, present and future. 

Originally exhibited at the Musée d’art contemporain de Montréal, it invites viewers to reflect on how contemporary actions and objects will serve as relics for future generations, emphasizing the importance and responsibility of shaping collective heritage.
short_description: A site-specific mural by Winnipeg-based artist Anna Binta Diallo, exploring themes of time, memory and interdependence t

event_description:
Borders divide, the cosmos unites.

Canadian legend Robert Lepage returns to Canadian Stage after sold-out productions of 887 and Needles and Opium.

Set against the Cold War's fierce U.S.-Soviet rivalry, this gripping story explores the personal and political turmoil of an era defined by global tension with a uniquely Canadian perspective. Through the tale of two Quebec City brothers, Lepage's stunning use of multimedia and visual storytelling draws the audience into a world on the brink of change and portrays the impact of global conflict on the individual.
event_name: The Far Side of the Moon
short_description:
Borders divide, the cosmos unites.

Canadian legend Robert Lepage returns to Canadian Stage after sold-out productions o
short_name: The Far Side of the Moon

event_description:
In commemoration of the 80th anniversary of the end of World War II and the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. 

The series consists of 29 posters, headed by KAMEKURA Yūsaku’s masterpiece “Burning Butterflies” 1983, continued with an unbroken sequence of works of high artistic excellence. 

In addition, 49 posters will be displayed with global messages from our collection, and Toronto’s poster collection accompany the Hiroshima Appeals posters, focusing on the shared unique nature of their design creation in being non-commercial, abstract, conceptual, and reflecting on global issues and subjects.
event_name: Hiroshima Appeals: A Poster Exhibition of Global Messages
short_description: In commemoration of the 80th anniversary of the end of World War II and the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.
short_name: Hiroshima Appeals: A Poster Exhibition of Global Messages

event_description: Ten artists, two cultures, one vision. Five Atikamekw artists from Manawan, Quebec, and five African Francophone artists from the GTA come together to create ribbon skirts as art—expressions of land, culture, and connection to Turtle Island. Experience this powerful exhibition of identity and collaboration as part of free guided tours at Spadina museum.

event_description:
Beginning July 1st at Scarborough Museum, experience Washed Up by Hatecopy. The project captures the essence of liminal spaces that serve as cultural hubs for the South Asian immigrant communities, using the washing machine as a vessel to carry textiles that signify our roots and drawing visitors into an environment that intertwines the past, present, and future; acknowledging the dirty laundry of Canadian History and “Truth,” and reclaiming both seen and unseen spaces.

Maria Qamar (b. 1991) is a Toronto-based pop artist whose work is focused in the South Asian diaspora and immigrant communities and their cultural experiences. The work specializes in themes regarding feminism, social change, humour, pop culture, politics and romance. The artist has been recognized both nationally and internationally with exhibits and features in the Museum of Contemporary Arts, the National Arts Centre, Sotheby’s, Phillips Auction, and the AGO.
event_name: Washed Up: Pop-Up Installation at Scarborough Museum
short_description: Beginning July 1st at Scarborough Museum, experience Washed Up by Hatecopy. The project captures the essence of liminal
short_name: Washed Up: Pop-Up Installation at Scarborough Museum

event_description:
In the chaos of urban life, we often forget to take a moment to breathe. Take in a moment of stillness, as we inviting visitors to stand beneath something that feels alive.

The outdoor installation, made from a suspended grid of copper leaves, reimagines the shelter of a forest canopy with each leaf individually cut and hung to form a floating canopy above. By day, the leaves catch the light and scatter soft shadows across the ground. By night, lighting transforms the installation, casting intricate patterns on surrounding surfaces and shifting the atmosphere of the space entirely. As wind moves through the piece, the leaves gently sway and rustle, adding a subtle layer of sound to the experience.

Responding to its surroundings and shifting with the light, weather and movement of people passing beneath it, this work offers a dynamic and reflective space in the heart of the city. 

Designed by RAW Works, with Roland Rom Colthoff, Suleman Khan, Elmira Yousefi and Aaron Hendershot.

event_description:
Celebrating art, nature and community.

Featuring over 70 original artworks created outdoors at Toronto Botanical Garden and Edwards Gardens, this curated, site-specific show invites visitors to experience the gardens through the eyes of the artists who paint here, capturing moments of light, movement, and the essence of the natural world.
event_name: Essence of the Garden: Plein Air Art Exhibition and Sale

event_name: Essence of the Garden: Plein Air Art Exhibition and Sale

Celebrating art, nature and community.

Featuring over 70 original artworks created outdoors at Toronto Botanical Garden

short_description: Join us at Montgomery's Inn for the Indoor Farmers' Market Season. Experience the best of local and farm fresh food, fam

event_description:
The must-see event of the Halloween season is back! From the creators of the sold-out sensation, Tales of the Grotesque (2023 - 2024), comes a new anthology of gothic horror. Experience what critics call a “devilish delight!” With fresh characters, familiar tales, and unique terrors, we bring literature’s most depraved characters to life… and death.

After a lady of the night is murdered, a mad doctor strikes a pact with the Devil to raise her from the dead. But when he comes face-to-face with her killer at a masquerade, all hell breaks loose. Descend into madness with Victor Frankenstein, Henry Jekyll, and Dorian Gray as they discover the consequences of playing God and the monstrous repercussions when the Devil comes to collect. 

An immersive horror opera set within the oldest surviving building from the Town of York, we invite you to explore Victorian Toronto through the eyes of history’s most disturbed authors, though it might just cost your soul.
short_description: The must-see event of the Halloween season is back! From the creators of the sold-out sensation, Tales of the Grotesque

event_description:
Renowned conductor Franz Welser-Möst, celebrated worldwide for leading the Vienna Philharmonic’s iconic New Year’s Concert, takes the podium for this unforgettable program. 

Spotlight Artist Bruce Liu brings Mozart’s spirited Piano Concerto No. 23 to vibrant life, and Richard Strauss’ radiant Der Rosenkavalier, a bittersweet tale of love and loss, warms hearts with its enchanting waltzes and tender melodies.

short_name: We were Promised Prosperity... Instead we got Spam Art Exhib

event_description:
Through the use of sculpture, photography, video, and installation, this exhibition is a blend of different people and perspectives forming a kind of visual and sonic cacophony. It’s a nod to global (or even galactic) unity, and to the idea that despite all the noise and division, we’re more alike than not. 

In her Canadian debut, Intergalactic Planetary brings together imagery and works inspired by cities including Shanghai, Chongqing, Berlin, Tokyo, Bangkok and locations across the United States. Snelling explains, “Through this work, I ask: how can we move beyond our fears, borders, and egos to become more humane? Perhaps by staying curious, open, and willing to see each other more fully, we can take a small step toward connection, and even a glimmer of peace for the future”.

Join us on Nuit Blanche to view the exhibition's works, while DJ beats set the mood with dynamic sounds and enjoy two exhibition-inspired cocktails-one coffee-based and the other with an intergalactic twist.
short_description: Through the use of sculpture, photography, video, and installation, this exhibition is a blend of different people and p

event_description:
In the chaos of urban life, we often forget to take a moment to breathe. Take in a moment of stillness, as we inviting visitors to stand beneath something that feels alive.

The outdoor installation, made from a suspended grid of copper leaves, reimagines the shelter of a forest canopy with each leaf individually cut and hung to form a floating canopy above. By day, the leaves catch the light and scatter soft shadows across the ground. By night, lighting transforms the installation, casting intricate patterns on surrounding surfaces and shifting the atmosphere of the space entirely. As wind moves through the piece, the leaves gently sway and rustle, adding a subtle layer of sound to the experience.

Responding to its surroundings and shifting with the light, weather and movement of people passing beneath it, this work offers a dynamic and reflective space in the heart of the city. 

Designed by RAW Works, with Roland Rom Colthoff, Suleman Khan, Elmira Yousefi and Aaron Hendershot.

event_description:
We are pleased to bring you the fifth annual Greek International Film Festival Tour of Canada (GIFFT).

This is a Canadian national film festival that will take place in 11 Canadian cities simultaneously. Those cities include: Toronto, Vancouver, Edmonton, Calgary, Regina, Winnipeg, London (Ontario), Hamilton/Niagara, Ottawa, and Halifax.

GIFFT is a showcase and celebration of Greek cinema and filmmakers of Greek Heritage. This festival will provide exciting platform for directors, writers, producers, and actors of Greek Heritage to showcase their exceptional art across Canada.
short_description:
We are pleased to bring you the fifth annual Greek International Film Festival Tour of Canada (GIFFT).

This is a Canadi

event_description:
Step back in time with a free visit to Spadina Museum, beautifully decorated for a 1920s Christmas. Visitors can enjoy the opulent holiday décor and period ambiance that once filled the home of the wealthy Austin family. Twinkling lights, antique ornaments, and rooms set for a classic Jazz Age celebration bring the spirit of the season to life.
As you stroll through the mansion, interpretive displays offer insights into the lavish holiday traditions of Toronto’s elite in the 1920s. In contrast, visitors will also learn about the experiences of the city’s less fortunate citizens during the same era—those who faced poverty, unemployment, and food insecurity during a time of great social and economic change.
From a grand dining room prepared for a festive feast to modest depictions of how the servants of the household marked the holidays, the experience paints a full picture of a Toronto Christmas in the early 20th century.
event_name: Jazz Age Christmas at Spadina Museum

short_name: Jazz Age Christmas at Spadina Museum

event_description:
Step into the glow, we're back for the sixth year! 

This year, guests can explore the magic like never before with a brand-new layout that lets you move freely between the immersive light show and Pumpkinville at your own pace. Wander through the illuminated maze of over 1.5 million LED and RGB lights, then pop into a vibrant fall fair featuring all new glowing photo ops, installations, midway rides, carnival games, and over 15,000 pumpkins. With new scenes, dazzling photo moments, and an entirely transformed setup, this is not just a walk, it's an adventure!

event_description: Grate, pound and sift sugar and spices in the historic kitchen at Fort York National Historic Site and make an 1831 Gingerbread recipe to taste and take home to enjoy for the holidays. Share stories about ingredients and their histories, and be inspired by renewed gingerbread recipes made by Fort York's Chef in Residence, Jean Régis Raynaud.

short_description: The weather outside is frightful! Light up your winter with this delightful comedy spectacular brimming with glee and ho

event_description:
Beginning July 1st at Scarborough Museum, experience Washed Up by Hatecopy. The project captures the essence of liminal spaces that serve as cultural hubs for the South Asian immigrant communities, using the washing machine as a vessel to carry textiles that signify our roots and drawing visitors into an environment that intertwines the past, present, and future; acknowledging the dirty laundry of Canadian History and “Truth,” and reclaiming both seen and unseen spaces.

Maria Qamar (b. 1991) is a Toronto-based pop artist whose work is focused in the South Asian diaspora and immigrant communities and their cultural experiences. The work specializes in themes regarding feminism, social change, humour, pop culture, politics and romance. The artist has been recognized both nationally and internationally with exhibits and features in the Museum of Contemporary Arts, the National Arts Centre, Sotheby’s, Phillips Auction, and the AGO.
event_name: Washed Up: Pop-Up Installation at Scarborough Museum

cost_notes: General admission (including touring the museum buildings, food sampling and craft activities) is free / does not require advanced tickets. Some workshops are ticketed - see additional listings for further details.
event_description:
Join Scarborough Museum for a Season of Celebration! Embrace the spirit of light, love, and joy through a series of family-friendly activities centered on food, culture, and storytelling.  

Enjoy gingerbread decorating, family-friendly winter crafts and weekly workshops led by guest facilitators, including chair yoga, henna and more! See additional listings for more details. 

Community Feature: Sample a rotating selection of warm drinks and finger foods from around the world, curated by the Scarborough Museum Youth Collective and participants of Scarborough Museum’s Newcomer Storytelling Circles. Try something new or enjoy an old favourite, learn more about the stories behind these sips and bites, and share your own stories of light and warmth in our community jar!  

Treats will be available first come-first served, while quantities last.
event_name: Season of Celebration at Scarborough Museum
short_description: Join Scarborough Museum for a Season of Celebration! Embrace the spirit of light, love, and joy through a series of fami
short_name: Season of Celebration at Scarborough Museum

The weather outside is frightful! Light up your winter with this delightful comedy spectacular brimming with glee and holiday cheer! 

Enjoy a merry mix of classic sketches from our celebrated archives, hilarious new material, and the uproarious improv antics that have made us legendary. It’s a perfect way to add laughter and joy to your holiday season!

cost_notes: General admission (including touring the museum buildings, food sampling and craft activities) is free / does not require advanced tickets. Some workshops are ticketed - see additional listings for further details.
event_description:
Join Scarborough Museum for a Season of Celebration! Embrace the spirit of light, love, and joy through a series of family-friendly activities centered on food, culture, and storytelling.  

Enjoy gingerbread decorating, family-friendly winter crafts and weekly workshops led by guest facilitators, including chair yoga, henna and more! See additional listings for more details. 

Community Feature: Sample a rotating selection of warm drinks and finger foods from around the world, curated by the Scarborough Museum Youth Collective and participants of Scarborough Museum’s Newcomer Storytelling Circles. Try something new or enjoy an old favourite, learn more about the stories behind these sips and bites, and share your own stories of light and warmth in our community jar!  

Treats will be available first come-first served, while quantities last.
event_name: Season of Celebration at Scarborough Museum

event_description:
Photography omes alive with dance, music, and spoken word performances. Nine photographic artists join together with professionals in the fields of dance, poetry, drama, and music to present an afternoon of visual art with Ekphrasis performances in response to the photographs. 

Photographic artists are Linda Briskin, Brianna Caryll, Lucie Collins, Martha Davis, Vivian East, Kye Marshall, Jana Skarecky, Patricia Stamp, and Henrietta Walmark.

Performers responding to the visual works are dancer Brianna Clarke, musicians Taivi Alexander, Kye Marshall and Jana Skarecky, dramatists Angie Littlefield and Annie Rosenberg and poets Kate Marshall Flaherty, Bianca Lakoseljac, JC Sulzenko and Donna Wootton.

event_description:
Join Jane Finch Centre's Artists-in-Residence, Taejah Daniel (Coach Milly), Vanna Nguyen and Rod Osei-Nuako (Reezy) for an outdoor art installation at Corner Commons. This Artist-in-Residence is held within Invitations to Better Worlds project and is a collaboration with the Department of Imaginary Affairs and Jane/Finch Centre. Through their residencies, the artists have brought to life their interpretations of a collective vision for better worlds for Jane and Finch. This project is an emergence of community engagement, storytelling, collective liberation, foresight and art. It is a practice in believing better worlds are possible.

A City of Toronto Cultural Hotspot Signature Project.
event_name: Invitations to Better Worlds: Artist Showcase + Meet & Greet
short_description: Join Jane Finch Centre's Artists-in-Residence, Taejah Daniel (Coach Milly), Vanna Nguyen and Rod Osei-Nuako (Reezy) for
short_name: Invitations to Better Worlds: Artist Showcase + Meet & Greet

event_description:
The Southern Netherlands, better known today as Flanders, was home to revolutionary artists. 

These extraordinary painters found new ways to depict reality, portray humanity, and tell stories that created parallels to their world then and to our world today. This large-scale exhibition, featuring over 80 stunning art works and objects, medieval, renaissance, baroque paintings, sculptures and more, offering a doorway to art between 1400 to 1700. 

The exhibition's unique presentation introduces the visitor, through these rare, extraordinary artworks, to stories of enterprising townspeople, prosperous cities, and an ever-developing society.
event_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Masterworks

event_description:
Explore the timeless interiors of Old City Hall and marvel at the grand staircase, stunning murals, and the historic former City Council Chamber — each space a witness to Toronto’s past. Enjoy its Romanesque Revival architecture, historic courtrooms and intricate iron finishings. Completed in 1899 and designed by architect E.J. Lennox, the building served as the city's municipal hub for more than 60 years.

Click on the event website link under contact information to access an audio tour.

event_description:
Source Canada is a new national summit to help large Canadian enterprises buy more Canadian technology. With Canada’s economic future at stake, procurement is more than a transaction — it’s an investment in our next generation of world-class companies.
On October 22, 2025, tech CEOs and corporate leaders will gather in Toronto for a first-of-its-kind trade mission, with curated 1:1 meetings, closed-door briefings, and practical discussions between buyers and builders. 
The City of Toronto is proud to support this important event. Tickets for startups and corporate buyers are available at www.sourcecan.ca

event_description: Join the Ontario Society of Artists in honoring its Life Members, acknowledging their significant contributions to both the Society and the wider art community. These distinguished members actively teach, exhibit their work, sustain their artistic practices and generously volunteer their time. Representing diverse disciplines, including painting, sculpture, printmaking and photography, the Life Members embody the creative spirit and dedication that enrich the arts.
event_name: Celebrating the Art of the Ontario Society of Artists Life Members

event_description:
You are invited into the beating heart of contemporary craft and design, a space where tradition meets bold reinvention, and where the maker’s hand is ever-present. 

Through the exceptional work of our current Artists-in-Residence, this exhibition explores the enduring relevance of skilled making in a world dominated by speed, automation and disposability. 

We are a cornerstone of Canada’s craft landscape, a rare incubator where artists have the time, space and support to experiment, collaborate and grow their professional careers. From glass, metal and ceramics to textiles and contemporary design, the residents featured here are not only shaping objects – they are shaping culture.  

In this context, to “meet your maker” is to engage with the processes, politics and poetics of craft and design today. It’s a chance to stand face to face with emerging visionaries who transform raw mate
short_description: You are invited into the beating heart of contemporary craft and design, a space where tradition meets bold reinvention,

event_description: An annual cultural event that celebrates the Swahili language and the diverse heritage of East African communities. The festival is organized by the Swahili Cultural Centre and provides a platform for people to experience Swahili culture through music, food, fashion, art and more.

event_description:
We’re presenting another all-night art experience to our East Toronto communities!

With a focus on different languages, cultures, stories and ideas of the neighbourhood not yet explored or platformed. You are invited to join us and enjoy the return of our IN VIEW series, an impressive storefront gallery exhibition; stop into an all-night forest-themed Silent Disco in collaboration with Native Women in the Arts.

event_description:
What makes for a delightful picnic? Food and drink? Poetry? Music? 

Immerse yourself into the pleasures, pastimes, and artistic heritage of Iran during the Safavid dynasty (1501-1736). A royal picnic, depicted on a large, treasured tile arch from the collections, is complemented by exceptional objects from the period.

event_description:
This is a contemporary form of environmental art created by artists who are  concerned about reducing waste, recycling, and making the world a better place, while raising awareness about environmental changes.

 It aims to showcases the beauty and creativity of using recycled, environmentally friendly or sustainable materials to create phenomenal artwork, using water-based paints, natural pigments and recycled materials to name a few elements. lt is art that advocates for the planet, catering to all ages and present in various mediums, including paintings, sculptures or fashion.

Presenting our second annual art exhibition, we will be utilizing selected artists to mentor African and Caribbean communities on the positioning of multicultural history and art within the Canadian cultural landscape.

event_description: Join us on October 18 at Harbourfront Centre for an insightful curated conversation between Malene Djenaba Barnett and Toronto History Museum's chief curator Tara Chadwick. The conversation will explore complex themes of home, identity, and artistic practice, weaving together personal and collective experiences in a compelling dialogue. Even more, join Malene in a 3 hour clay tile workshop and craft kinship with your own artistic vision.

Welcome to our inaugural fall-inspired event!

Celebrate creativity, culture and community on the waterfront through art, food, entertainment and more!
 
Enjoy spectacular public art installations on and off the water, harvest-themed food and drink markets, live music and dance performances, a sustainable makers market, illuminating boat tours and more.

event_description:
A hilarious immersive Broadway-style show that blends your favourite holiday movie tropes with high-octane pop showtunes. 

Directed by Tim Drucker of Friends Parody Musical, Trixie and Katya LIVE and choreographed by Brooke Engen of Hairspray, Beetlejuice, Rock of Ages, with additional creatives to be announced. 

Be amongst the first to see it!
short_description: A hilarious immersive Broadway-style show that blends your favourite holiday movie tropes with high-octane pop showtunes

event_description:
Step back in time with a free visit to Spadina Museum, beautifully decorated for a 1920s Christmas. Visitors can enjoy the opulent holiday décor and period ambiance that once filled the home of the wealthy Austin family. Twinkling lights, antique ornaments, and rooms set for a classic Jazz Age celebration bring the spirit of the season to life.
As you stroll through the mansion, interpretive displays offer insights into the lavish holiday traditions of Toronto’s elite in the 1920s. In contrast, visitors will also learn about the experiences of the city’s less fortunate citizens during the same era—those who faced poverty, unemployment, and food insecurity during a time of great social and economic change.
From a grand dining room prepared for a festive feast to modest depictions of how the servants of the household marked the holidays, the experience paints a full picture of a Toronto Christmas in the early 20th century.
event_name: Jazz Age Christmas at Spadina Museum

short_name: Jazz Age Christmas at Spadina Museum

event_description:
Join Scarborough Museum for Halloween-themed fun on weekends in October! Enjoy a warm drink from the museum's kitchens, then join in on family-friendly Halloween-themed crafts, games and activities all month long. Decorate chilling cupcakes, and spark your imagination with paper crafts, a scavenger hunt, and more! 

Community Feature: sample a rotating selection of sweet treats from across the globe, curated by the Scarborough Museum Youth Collective. Try something new or enjoy an old favourite, learn more about the stories behind these sweets, and share your own sweet stories in our community jar! 

Treats will be available first come-first served, while quantities last.
short_description: Join Scarborough Museum for Halloween-themed fun on weekends in October! Enjoy a warm drink from the museum's kitchens,

event_description: Introducing “Hidden Toronto” – the new light-hearted walking tour from the creators of The Haunted Walk that’s gonna have you chuckling with laughter and shaking your head in disbelief. Join our crew of storytelling guides as we take you on a 90-minute adventure through the hidden side of Toronto. From movie mistakes to our infamous clown riot, these fun tales of mischief and mayhem make up the fascinating story of our city. Guffaw and gasp through the city’s streets as our fun and engaging tour guides spill the beans on those little-known stories and secrets that define Toronto’s hidden personality. “Hidden Toronto” is a fun and engaging good-natured adventure, perfect for first-time visitors and locals alike.
short_description: Introducing “Hidden Toronto” – the new light-hearted walking tour from the creators of The Haunted Walk that’s gonna hav

event_description:
Join us for a chilling tour at Colborne Lodge in High Park. 

Visit the gravesite of John and Jemima Howard. Explore ideas about death and the afterlife from the 1800s and hear true tales of paranormal activities. Experience some of the museum’s dark stories if you dare! 

A portion of this event is outside so please dress accordingly. 
Recommended for ages 12 and up. Youth 12-16 must be accompanied by an adult.
event_name: After Dark Tours: The Unexplained at Colborne Lodge

event_description:
Step into the glow, we're back for the sixth year! 

This year, guests can explore the magic like never before with a brand-new layout that lets you move freely between the immersive light show and Pumpkinville at your own pace. Wander through the illuminated maze of over 1.5 million LED and RGB lights, then pop into a vibrant fall fair featuring all new glowing photo ops, installations, midway rides, carnival games, and over 15,000 pumpkins. With new scenes, dazzling photo moments, and an entirely transformed setup, this is not just a walk, it's an adventure!

event_description:
This family-friendly exhibition invites you to uncover fresh perspectives, groundbreaking research and the astounding diversity of this ancient group of fishes.

Visitors will delve into the anatomy, behaviour, and history of sharks, from familiar favourites like tiger sharks and great whites to lesser-known species like the dwarf lanternshark—a tiny, light-producing marvel small enough to hold in your hand.

Through dozens of interactives and life-sized models, including a life-size head of the huge extinct Megalodon, join us for a unique look at these magnificent creatures, their habitats, hunting techniques, and the conservation threats that they face.

event_description:
Renowned conductor Franz Welser-Möst, celebrated worldwide for leading the Vienna Philharmonic’s iconic New Year’s Concert, takes the podium for this unforgettable program. 

Spotlight Artist Bruce Liu brings Mozart’s spirited Piano Concerto No. 23 to vibrant life, and Richard Strauss’ radiant Der Rosenkavalier, a bittersweet tale of love and loss, warms hearts with its enchanting waltzes and tender melodies.
short_description: Renowned conductor Franz Welser-Möst, celebrated worldwide for leading the Vienna Philharmonic’s iconic New Year’s Conce

event_description: Take a break in Old City Hall’s open-air courtyard — a hidden oasis in the heart of downtown. Bring your lunch, meet up with friends or simply enjoy the peaceful surroundings and heritage architecture. While you're here, look up to spot the clock tower's four gargoyles — part of the original 1899 design and removed in 1938 and reinstalled in 2002 using modern materials.

event_description:
Explore the trees and green spaces around the Dufferin St. Clair branch with City of Toronto Urban Forestry staff. Take a guided neighbourhood walk to learn how to identify local tree species and understand their role in the urban environment, from cultural to ecological benefits.

Children under 12 must be accompanied by a parent/caregiver. Please note that the tour will start and end at the library branch and will be guided by the City of Toronto Urban Forestry staff. There may be uneven, unpaved surfaces along the route outside and around the neighbourhood. 

Please dress and prepare accordingly for this outdoor program (e.g. gloves/mittens, hats, sunscreen, water, comfortable shoes). This program takes place rain or shine. In the event of severe inclement weather, please register with the branch to be notified of an alternative date.Registration is required. Please contact the branch by phone or in person to register.
event_name: Trees Around the Branch Tour at Dufferin/St. Clair Library
short_description: Explore the trees and green spaces around the Dufferin St. Clair branch with City of Toronto Urban Forestry staff. Take
short_name: Trees Around the Branch Tour at Dufferin/St. Clair Library

event_description:
Kalos is drawn to water. 

Every performance is like stepping into a river, they never play a song the same way twice. They make music inspired by the maritime traditions of Scotland, Ireland, Scandinavia and North America. Their album titles "Harbour" and "Headland", honor the meeting point between the land and sea and they sing songs about shorelines, seafarers and drownings. 

They revel in the driving danceability of Irish tunes, but also take inspiration from the pastoral melodies and naturalistic metaphors of Scottish music. But while the music they write is forged in tradition, it is nonetheless cast and tempered in new and unexpected ways.

Every performance is like stepping into a river, they never play a song the same way twice. T

event_description:
You are invited into the beating heart of contemporary craft and design, a space where tradition meets bold reinvention, and where the maker’s hand is ever-present. 

Through the exceptional work of our current Artists-in-Residence, this exhibition explores the enduring relevance of skilled making in a world dominated by speed, automation and disposability. 

We are a cornerstone of Canada’s craft landscape, a rare incubator where artists have the time, space and support to experiment, collaborate and grow their professional careers. From glass, metal and ceramics to textiles and contemporary design, the residents featured here are not only shaping objects – they are shaping culture.  

In this context, to “meet your maker” is to engage with the processes, politics and poetics of craft and design today. It’s a chance to stand face to face with emerging visionaries who transform raw mate
short_description: You are invited into the beating heart of contemporary craft and design, a space where tradition meets bold reinvention,

event_description:
Beirut, 1978 and Beirut, 2018. 

Memory is a funny thing, so quiet if left undisturbed, beyond space and time.

Two love stories twist together in two Beiruts riven by time and conflict. In 1978, two women share spit on the ends of cigarettes and yearn for tenderness under the tumult of war. In 2018, a foreigner and a local flirt over vodka sodas as their contradictions collect like condensation on the sides of their glasses. 

Poetic realism braids past and present into the green line of vegetation that bisected the concrete of Lebanon’s capital during the civil war. Named a finalist for the 2024 Governor General's Literary Award, unearths queer history that has always been there, whether our ancestors wanted it to be inherited or erased.

event_description:
A quiet lake in Ontario is making a lot of noise.

Sediments from the bottom of a small lake in Ontario are revealing a remarkable record of our impact on the planet.

Just outside Toronto, Ontario lies Crawford Lake, a significant site offering a unique, comprehensive 1,000-year record of human impacts - local, regional, and global.

The Toronto Music Garden will be transformed into a celebration of sound and light during a series of free live performances featuring Land of Talk, Sean Jones, Soulpepper Academy, Begonia, Amanda Rheaume, The North Sound, Charlotte Cornfield, Tanika Charles and The Recipee Band complemented by glowing interactive lights.

Bring a blanket or lawn chair, settle in by the water, and take in the magic of music, lights and community at the waterfront.

Part of Water/Fall Festival.

event_description:
What makes for a delightful picnic? Food and drink? Poetry? Music? 

Immerse yourself into the pleasures, pastimes, and artistic heritage of Iran during the Safavid dynasty (1501-1736). A royal picnic, depicted on a large, treasured tile arch from the collections, is complemented by exceptional objects from the period.

event_description:
Photography omes alive with dance, music, and spoken word performances. Nine photographic artists join together with professionals in the fields of dance, poetry, drama, and music to present an afternoon of visual art with Ekphrasis performances in response to the photographs. 

Photographic artists are Linda Briskin, Brianna Caryll, Lucie Collins, Martha Davis, Vivian East, Kye Marshall, Jana Skarecky, Patricia Stamp, and Henrietta Walmark.

Performers responding to the visual works are dancer Brianna Clarke, musicians Taivi Alexander, Kye Marshall and Jana Skarecky, dramatists Angie Littlefield and Annie Rosenberg and poets Kate Marshall Flaherty, Bianca Lakoseljac, JC Sulzenko and Donna Wootton.

Photography omes alive with dance, music, and spoken word performances. Nine photographic artists join together with professionals in the fields of dance, poetry, drama, and music to present an afternoon of visual art with Ekphrasis performances in response to the photographs. 

Photographic artists are Linda Briskin, Brianna Caryll, Lucie Collins, Martha Davis, Vivian East, Kye Marshall, Jana Skarecky, Patricia Stamp, and Henrietta Walmark.

Performers responding to the visual works are dancer Brianna Clarke, musicians Taivi Alexander, Kye Marshall and Jana Skarecky, dramatists Angie Littlefield and Annie Rosenberg and poets Kate Marshall Flaherty, Bianca Lakoseljac, JC Sulzenko and Donna Wootton.

event_description:
This family-friendly exhibition invites you to uncover fresh perspectives, groundbreaking research and the astounding diversity of this ancient group of fishes.

Visitors will delve into the anatomy, behaviour, and history of sharks, from familiar favourites like tiger sharks and great whites to lesser-known species like the dwarf lanternshark—a tiny, light-producing marvel small enough to hold in your hand.

Through dozens of interactives and life-sized models, including a life-size head of the huge extinct Megalodon, join us for a unique look at these magnificent creatures, their habitats, hunting techniques, and the conservation threats that they face.

Hidden throughout our miniature world are spooky little Halloween scenes, each with a letter next to it. Collect all the letters, unscramble the riddle and unlock the final phrase. It’s an adventure full of tiny chills, big thrills and mysterious fun for everyone.

Are you ready to begin the hunt?

event_description:
A ‘"Crossing" could be an intersection of ideas and viewpoints represented in the abstract, or the crossing of physical space via a road or bridge, or the crossing of an ocean towards a new life. 

It could mean crossing into a different emotional state, when inspired or uplifted, or even a new state of being in a different plane of existence.

event_description:
Making its Canadian debut, we are excited to present the animated classic on the big screen in its entirety, accompanied by a live orchestra performing composer Randy Newman’s vibrant score note-for-note. The perfect way to experience the original ahead of next year’s Toy Story 5! 

Featuring the FILMharmonique Orchestra, Canada's premier orchestra dedicated to film concerts. Conductor: Francis Choinière.

Presentation licenced by Disney Concerts.

event_description:
Making Home in Scarborough is a vibrant pop-up installation celebrating memory, identity, and belonging through cultural traditions and objects we hold dear to our hearts in generations past, present and future. 
 

Co-created through conversation and care, community members were invited to share a meaningful object, rooted in a heartfelt story. All speak to how home is made not only in buildings or borders, but in the places, people, and practices that give life meaning. 
 
As you explore the exhibition, we invite you to reflect: "What does home mean to you?" If you live in Scarborough, "What does Making Home in Scarborough Mean to you?" 
 
We are grateful for our community collaborators: Native Child and Family Services / Scarborough Child & Family Life Centre, Malvern Family Resource Centre, TDSB Newcomer Services (Malvern), Toby's Place, Scarborough Museum Youth Collective and Change Made.
event_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Making Home in Scarborough at Scarborough Museum
short_description: Making Home in Scarborough is a vibrant pop-up installation celebrating memory, identity, and belonging through cultural
short_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Making Home in Scarborough at Scarborough Mu

event_description:
Experience a guided sound journey that sparks joy, connection and play through music and movement. Participants will wear headphones and enter a soundscape that blends music, story and guided exploration, inviting you to listen, move and feel together.  

In an era marked by disconnection, loneliness and social division, Reset offers a counter-experience: one rooted in curiosity, shared presence and delight. The work draws on traditions of street theatre, sound art and community ritual to create a space where strangers can become participants, and where every day public space is transformed into a site of collective effervescence.

event_description:
Explore the trees and green spaces around the Sanderson library branch with City of Toronto Urban Forestry staff. Take a guided neighbourhood walk to learn how to identify local tree species and understand their role in the urban environment, from cultural to ecological benefits.
Children under 12 must be accompanied by a parent/caregiver. Please note that the tour will start and end at the library branch and will be guided by the City of Toronto Urban Forestry staff. There may be uneven, unpaved surfaces along the route outside and around the neighbourhood. Please dress and prepare accordingly for this outdoor program (e.g. gloves/mittens, hats, sunscreen, water, comfortable shoes). 
This program takes place rain or shine. In the event of severe inclement weather, please register with the branch to be notified of an alternative date.
Registration is required. Please contact the branch by phone or in person to register.
event_name: Trees  Around the Branch Tour at Sanderson Library
short_description: Explore the trees and green spaces around the Sanderson library branch with City of Toronto Urban Forestry staff. Take a
short_name: Trees  Around the Branch Tour at Sanderson Library

event_description:
In the chaos of urban life, we often forget to take a moment to breathe. Take in a moment of stillness, as we inviting visitors to stand beneath something that feels alive.

The outdoor installation, made from a suspended grid of copper leaves, reimagines the shelter of a forest canopy with each leaf individually cut and hung to form a floating canopy above. By day, the leaves catch the light and scatter soft shadows across the ground. By night, lighting transforms the installation, casting intricate patterns on surrounding surfaces and shifting the atmosphere of the space entirely. As wind moves through the piece, the leaves gently sway and rustle, adding a subtle layer of sound to the experience.

Responding to its surroundings and shifting with the light, weather and movement of people passing beneath it, this work offers a dynamic and reflective space in the heart of the city. 

Designed by RAW Works, with Roland Rom Colthoff, Suleman Khan, Elmira Yousefi and Aaron Hendershot.
short_description: In the chaos of urban life, we often forget to take a moment to breathe. Take in a moment of stillness, as we inviting v

event_description:
What does home mean to you? Discover rarely seen artifacts from the City’s collections and items from community members. Explore the many ways we define, create and carry home with us. From a First World War soldier’s return ticket home to a precious family object stewarded by multiple generations, encounter belongings, voices and stories of Toronto artists, makers, entrepreneurs and community leaders as they share their unique perspectives on belonging, identity and place. These powerful objects offer fresh, heartfelt perspectives on what it means to find, make or remember home.

At Home in Toronto includes the artworks of Rebecca Baird, Carl Beam, Fred Hagan, Robert Houle, Luis Jacob, Kit Li, Raoul Olou, Yasmine Louis and Natalie Wood, as well as loaned works by local artists Doug Brown and Frantz Brent-Harris.
short_description: What does home mean to you? Discover rarely seen artifacts from the City’s collections and items from community members.

event_description:
This pop-up installation explores the compelling stories and experiences of Toronto’s diverse communities who have fought for their sense of home, belonging and identity during periods of conflict and peace. 

This installation is created in partnership with the Toronto Metropolitan University's Masters of Digital Media program.

event_description:
Step back in time with a free visit to Spadina Museum, beautifully decorated for a 1920s Christmas. Visitors can enjoy the opulent holiday décor and period ambiance that once filled the home of the wealthy Austin family. Twinkling lights, antique ornaments, and rooms set for a classic Jazz Age celebration bring the spirit of the season to life.
As you stroll through the mansion, interpretive displays offer insights into the lavish holiday traditions of Toronto’s elite in the 1920s. In contrast, visitors will also learn about the experiences of the city’s less fortunate citizens during the same era—those who faced poverty, unemployment, and food insecurity during a time of great social and economic change.
From a grand dining room prepared for a festive feast to modest depictions of how the servants of the household marked the holidays, the experience paints a full picture of a Toronto Christmas in the early 20th century.
event_name: Jazz Age Christmas at Spadina Museum

short_name: Jazz Age Christmas at Spadina Museum

event_description:
The Southern Netherlands, better known today as Flanders, was home to revolutionary artists. 

These extraordinary painters found new ways to depict reality, portray humanity, and tell stories that created parallels to their world then and to our world today. This large-scale exhibition, featuring over 80 stunning art works and objects, medieval, renaissance, baroque paintings, sculptures and more, offering a doorway to art between 1400 to 1700. 

The exhibition's unique presentation introduces the visitor, through these rare, extraordinary artworks, to stories of enterprising townspeople, prosperous cities, and an ever-developing society.
event_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Masterworks

short_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Mast

event_description:
Experience our world in vivid detail and see some of the most unusual species and their habitats in ways you never imagined. 

Each back-lit photograph provides exquisite quality and depth. From the photographer's eye to the camera's lens, viewers become witnesses to the lives animals live and the challenges they face. 

Emotive, surprising, and sometimes sobering, glimpses of life on our planet are showcased through exceptional talent, technical expertise, and perfectly captured moments.
event_name: Wildlife Photographer of the Year Exhibition

short_name: Wildlife Photographer of the Year Exhibition

event_description:
In commemoration of the 80th anniversary of the end of World War II and the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. 

The series consists of 29 posters, headed by KAMEKURA Yūsaku’s masterpiece “Burning Butterflies” 1983, continued with an unbroken sequence of works of high artistic excellence. 

In addition, 49 posters will be displayed with global messages from our collection, and Toronto’s poster collection accompany the Hiroshima Appeals posters, focusing on the shared unique nature of their design creation in being non-commercial, abstract, conceptual, and reflecting on global issues and subjects.
event_name: Hiroshima Appeals: A Poster Exhibition of Global Messages
short_description: In commemoration of the 80th anniversary of the end of World War II and the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.
short_name: Hiroshima Appeals: A Poster Exhibition of Global Messages

event_description:
What makes for a delightful picnic? Food and drink? Poetry? Music? 

Immerse yourself into the pleasures, pastimes, and artistic heritage of Iran during the Safavid dynasty (1501-1736). A royal picnic, depicted on a large, treasured tile arch from the collections, is complemented by exceptional objects from the period.

In addition, 49 posters will be displayed with global messages from our collection, and Toronto’s poster collection accompany the Hiroshima Appeals posters, focusing on the shared unique nature of their design creation in being non-commercial, abstract, conceptual, and reflecting on global issues and subjects.
event_name: Hiroshima Appeals: A Poster Exhibition of Global Messages
short_description: In commemoration of the 80th anniversary of the end of World War II and the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.
short_name: Hiroshima Appeals: A Poster Exhibition of Global Messages

What makes for a delightful picnic? Food and drink? Poetry? Music? 

Immerse yourself into the pleasures, pastimes, and artistic heritage of Iran during the Safavid dynasty (1501-1736). A royal picnic, depicted on a large, treasured tile arch from the collections, is complemented by exceptional objects from the period.

Directed by Tim Drucker of Friends Parody Musical, Trixie and Katya LIVE and choreographed by Brooke Engen of Hairspray, Beetlejuice, Rock of Ages, with additional creatives to be announced. 

Be amongst the first to see it!
short_description: A hilarious immersive Broadway-style show that blends your favourite holiday movie tropes with high-octane pop showtunes

event_description:
Join the Lassonde Art Trail and the City of Toronto on Saturday, October 4th from 11:30 am – 1:30 pm for a traditional celebration of Trajet with artists Caroline Monnet and Dean Baldwin Lew, the walkers of the artwork, as well as Jesse Wente, Elder Clayton Shirt and Elder Shirley Gillis-Kendall. Soup and bannock by Pow Wow Cafe will be served at the close of the event.

Trajet acknowledges footprints made by Indigenous ancestors that were uncovered in blue clay on the floor of Lake Ontario in 1908. Trajet is now permanently integrated into the landscape of Biidaasige Park at the bend of the new Don River mouth, just south-east of Commissioners Bridge.

event_description:
The Southern Netherlands, better known today as Flanders, was home to revolutionary artists. 

These extraordinary painters found new ways to depict reality, portray humanity, and tell stories that created parallels to their world then and to our world today. This large-scale exhibition, featuring over 80 stunning art works and objects, medieval, renaissance, baroque paintings, sculptures and more, offering a doorway to art between 1400 to 1700. 

The exhibition's unique presentation introduces the visitor, through these rare, extraordinary artworks, to stories of enterprising townspeople, prosperous cities, and an ever-developing society.
event_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Masterworks

event_description:
Autumn is a season when we embrace death and dying as we watch the leaves turn and the weather change, Mother Nature shows us how to die with grace. 

Learn about metabolizing your grief and how sound, movement, community and storytelling can alleviate symptoms, building capacity for holding your grief. Explore legacy and build a community memorial together. Come to share your grief aloud, or come to be quiet and listen to the trees. 

Giveaway opportunities present at every walk!

event_description:
Beginning July 1st at Scarborough Museum, experience Washed Up by Hatecopy. The project captures the essence of liminal spaces that serve as cultural hubs for the South Asian immigrant communities, using the washing machine as a vessel to carry textiles that signify our roots and drawing visitors into an environment that intertwines the past, present, and future; acknowledging the dirty laundry of Canadian History and “Truth,” and reclaiming both seen and unseen spaces.

Maria Qamar (b. 1991) is a Toronto-based pop artist whose work is focused in the South Asian diaspora and immigrant communities and their cultural experiences. The work specializes in themes regarding feminism, social change, humour, pop culture, politics and romance. The artist has been recognized both nationally and internationally with exhibits and features in the Museum of Contemporary Arts, the National Arts Centre, Sotheby’s, Phillips Auction, and the AGO.
event_name: Washed Up: Pop-Up Installation at Scarborough Museum

short_name: Washed Up: Pop-Up Installation at Scarborough Museum

event_description:
Discover how homes shape identity through the Austin family story and contemporary art at Spadina Museum. Reimagine history, reframe home.

“Home at Spadina Museum” considers how people are influenced by their home. We look at those who make it a home and those who live in it are shaped by domestic spaces. Through interpretation of the Austin family and into contemporary art, we will analyze what makes a home. Re-Imagining the Historic House Museum: A Workplace for Women. 

Step into “Home at Spadina Museum” and explore how homes are shaped by the people who live and work in them. From the Austin family to contemporary art, discover untold stories of women’s labour, care, and community. Reimagine the historic house as both a home and a workplace.

As you explore the exhibition, we invite you to reflect: "What does home mean to you?"

We are grateful to our community partners, Augusto Bitter and the Women’s Art Association of Canada.
event_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Home at Spadina Museum
short_description: Discover how homes shape identity through the Austin family story and contemporary art at Spadina Museum. Reimagine hist
short_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Home at Spadina Museum

event_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Home at Spadina Museum
short_description: Discover how homes shape identity through the Austin family story and contemporary art at Spadina Museum. Reimagine hist
short_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Home at Spadina Museum

event_description:
The Southern Netherlands — better known today as Flanders — was home to revolutionary artists. These extraordinary painters found new ways to depict reality, portray humanity, and tell stories that created parallels to their world then - and to our world today. 

This large-scale exhibition, featuring over 80 stunning art works and objects — medieval, Renaissance, and baroque paintings, sculptures and more — offers a doorway into the Southern Netherlands of 1400 to 1700. The exhibition's unique presentation introduces the visitor, through these rare, extraordinary artworks, to stories of enterprising townspeople, prosperous cities, and an ever-developing society.
event_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Masterworks
short_description: The Southern Netherlands — better known today as Flanders — was home to revolutionary artists. These extraor
short_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Mast

event_description:
Join Scarborough Museum for a Season of Celebration! Embrace the spirit of light, love, and joy through a series of family-friendly activities centered on food, culture, and storytelling.  

Enjoy gingerbread decorating, family-friendly winter crafts and weekly workshops led by guest facilitators, including chair yoga, henna and more! See additional listings for more details. 

Community Feature: Sample a rotating selection of warm drinks and finger foods from around the world, curated by the Scarborough Museum Youth Collective and participants of Scarborough Museum’s Newcomer Storytelling Circles. Try something new or enjoy an old favourite, learn more about the stories behind these sips and bites, and share your own stories of light and warmth in our community jar!  

Treats will be available first come-first served, while quantities last.
event_name: Season of Celebration at Scarborough Museum

short_name: Season of Celebration at Scarborough Museum
