Tickets will be released October 10th.

Tickets must be reserved for all participants, including children. Children under the age of 14 must be accompanied by an adult over the age of 18.
event_description:
Join Elavarasi Janakiraman and Scarborough Museum for family-friendly, hands-on henna workshops this November! Learn more about the artform, and adorn your hands with traditional henna designs that honour intergenerational artistry and cultural expression. 

Elavarasi Janakiraman of Lotus Henna Scarborough is a passionate henna artist rooted in the Scarborough community. Her love for henna began in childhood, when she would decorate her own hands with intricate designs. What started as a personal art form shared with friends and family has since blossomed into a full-time career. Today, she offers her beautiful henna services across Scarborough and the Greater Toronto Area. 

This workshop is part of Scarborough Museum's Season of Celebration - a series of family-friendly activities that celebrate light, love, and joy through food, culture, and storytelling.

Olga is a multidisciplinary artist, cultural leader, and Master of Arts Leadership candidate at Queen’s University whose practice bridges painting, storytelling, and community engagement. event_description:
One of the longest running markets of its kind in Toronto, opening annually for 46 years. With its rich and storied history, the market has become a staple event that the Weston community enjoys visiting every year. Generations of families have visited to enjoy some farm fresh produce, dairy, meats, eggs and finely prepared foods, as well as local artisans showcasing their work to the community.

We look forward to welcoming new friends to join us!

event_description: Your weekly destination for local shopping and community vibes inside the historic Parkdale Hall. The market features a curated mix of fresh produce, artisan goods, handmade crafts, and vintage finds from Toronto’s most creative small businesses. With new vendors each week and seasonal surprises throughout the year, there’s always something fresh to discover. Pet-friendly, and open year-round!

event_description:
Photography omes alive with dance, music, and spoken word performances. Nine photographic artists join together with professionals in the fields of dance, poetry, drama, and music to present an afternoon of visual art with Ekphrasis performances in response to the photographs. 

Photographic artists are Linda Briskin, Brianna Caryll, Lucie Collins, Martha Davis, Vivian East, Kye Marshall, Jana Skarecky, Patricia Stamp, and Henrietta Walmark.

Performers responding to the visual works are dancer Brianna Clarke, musicians Taivi Alexander, Kye Marshall and Jana Skarecky, dramatists Angie Littlefield and Annie Rosenberg and poets Kate Marshall Flaherty, Bianca Lakoseljac, JC Sulzenko and Donna Wootton.

event_description:
Step into an immersive visual experience where material becomes memory, and memory becomes art. 

A compelling mixed media art exhibition that explores emotion, expression, and the sense of belonging through abstract and landscape works. From fragmented shorelines to colour-washed horizons and textured echoes of time, the exhibition invites viewers into a space of contemplation and connection, where personal and collective memories surface through layered materials and imaginative forms.

event_description:
Explore the trees and green spaces around the Agincourt branch with City of Toronto Urban Forestry staff. Take a guided neighborhood walk to learn how to identify local tree species and understand their role in the urban environment, from cultural connections to ecological benefits.

Children under 12 must be accompanied by a parent/caregiver. Please note that the tour will start and end at the Agincourt library and will be guided by the City of Toronto Urban Forestry staff. There may be uneven, unpaved surfaces along the route outside and around the neighbourhood. Please dress and prepare accordingly for this outdoor program (e.g., hats, sunscreen, water, comfortable shoes). 

This program takes place rain or shine. In the event of severe inclement weather, please register with the branch to be notified of an alternative date. Registration is required. Please contact the branch by phone or in person to register.
event_name: Trees Around the Branch Tour at Agincourt Library

short_name: Trees Around the Branch Tour at Agincourt Library

event_description:
In the chaos of urban life, we often forget to take a moment to breathe. Take in a moment of stillness, as we inviting visitors to stand beneath something that feels alive.

The outdoor installation, made from a suspended grid of copper leaves, reimagines the shelter of a forest canopy with each leaf individually cut and hung to form a floating canopy above. By day, the leaves catch the light and scatter soft shadows across the ground. By night, lighting transforms the installation, casting intricate patterns on surrounding surfaces and shifting the atmosphere of the space entirely. As wind moves through the piece, the leaves gently sway and rustle, adding a subtle layer of sound to the experience.

Responding to its surroundings and shifting with the light, weather and movement of people passing beneath it, this work offers a dynamic and reflective space in the heart of the city. 

Designed by RAW Works, with Roland Rom Colthoff, Suleman Khan, Elmira Yousefi and Aaron Hendershot.
short_description: In the chaos of urban life, we often forget to take a moment to breathe. Take in a moment of stillness, as we inviting v

event_description:
The Palmerston Branch and its neighbourhood are home to a variety of trees. Join City of Toronto Urban Forestry staff to explore the natural world on a local neighbourhood walk. Learn how to recognize different species and fun facts about their cultural and ecological importance.

Children under 12 must be accompanied by a parent/caregiver.

Please note, the tour will start and end at the Palmerston Branch. The City of Toronto Urban Forestry staff will guide attendees outside and around the neighbourhood where there may be uneven, unpaved surfaces. Please dress and prepare accordingly for this outdoor program (e.g. hats, sunscreen, water, comfortable shoes). This program takes place rain or shine. In the event of severe inclement weather, please register with the branch to be notified of an alternative date.

Registration is required. Please visit the branch or call 416-393-7680 to register. REGISTRATION WILL OPEN IN OCTOBER.
event_name: Trees Around the Branch Tour at Palmerston Library
short_description: The Palmerston Branch and its neighbourhood are home to a variety of trees. Join City of Toronto Urban Forestry staff to
short_name: Trees Around the Branch Tour at Palmerston Library

event_description:
A celebration of the city’s passion for basketball and the remarkable stories of legendary players who changed the game. Join us and experience basketball history come to life through augmented reality, where you can custom design your own basketball jersey.

Even before the Toronto Raptors and the rallying cry, “We the North” became a slogan, for over a century, basketball in Toronto was deeply rooted in the evolving social and cultural conditions of our city and its people.  

From the Canadian invention of basketball to the early women’s game in 1895, to the first professional basketball game played by the short-lived Toronto Huskies in 1946, and the recent creation of the Toronto Tempo WNBA team, these and many other milestones chart the sport’s development in the city.
short_description: A celebration of the city’s passion for basketball and the remarkable stories of legendary players who changed the game.

event_description:
A celebration of the city’s passion for basketball and the remarkable stories of legendary players who changed the game. Join us and experience basketball history come to life through augmented reality, where you can custom design your own basketball jersey.

Even before the Toronto Raptors and the rallying cry, “We the North” became a slogan, for over a century, basketball in Toronto was deeply rooted in the evolving social and cultural conditions of our city and its people.  

From the Canadian invention of basketball to the early women’s game in 1895, to the first professional basketball game played by the short-lived Toronto Huskies in 1946, and the recent creation of the Toronto Tempo WNBA team, these and many other milestones chart the sport’s development in the city.
short_description: A celebration of the city’s passion for basketball and the remarkable stories of legendary players who changed the game.

event_description:
Enjoy a rich blend of folk, jazz and roots music has drawn comparisons to Alison Krauss and Eva Cassidy. With warmth and honesty, Clela’s songs explore love, resilience and the meaning of home. We welcome Clela to celebrate the release of her album "Walkin’ Each Other Home", which was recorded live off the floor with producer Jimmy Bowskill. 

Tune in for an opening set from Katey Morley. Her music follows few rules, weaving together unexpected yet singable melodies and effortlessly fusing her love for country, jazz, folk and pop music. With a dynamic and emotional voice, Katey draws comparisons to Linda Ronstadt, Barbra Streisand and Sinead O'Connor.
short_description: Enjoy a rich blend of folk, jazz and roots music has drawn comparisons to Alison Krauss and Eva Cassidy. With warmth and

event_description:
After 23 years away chasing dreams in Toronto, this three-time JUNO nominee (formerly know as Oh Susanna) returned home to Vancouver, drawn by its salt air and towering trees. Her new album "Among the Evergreens" is a deeply personal journey through time, tracing her path from youthful dreams to the wisdom of experience.

Suzie brings her stories to life with her captivating voice and raw honesty. Inviting you into her world through poetic lyricism and mesmerizing melodies, she shares her experiences from teenage-hood to motherhood. She ponders, “Here I am making songs back among the evergreens, a prodigal daughter, who is now a mother, asking, who was I then and who am I now, where have I been and what did I learn along the way?”.
short_description: After 23 years away chasing dreams in Toronto, this three-time JUNO nominee (formerly know as Oh Susanna) returned home

event_description:
A Latin Grammy and JUNO winning Canadian guitarist, songwriter, producer and composer who creates music to inspire and connect people. 

From his bands Prozzak and The Philosopher Kings to a collborations with global stars Drake, Nelly Furtado, Luis Fonsi and more, James has produced, written and performed on hundreds of records, with nearly 2 billion total streams across platforms. 

A passionate performer, he has played on many iconic stages from Wembley Stadium to Madison Square Garden. James brings his enthusiasm of supporting the next great generation of artists!
event_name: Discoveries Vol. 6 with Musical Host James Bryan

event_description:
Making Home in Scarborough is a vibrant pop-up installation celebrating memory, identity, and belonging through cultural traditions and objects we hold dear to our hearts in generations past, present and future. 
 

Co-created through conversation and care, community members were invited to share a meaningful object, rooted in a heartfelt story. All speak to how home is made not only in buildings or borders, but in the places, people, and practices that give life meaning. 
 
As you explore the exhibition, we invite you to reflect: "What does home mean to you?" If you live in Scarborough, "What does Making Home in Scarborough Mean to you?" 
 
We are grateful for our community collaborators: Native Child and Family Services / Scarborough Child & Family Life Centre, Malvern Family Resource Centre, TDSB Newcomer Services (Malvern), Toby's Place, Scarborough Museum Youth Collective and Change Made.
event_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Making Home in Scarborough at Scarborough Museum
short_description: Making Home in Scarborough is a vibrant pop-up installation celebrating memory, identity, and belonging through cultural
short_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Making Home in Scarborough at Scarborough Mu

event_description:
You are invited into the beating heart of contemporary craft and design, a space where tradition meets bold reinvention, and where the maker’s hand is ever-present. 

Through the exceptional work of our current Artists-in-Residence, this exhibition explores the enduring relevance of skilled making in a world dominated by speed, automation and disposability. 

We are a cornerstone of Canada’s craft landscape, a rare incubator where artists have the time, space and support to experiment, collaborate and grow their professional careers. From glass, metal and ceramics to textiles and contemporary design, the residents featured here are not only shaping objects – they are shaping culture.  

In this context, to “meet your maker” is to engage with the processes, politics and poetics of craft and design today. It’s a chance to stand face to face with emerging visionaries who transform raw mate
short_description: You are invited into the beating heart of contemporary craft and design, a space where tradition meets bold reinvention,

event_description:
This is a solo exhibition by Ukrainian-Canadian artist Olga Polstvin.

Olga is a multidisciplinary artist, cultural leader, and Master of Arts Leadership candidate at Queen’s University whose practice bridges painting, storytelling, and community engagement. Born in Kyiv, Ukraine, she carries forward the resilience and cultural memory of her heritage, weaving themes of belonging, healing, and identity into her work.
event_name: Through the Lens of Ukrainian Belonging

event_description:
What makes for a delightful picnic? Food and drink? Poetry? Music? 

Immerse yourself into the pleasures, pastimes, and artistic heritage of Iran during the Safavid dynasty (1501-1736). A royal picnic, depicted on a large, treasured tile arch from the collections, is complemented by exceptional objects from the period.

event_description:
A quiet lake in Ontario is making a lot of noise.

Sediments from the bottom of a small lake in Ontario are revealing a remarkable record of our impact on the planet.

Just outside Toronto, Ontario lies Crawford Lake, a significant site offering a unique, comprehensive 1,000-year record of human impacts - local, regional, and global.

event_description:
Step into an immersive visual experience where material becomes memory, and memory becomes art. 

A compelling mixed media art exhibition that explores emotion, expression, and the sense of belonging through abstract and landscape works. From fragmented shorelines to colour-washed horizons and textured echoes of time, the exhibition invites viewers into a space of contemplation and connection, where personal and collective memories surface through layered materials and imaginative forms.

event_description:
Two internationally acclaimed  experiences, SÉANCE and FLIGHT, are coming. 

Staged inside purpose-built 40-foot shipping containers, these genre-defying works use complete darkness, 360° binaural audio, and precisely timed physical and environmental effects to create psychologically charged alternate realities.

The Toronto season brings two of the company’s most toured experiences to Canada for the first time. With over 700,000 attendees worldwide and appearances of their work at Venice Film Festival, Tribeca, SXSW, and Edinburgh Fringe, Toronto is now invited also to step inside the dark.

event_description:
Step into the glow, we're back for the sixth year! 

This year, guests can explore the magic like never before with a brand-new layout that lets you move freely between the immersive light show and Pumpkinville at your own pace. Wander through the illuminated maze of over 1.5 million LED and RGB lights, then pop into a vibrant fall fair featuring all new glowing photo ops, installations, midway rides, carnival games, and over 15,000 pumpkins. With new scenes, dazzling photo moments, and an entirely transformed setup, this is not just a walk, it's an adventure!
short_description:
Step into the glow, we're back for the sixth year! 

This year, guests can explore the magic like never before with a br

event_description:
The Southern Netherlands — better known today as Flanders — was home to revolutionary artists. These extraordinary painters found new ways to depict reality, portray humanity, and tell stories that created parallels to their world then - and to our world today. 

This large-scale exhibition, featuring over 80 stunning art works and objects — medieval, Renaissance, and baroque paintings, sculptures and more — offers a doorway into the Southern Netherlands of 1400 to 1700. The exhibition's unique presentation introduces the visitor, through these rare, extraordinary artworks, to stories of enterprising townspeople, prosperous cities, and an ever-developing society.
event_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Masterworks
short_description: The Southern Netherlands — better known today as Flanders — was home to revolutionary artists. These extraordinary paint
short_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Mast

event_description:
Borders divide, the cosmos unites.

Canadian legend Robert Lepage returns to Canadian Stage after sold-out productions of 887 and Needles and Opium.

Set against the Cold War's fierce U.S.-Soviet rivalry, this gripping story explores the personal and political turmoil of an era defined by global tension with a uniquely Canadian perspective. Through the tale of two Quebec City brothers, Lepage's stunning use of multimedia and visual storytelling draws the audience into a world on the brink of change and portrays the impact of global conflict on the individual.
event_name: The Far Side of the Moon
short_description:
Borders divide, the cosmos unites.

Canadian legend Robert Lepage returns to Canadian Stage after sold-out productions o
short_name: The Far Side of the Moon

event_description:
Experience a guided sound journey that sparks joy, connection and play through music and movement. Participants will wear headphones and enter a soundscape that blends music, story and guided exploration, inviting you to listen, move and feel together.  

In an era marked by disconnection, loneliness and social division, Reset offers a counter-experience: one rooted in curiosity, shared presence and delight. The work draws on traditions of street theatre, sound art and community ritual to create a space where strangers can become participants, and where every day public space is transformed into a site of collective effervescence.

event_description:
Enjoy this concert of dramatic contrasts.

The evening begins with Canadian composer Matthew Donnelly’s witty and macabre The Grave-Digger’s Waltz, a Halloween-inspired piece full of dark humor. 

Acclaimed pianist Michael Berkovsky, praised for his “remarkable virtuosity and extraordinary artistry,” performs Rachmaninoff’s dazzling Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini, Op. 43. This beloved work contrasts fiery, demonic themes with some of the most angelic and tender melodies ever written, including the famous 18th variation. 

The program concludes with Dvořák’s Symphony No. 8 in G Major, a jubilant celebration of life, filled with sweeping melodies, folk-inspired rhythms, and triumphant spirit. Join us for an unforgettable night of music that explores both the shadows and the light.
short_description:
Enjoy this concert of dramatic contrasts.

The evening begins with Canadian composer Matthew Donnelly’s witty and macab

event_description:
Celebrating our 40th anniversary with the return of Mozart’s enchanting fairy tale!

One of the most popular productions in our repetoire and sung in Andrew Porter’s acclaimed English translation, The Magic Flute is a dazzling blend of comedy and fantasy, in which dragons and spirits roam, and perseverance is rewarded by true love. This is the tale of a prince, Tamino, who is sent by the Queen of the Night to rescue her daughter Pamina from her nemesis Sarastro.

event_description:
Join us for a chilling tour at Colborne Lodge in High Park. 

Visit the gravesite of John and Jemima Howard. Explore ideas about death and the afterlife from the 1800s and hear true tales of paranormal activities. Experience some of the museum’s dark stories if you dare! 

A portion of this event is outside so please dress accordingly. 
Recommended for ages 12 and up. Youth 12-16 must be accompanied by an adult.
event_name: After Dark Tours: The Unexplained at Colborne Lodge

event_description:
A hilarious immersive Broadway-style show that blends your favourite holiday movie tropes with high-octane pop showtunes. 

Directed by Tim Drucker of Friends Parody Musical, Trixie and Katya LIVE and choreographed by Brooke Engen of Hairspray, Beetlejuice, Rock of Ages, with additional creatives to be announced. 

Be amongst the first to see it!

event_description:
Wyrmwell Studios showcases emerging Toronto artists Shevon Lewis, Kima Lenaghan, Amy Thomson, and Misbah Ahmed. Explore their illustrations, transformative portraiture, and sculptural ceramics. 

Join the Artists for the opening reception on Saturday, November 1, 2 to 4 p.m. Light refreshments provided.

event_description:
Two internationally acclaimed  experiences, SÉANCE and FLIGHT, are coming. 

Staged inside purpose-built 40-foot shipping containers, these genre-defying works use complete darkness, 360° binaural audio, and precisely timed physical and environmental effects to create psychologically charged alternate realities.

The Toronto season brings two of the company’s most toured experiences to Canada for the first time. With over 700,000 attendees worldwide and appearances of their work at Venice Film Festival, Tribeca, SXSW, and Edinburgh Fringe, Toronto is now invited also to step inside the dark.

event_description:
Two-time JUNO Award-winning Canadian singer-songwriter and banjo player Christopher “Chris” Rudolf Luedecke's narrative-driven folk songs are playful, coy and soul warming.

Based in Chester, Nova Scotia, the roots singer-songwriter muses on love, art and purpose. With skillful precision and a storyteller's heart, Luedecke charms audiences with his heartfelt folk tunes.

event_description:
Through the use of sculpture, photography, video, and installation, this exhibition is a blend of different people and perspectives forming a kind of visual and sonic cacophony. It’s a nod to global (or even galactic) unity, and to the idea that despite all the noise and division, we’re more alike than not. 

In her Canadian debut, Intergalactic Planetary brings together imagery and works inspired by cities including Shanghai, Chongqing, Berlin, Tokyo, Bangkok and locations across the United States. Snelling explains, “Through this work, I ask: how can we move beyond our fears, borders, and egos to become more humane? Perhaps by staying curious, open, and willing to see each other more fully, we can take a small step toward connection, and even a glimmer of peace for the future”.

Join us on Nuit Blanche to view the exhibition's works, while DJ beats set the mood with dynamic sounds and enjoy two exhibition-inspired cocktails-one coffee-based and the other with an intergalactic twist.
short_description: Through the use of sculpture, photography, video, and installation, this exhibition is a blend of different people and p

event_description:
We are pleased to bring you the fifth annual Greek International Film Festival Tour of Canada (GIFFT).

This is a Canadian national film festival that will take place in 11 Canadian cities simultaneously. Those cities include: Toronto, Vancouver, Edmonton, Calgary, Regina, Winnipeg, London (Ontario), Hamilton/Niagara, Ottawa, and Halifax.

GIFFT is a showcase and celebration of Greek cinema and filmmakers of Greek Heritage. This festival will provide exciting platform for directors, writers, producers, and actors of Greek Heritage to showcase their exceptional art across Canada.

event_description:
Since 1975, we have been Canada’s favourite holiday tradition, spotlighting the creativity and talent of makers from across the country. This year, we proudly celebrate our 50th anniversary, honouring 
five decades of Canadian craft while looking ahead to an exciting new era.

More than just a marketplace, this is a cultural movement where creativity comes to life. Visitors can shop from over 700 artisans and makers, discover one-of-a-kind treasures and support Canadian small businesses, all while experiencing the festive magic of the season.

This year enjoy a brand-new vintage section, full of nostalgic finds, a European-style Christmas Market with festive gifts, décor, food and drink, an expanded Flavours section for food lovers and special Northwest Territories Pop-Up.
event_name: One Of a Kind Christmas Show | 50th Anniversary
short_description: Since 1975, we have been Canada’s favourite holiday tradition, spotlighting the creativity and talent of makers from acr
short_name: One Of a Kind Christmas Show | 50th Anniversary

event_description:
One of Toronto's oldest holiday traditions. 

First staged here in 1938, this pageant began in St. Martin-in-the-Fields church in London, England in 1928. Queen Elizabeth and her sister Margaret were taken to see it when they were little girls. The story of the Nativity is told through a series of narrated scenes linked by beautiful organ music and carols from an unseen choir.   

Close to 50 volunteers, including babies who take turns playing the role of baby Jesus, perform in the cast. The Church of the Holy Trinity, a 178-year-old architectural treasure, brings its own charm to the show.  ASL interpretation is available on Friday, December 19th.
short_description:
One of Toronto's oldest holiday traditions. 

First staged here in 1938, this pageant began in St. Martin-in-the-Fields

event_description:
"I Am Scarborough" is a community-engaged installation at Scarborough Museum, created by artist Kseniya Tsoy during her Toronto Arts Council Animating Historic Sites residency.

Over the course of several months, Scarborough residents and museum visitors came together to fold hundreds of origami butterflies and share their stories—their journeys, the lands their families come from, and their hopes and dreams.

Now gathered and suspended in flight, these butterflies embody the vibrant diversity of Scarborough—soaring high and envisioning a bright, shared future.

Experience their collective flight at Scarborough Museum through October 2025.
event_name: I am Scarborough - Installation at Scarborough Museum

short_name: I am Scarborough - Installation at Scarborough Museum

cost_notes: Register in Museum Store upon arrival.  Maximum of 12 participants.
event_description: Grate, pound and sift sugar and spices in the historic kitchen at Fort York National Historic Site and make an 1831 Gingerbread recipe to taste and take home to enjoy for the holidays. Share stories about ingredients and their histories, and be inspired by renewed gingerbread recipes made by Fort York's Chef in Residence, Jean Régis Raynaud.
event_name: Make, Bake & Take Gingerbread Workshops for Children

short_name: Make, Bake & Take Gingerbread Workshops for Children

event_description:
Singing workshop series for newcomers exploring music to express creativity. This 8-week workshop series is designed to build confidence, develop voice and meet new friends. No experience is needed. Light refreshments provided.

A City of Toronto Cultural Hotspot SPARK Project.
short_description: Singing workshop series for newcomers exploring music to express creativity. This 8-week workshop series is designed to

event_description:
The Southern Netherlands, better known today as Flanders, was home to revolutionary artists. 

These extraordinary painters found new ways to depict reality, portray humanity, and tell stories that created parallels to their world then and to our world today. This large-scale exhibition, featuring over 80 stunning art works and objects, medieval, renaissance, baroque paintings, sculptures and more, offering a doorway to art between 1400 to 1700. 

The exhibition's unique presentation introduces the visitor, through these rare, extraordinary artworks, to stories of enterprising townspeople, prosperous cities, and an ever-developing society.
event_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Masterworks

The Southern Netherlands, better known today as Flanders, was home to revolutionary artists.

short_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Mast

event_description:
Join us in celebrating joy, light, and culture at Toronto’s largest Diwali celebration!

Also known as Deepavali, the Festival of Lights symbolizes the victory of light over darkness, good over evil, and knowledge over ignorance.

Bring your family, friends, and neighbors to experience stunning light displays, delicious global cuisine, live music and cultural performances, musical Ramayana, a showcase and a fun kid's zone.
short_description:
Join us in celebrating joy, light, and culture at Toronto’s largest Diwali celebration!

Also known as Deepavali, the Fe

event_description:
Step back in time with a free visit to Spadina Museum, beautifully decorated for a 1920s Christmas. Visitors can enjoy the opulent holiday décor and period ambiance that once filled the home of the wealthy Austin family. Twinkling lights, antique ornaments, and rooms set for a classic Jazz Age celebration bring the spirit of the season to life.
As you stroll through the mansion, interpretive displays offer insights into the lavish holiday traditions of Toronto’s elite in the 1920s. In contrast, visitors will also learn about the experiences of the city’s less fortunate citizens during the same era—those who faced poverty, unemployment, and food insecurity during a time of great social and economic change.
From a grand dining room prepared for a festive feast to modest depictions of how the servants of the household marked the holidays, the experience paints a full picture of a Toronto Christmas in the early 20th century.
event_name: Jazz Age Christmas at Spadina Museum

short_name: Jazz Age Christmas at Spadina Museum

In essence, TISAS 26 is a globally focused Street Art conference meets mural festival in one, with a speakers plus workshop series, live mural painting as a spectator sport, A film festival, family programming, music , and more. its big, to say the least! We're inviting over 100 of the world's best and brightest street artists to participate in painting, speaking and teaching, bringing new color city wide.

event_description:
Hailing from the east coast, Lennie has released fifteen albums of original songs which have won him a host of awards and nominations from the JUNOs, Les Prix Éloizes, and The East Coast Music Awards. 

He has performed all over North America and Europe. His songs have been covered by many artists and he has shared the stage with several orchestras and with performers such as Lucinda Williams, Patti Griffin and Roger Hodgson. 

His work has reach as far as the International Space Station and circled the planet 248 times. As a member of The Order of Canada, he has been recognized for his humanitarian efforts.

event_description:
Toronto’s Favourite Holiday Panto Returns!

Get ready to root for the underdog and boo the baddies! This year, the legendary outlaw tale takes on a bold twist - our Robin is a spirited, savvy heroine leading her merry band of misfits in a fight for justice and kindness.  

Join Robin and her friends on a medieval romp through merry old Torontoshire! Journey through the lush forests of High Park, go head-to-head with the greedy Prince John, and rescue those in need - all with a hearty dose of laughter, pop hits, and plenty of surprises. 

Robin Hood delivers all the Panto fun you love, a sparkling spoof on a classic tale, hilarious comedy, dazzling musical numbers, and an intergenerational celebration that's perfect for the whole family.  

Grab your loved ones, don your green tights, and join us for a experience full of mischief, melody, and meaning.
event_name: Robin Hood: A Very Merry Family Musical

event_description:
Join us on a chilling and thrilling journey through the dark history of the city as we delve into the world of ghosts, graveyards, hangings, and haunts.

 Prepare to be captivated by spine-tingling ghost stories about haunted theatres, unsolved mysteries, secrets hiding in plain sight, and spooky historic buildings. Our outdoor tour will take you on a hair-raising paranormal adventure, departing from the courtyard in front of the Hockey Hall of Fame. 

Get ready to see the city in a whole new light, or rather, darkness, as you uncover the eerie and supernatural tales that lurk in its shadows.

event_description:
Join us for a chilling tour at Colborne Lodge in High Park. 

Visit the gravesite of John and Jemima Howard. Explore ideas about death and the afterlife from the 1800s and hear true tales of paranormal activities. Experience some of the museum’s dark stories if you dare! 

A portion of this event is outside so please dress accordingly. 
Recommended for ages 12 and up. Youth 12-16 must be accompanied by an adult.
event_name: After Dark Tours: The Unexplained at Colborne Lodge

event_description:
A Story of Hope and Finding Light in Dark Places.

Witness hope and resilience onstage in The Mush Hole – an exquisite theatrical dance performance that illuminates a dark corner of Canada’s history. From 1828 to 1970, Indigenous children from Six Nations were torn from their families, stripped of their names, and forced to live at Brantford’s Mohawk Institute Residential School. Kids called it the Mush Hole for the appalling gruel they were fed.

From visionary director, choreographer, and producer Santee Smith, comes this powerful story, created from the testimonials of two generations of survivors. With visceral performances from an all-Indigenous cast, immersive video, and a cinematic musical score, this five-time Dora Award-winner is one of Canada’s must-see productions.
short_description:
A Story of Hope and Finding Light in Dark Places.

Witness hope and resilience onstage in The Mush Hole – an exquisite t

event_description:
You are invited into the beating heart of contemporary craft and design, a space where tradition meets bold reinvention, and where the maker’s hand is ever-present. 

Through the exceptional work of our current Artists-in-Residence, this exhibition explores the enduring relevance of skilled making in a world dominated by speed, automation and disposability. 

We are a cornerstone of Canada’s craft landscape, a rare incubator where artists have the time, space and support to experiment, collaborate and grow their professional careers. From glass, metal and ceramics to textiles and contemporary design, the residents featured here are not only shaping objects – they are shaping culture.  

In this context, to “meet your maker” is to engage with the processes, politics and poetics of craft and design today. It’s a chance to stand face to face with emerging visionaries who transform raw mate
short_description: You are invited into the beating heart of contemporary craft and design, a space where tradition meets bold reinvention,

A quiet lake in Ontario is making a lot of noise.

Sediments from the bottom of a small lake in Ontario are revealing a remarkable record of our impact on the planet.

Just outside Toronto, Ontario lies Crawford Lake, a significant site offering a unique, comprehensive 1,000-year record of human impacts - local, regional, and global.

event_description:
What makes for a delightful picnic? Food and drink? Poetry? Music? 

Immerse yourself into the pleasures, pastimes, and artistic heritage of Iran during the Safavid dynasty (1501-1736). A royal picnic, depicted on a large, treasured tile arch from the collections, is complemented by exceptional objects from the period.

event_description:
Toronto has one of the largest urban forests in the world. Join City of Toronto Urban Forestry staff for an in-library presentation on this amazing natural habitat that reaches all corners of Toronto. We'll talk about what makes the urban forest so special and share tools to explore and understand it better. Bring questions and curiosities, and leave with emboldened confidence and understanding of your City and the natural world that surrounds you!

Registration required. To register, please call 416-396-8969 or visit the reference desk. If you identify as a person with a disability or as a person who is Deaf and require accessibility accommodations to participate in this program, please contact Accessibility Services by email, accessibleservices@tpl.ca, or voicemail, 416-393-7099, to make a request. Please contact us at least three weeks in advance.
event_name: Forestry Talk at North York Central Library

The Southern Netherlands — better known today as Flanders — was home to revolutionary artists. These extraordinary painters found new ways to depict reality, portray humanity, and tell stories that created parallels to their world then - and to our world today. 

This large-scale exhibition, featuring over 80 stunning art works and objects — medieval, Renaissance, and baroque paintings, sculptures and more — offers a doorway into the Southern Netherlands of 1400 to 1700. The exhibition's unique presentation introduces the visitor, through these rare, extraordinary artworks, to stories of enterprising townspeople, prosperous cities, and an ever-developing society.
event_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Masterworks
short_description: The Southern Netherlands — better known today as Flanders — was home to revolutionary artists. These extraor
short_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Mast

event_description:
This is our seventh solo exhibition of work by Canadian artist Sarah Anne Johnson.

This journey is presented in two chapters: “Cedar Forest” and “Mountain”. Both series expound on the artist’s “Woodland” series, offering new dimensions and depth to an already impressive body of work. 

“Mountain” offers a quiet, personal reflection on horseback trek through Jasper National Park, while “Cedar Forest” draws viewers into the mesmerizing cedar groves of British Columbia. These series exist in beautiful harmony as a meditation on the natural world, and what it mean means to experience it fully.
event_name: A Mountain and a Forest by Sarah Anne Johnson

event_description:
Celebrating art, nature and community.

Featuring over 70 original artworks created outdoors at Toronto Botanical Garden and Edwards Gardens, this curated, site-specific show invites visitors to experience the gardens through the eyes of the artists who paint here, capturing moments of light, movement, and the essence of the natural world.
event_name: Essence of the Garden: Plein Air Art Exhibition and Sale

Celebrating art, nature and community.

event_description:
This is a contemporary form of environmental art created by artists who are  concerned about reducing waste, recycling, and making the world a better place, while raising awareness about environmental changes.

 It aims to showcases the beauty and creativity of using recycled, environmentally friendly or sustainable materials to create phenomenal artwork, using water-based paints, natural pigments and recycled materials to name a few elements. lt is art that advocates for the planet, catering to all ages and present in various mediums, including paintings, sculptures or fashion.

Presenting our second annual art exhibition, we will be utilizing selected artists to mentor African and Caribbean communities on the positioning of multicultural history and art within the Canadian cultural landscape.

event_description:
Join us on a chilling and thrilling journey through the dark history of the city as we delve into the world of ghosts, graveyards, hangings, and haunts.

 Prepare to be captivated by spine-tingling ghost stories about haunted theatres, unsolved mysteries, secrets hiding in plain sight, and spooky historic buildings. Our outdoor tour will take you on a hair-raising paranormal adventure, departing from the courtyard in front of the Hockey Hall of Fame. 

Get ready to see the city in a whole new light, or rather, darkness, as you uncover the eerie and supernatural tales that lurk in its shadows.

event_description:
Jason Wilson is an award-winning Scottish-Canadian musician, bestselling historian and television personality. 

A two-time Juno Awards nominee and CRMA Winner, Wilson has eight books to his name including the OHS award-winning "King Alpha’s Song in a Strange Land: The Roots and Routes of Canadian Reggae" (UBC Press, 2020) and the national bestseller "The Toronto Maple Leaf Hockey Club" (McClelland and Stewart, 2016). 

Born to Scottish immigrants, Jason Wilson grew up in Downsview, a neighbourhood in Toronto’s northwest corridor and has amassed over 2,500 performances across Canada, the United States, the United Kingdom and Jamaica. 

He has performed and recorded with UB40, Alanis Morissette, Sly & Robbie, Prince Buster, Aswad’s Brinsley Forde, Dick Gaughan, Pee Wee Ellis and more.

We're inviting over 100 of the world's best and brightest street artists to participate in painting, speaking and teaching, bringing new color city wide.

event_description:
You are invited into the beating heart of contemporary craft and design, a space where tradition meets bold reinvention, and where the maker’s hand is ever-present. 

Through the exceptional work of our current Artists-in-Residence, this exhibition explores the enduring relevance of skilled making in a world dominated by speed, automation and disposability. 

We are a cornerstone of Canada’s craft landscape, a rare incubator where artists have the time, space and support to experiment, collaborate and grow their professional careers. From glass, metal and ceramics to textiles and contemporary design, the residents featured here are not only shaping objects – they are shaping culture.  

In this context, to “meet your maker” is to engage with the processes, politics and poetics of craft and design today. It’s a chance to stand face to face with emerging visionaries who transform raw mate
short_description: You are invited into the beating heart of contemporary craft and design, a space where tradition meets bold reinvention,

event_description:
Discover how homes shape identity through the Austin family story and contemporary art at Spadina Museum. Reimagine history, reframe home.

“Home at Spadina Museum” considers how people are influenced by their home. We look at those who make it a home and those who live in it are shaped by domestic spaces. Through interpretation of the Austin family and into contemporary art, we will analyze what makes a home. Re-Imagining the Historic House Museum: A Workplace for Women. 

Step into “Home at Spadina Museum” and explore how homes are shaped by the people who live and work in them. From the Austin family to contemporary art, discover untold stories of women’s labour, care, and community. Reimagine the historic house as both a home and a workplace.

As you explore the exhibition, we invite you to reflect: "What does home mean to you?"

We are grateful to our community partners, Augusto Bitter and the Women’s Art Association of Canada.
event_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Home at Spadina Museum

short_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Home at Spadina Museum

event_description: Join us as we explore the supernatural side of Toronto’s historic and haunted pioneer village Featuring some of the oldest buildings in the city it is the perfect creepy backdrop for a night of spine-tingling ghost stories. Many of which have occurred to previous village guests and Haunted Walk tour guides. It is easily one of the most active sites we tour and is a must-do for paranormal enthusiasts. Not recommended for children or easily frightened adults.
event_name: Ghosts of the Village at Black Creek

event_description:
A quiet lake in Ontario is making a lot of noise.

Sediments from the bottom of a small lake in Ontario are revealing a remarkable record of our impact on the planet.

Just outside Toronto, Ontario lies Crawford Lake, a significant site offering a unique, comprehensive 1,000-year record of human impacts - local, regional, and global.
short_description:
A quiet lake in Ontario is making a lot of noise.

event_description:
In commemoration of the 80th anniversary of the end of World War II and the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. 

The series consists of 29 posters, headed by KAMEKURA Yūsaku’s masterpiece “Burning Butterflies” 1983, continued with an unbroken sequence of works of high artistic excellence. 

In addition, 49 posters will be displayed with global messages from our collection, and Toronto’s poster collection accompany the Hiroshima Appeals posters, focusing on the shared unique nature of their design creation in being non-commercial, abstract, conceptual, and reflecting on global issues and subjects.
event_name: Hiroshima Appeals: A Poster Exhibition of Global Messages
short_description: In commemoration of the 80th anniversary of the end of World War II and the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.
short_name: Hiroshima Appeals: A Poster Exhibition of Global Messages

event_name: Hiroshima Appeals: A Poster Exhibition of Global Messages

event_description:
A quiet lake in Ontario is making a lot of noise.

Sediments from the bottom of a small lake in Ontario are revealing a remarkable record of our impact on the planet.

Just outside Toronto, Ontario lies Crawford Lake, a significant site offering a unique, comprehensive 1,000-year record of human impacts - local, regional, and global.

event_description:
What does home mean to you? Discover rarely seen artifacts from the City’s collections and items from community members. Explore the many ways we define, create and carry home with us. From a First World War soldier’s return ticket home to a precious family object stewarded by multiple generations, encounter belongings, voices and stories of Toronto artists, makers, entrepreneurs and community leaders as they share their unique perspectives on belonging, identity and place. These powerful objects offer fresh, heartfelt perspectives on what it means to find, make or remember home.

At Home in Toronto includes the artworks of Rebecca Baird, Carl Beam, Fred Hagan, Robert Houle, Luis Jacob, Kit Li, Raoul Olou, Yasmine Louis and Natalie Wood, as well as loaned works by local artists Doug Brown and Frantz Brent-Harris.
short_description: What does home mean to you? Discover rarely seen artifacts from the City’s collections and items from community members.

event_description:
This is our seventh solo exhibition of work by Canadian artist Sarah Anne Johnson.

This journey is presented in two chapters: “Cedar Forest” and “Mountain”. Both series expound on the artist’s “Woodland” series, offering new dimensions and depth to an already impressive body of work. 

“Mountain” offers a quiet, personal reflection on horseback trek through Jasper National Park, while “Cedar Forest” draws viewers into the mesmerizing cedar groves of British Columbia. These series exist in beautiful harmony as a meditation on the natural world, and what it mean means to experience it fully.
event_name: A Mountain and a Forest by Sarah Anne Johnson

Live instruction provided by Salsa & Sabor.

Join us at the iconic Fort York for an energetic evening of Latin rhythms, family-friendly fun, and salsa dance instruction under the stars. 
No experience or partner required—just bring your dancing shoes and your best moves!

event_description:
As night falls, we’ll set out on a lantern-lit stroll along the cobblestone streets of the historic Distillery District, one of Toronto’s most haunted spots! 

Learn about the tragic events that left their mark and hear spine-chilling tales of paranormal encounters from this iconic area. Feel the goosebumps rise as you explore the narrow alleyways and hidden corners where spirits are said to lurk. 

Whether you’re a history buff, a ghost enthusiast, or just looking for a unique experience, this outdoor tour is sure to captivate your imagination. Get ready to experience the thrills and chills like never before.
event_name: Spirits of the Distillery District Ghost Tour

short_name: Spirits of the Distillery District Ghost Tour

The festival’s core mission is to advance education and raise cultural, artistic, and aesthetic awareness within the community. It aims to enrich public appreciation for the arts through film programming, workshops, and panel discussions, while uplifting both filmmakers and artists.

event_description:
The recipient of the 2024 Spirit of Folk Award, 2023 Canadian Fold Music Award for Indigenous Songwriter of the Year and the 2023 Capital Music Awards’ Album of the Year, Amanda Rheaume has released six full-length albums to date. 

Beyond recording and touring, Rheaume continues her ever-expanding role as an essential advocate of Indigenous music infrastructure and community. For her sixth release, The Truth We Hold, produced and mixed by Grammy-award winner Colin Linden at his Nashville studio, Rheaume offers 10 new songs that chronicle the Métis spirit; she sings for those that came before, those here now, and those not yet born.

Step into an immersive visual experience where material becomes memory, and memory becomes art. 

A compelling mixed media art exhibition that explores emotion, expression, and the sense of belonging through abstract and landscape works. From fragmented shorelines to colour-washed horizons and textured echoes of time, the exhibition invites viewers into a space of contemplation and connection, where personal and collective memories surface through layered materials and imaginative forms.

event_description:
This family-friendly exhibition invites you to uncover fresh perspectives, groundbreaking research and the astounding diversity of this ancient group of fishes.

Visitors will delve into the anatomy, behaviour, and history of sharks, from familiar favourites like tiger sharks and great whites to lesser-known species like the dwarf lanternshark—a tiny, light-producing marvel small enough to hold in your hand.

Through dozens of interactives and life-sized models, including a life-size head of the huge extinct Megalodon, join us for a unique look at these magnificent creatures, their habitats, hunting techniques, and the conservation threats that they face.

event_description:
In the chaos of urban life, we often forget to take a moment to breathe. Take in a moment of stillness, as we inviting visitors to stand beneath something that feels alive.

The outdoor installation, made from a suspended grid of copper leaves, reimagines the shelter of a forest canopy with each leaf individually cut and hung to form a floating canopy above. By day, the leaves catch the light and scatter soft shadows across the ground. By night, lighting transforms the installation, casting intricate patterns on surrounding surfaces and shifting the atmosphere of the space entirely. As wind moves through the piece, the leaves gently sway and rustle, adding a subtle layer of sound to the experience.

Responding to its surroundings and shifting with the light, weather and movement of people passing beneath it, this work offers a dynamic and reflective space in the heart of the city. 

Designed by RAW Works, with Roland Rom Colthoff, Suleman Khan, Elmira Yousefi and Aaron Hendershot.

event_description:
Two internationally acclaimed  experiences, SÉANCE and FLIGHT, are coming. 

Staged inside purpose-built 40-foot shipping containers, these genre-defying works use complete darkness, 360° binaural audio, and precisely timed physical and environmental effects to create psychologically charged alternate realities.

The Toronto season brings two of the company’s most toured experiences to Canada for the first time. With over 700,000 attendees worldwide and appearances of their work at Venice Film Festival, Tribeca, SXSW, and Edinburgh Fringe, Toronto is now invited also to step inside the dark.

Staged inside purpose-built 40-foot shipping containers, these genre-defying works use complete darkness, 360° binaural audio, and precisely timed physical and environmental effects to create psychologically charged alternate realities.

The Toronto season brings two of the company’s most toured experiences to Canada for the first time. With over 700,000 attendees worldwide and appearances of their work at Venice Film Festival, Tribeca, SXSW, and Edinburgh Fringe, Toronto is now invited also to step inside the dark.
short_description:
Two internationally acclaimed  experiences, SÉANCE and FLIGHT, are coming. 

Staged inside purpose-built 40-foot shippin

A spoken word poetry program for youth in the Jane and Finch community. Youth will learn the fundamentals of spoken word with Jayda Marley and Naiesha Marques and have the opportunity to present what they have learned at a final showcase for family and friends. 

A City of Toronto Cultural Hotspot Signature Project.

event_description:
With a career that spanned more than half a century, Frank Sinatra remains a towering figure in the world of music. Iconic hits like “My Way,” “Come Fly with Me,” and “Fly Me to the Moon” have become enduring classics, shaping the soundscape of early pop, swing, and jazz.

Born to Italian immigrants, Sinatra’s remarkable ‘rags to riches’ journey embodies the vitality and artistic spirit of Italian culture in post-World War II America. His voice, charisma, and influence continue to resonate across generations.

Join us for an unforgettable evening featuring acclaimed jazz vocalist John Alcorn and The Daniel Barnes Trio, as they revisit the timeless songs of "The Voice" and pay tribute to one of the most iconic Italo-American artists of the twentieth century.
event_name: The Voice: A Tribute to Frank Sinatra
short_description: With a career that spanned more than half a century, Frank Sinatra remains a towering figure in the world of music. Icon
short_name: The Voice: A Tribute to Frank Sinatra

event_description:
Step into the world of teas with a guided connoisseur-led tasting of classic, herbal, and signature tea blends. 

Enjoy chef-inspired food pairings, bite size snacks and delicacies while sipping the teas. Learn the art of making a chai latte with spices like cinnamon, cardamom, ginger, clove and pepper. Create 3 seasonal special lattes and make yourself a holiday tea cocktail.

Connect with a community of tea lovers over flavor, culture and wellness.
event_name: Holiday Tea Tasting Experience and Seasonal Chai Latte Masterclass
short_description:

event_description:
Curated by Mikinaak Migwans, Earthwork redefines a term that until now has referred to a type of artistic practice associated within the larger conceptual framework of land art. 

In this exhibition, Migwans shifts our understanding of earthwork to refer to a way of working, rather than the making of singular objects, reclaiming the art historical framing from an Indigenous perspective. It considers multiple layers of engagement with the land, including a history of land defense movements, medicine walks, and ancestral practices of prescribed burns, alongside contemporary art.

Featured artists include Michael Belmore, BUSH Gallery (Gabrielle L’Hirondelle Hill, Peter Morin, Tania Willard), Faye HeavyShield, Art Hunter, Alex Jacobs-Blum, Mike MacDonald, Lisa Myers, Edward Poitras, and Protect the Tract Collective.
event_name: Art Museum at the University of Toronto: Earthwork
short_description: Curated by Mikinaak Migwans, Earthwork redefines a term that until now has referred to a type of artistic practice assoc
short_name: Art Museum at the University of Toronto: Earthwork

In essence, TISAS 26 is a globally focused Street Art conference meets mural festival in one, with a speakers plus workshop series, live mural painting as a spectator sport, A film festival, family programming, music , and more. its big, to say the least! We're inviting over 100 of the world's best and brightest street artists to participate in painting, speaking and teaching, bringing new color city wide.

event_description: Join us for over 400 juried, original works of art created by The Art Guild of Scarborough artists, many of whom will be in attendance.  The art is a variety of mediums including watercolour, pastel, oil, acrylic, ink, sculpture and mixed media.  As well, our selection of mini-art returns by popular demand.  More than 50 artists have each created a mini-panel to be displayed and sold with its own mini-easel.

event_description:
Explore the trees and green spaces around the Mount Pleasant library branch with City of Toronto Urban Forestry staff. Take a guided neighborhood walk to learn how to identify local tree species and understand their role in the urban environment, from cultural connections to ecological benefits.

Children under 12 must be accompanied by a parent/caregiver. Please note that the tour will start and end at the library branch and will be guided by the City of Toronto Urban Forestry staff. There may be uneven, unpaved surfaces along the route outside and around the neighbourhood. Please dress and prepare accordingly for this outdoor program (e.g. gloves/mittens, hats, sunscreen, water, comfortable shoes). 

This program takes place rain or shine. In the event of severe inclement weather, please register with the branch to be notified of an alternative date. 

Registration is required. Please contact the branch by phone or in person to register
event_name: Trees Around the Branch Tour at Mount Pleasant Library
short_description: Explore the trees and green spaces around the Mount Pleasant library branch with City of Toronto Urban Forestry staff. T
short_name: Trees Around the Branch Tour at Mount Pleasant Library

event_description:
Through the use of sculpture, photography, video, and installation, this exhibition is a blend of different people and perspectives forming a kind of visual and sonic cacophony. It’s a nod to global (or even galactic) unity, and to the idea that despite all the noise and division, we’re more alike than not. 

In her Canadian debut, Intergalactic Planetary brings together imagery and works inspired by cities including Shanghai, Chongqing, Berlin, Tokyo, Bangkok and locations across the United States. Snelling explains, “Through this work, I ask: how can we move beyond our fears, borders, and egos to become more humane? Perhaps by staying curious, open, and willing to see each other more fully, we can take a small step toward connection, and even a glimmer of peace for the future”.

Join us on Nuit Blanche to view the exhibition's works, while DJ beats set the mood with dynamic sounds and enjoy two exhibition-inspired cocktails-one coffee-based and the other with an intergalactic twist.
short_description: Through the use of sculpture, photography, video, and installation, this exhibition is a blend of different people and p

event_description:
Join us on a chilling and thrilling journey through the dark history of the city as we delve into the world of ghosts, graveyards, hangings, and haunts.

 Prepare to be captivated by spine-tingling ghost stories about haunted theatres, unsolved mysteries, secrets hiding in plain sight, and spooky historic buildings. Our outdoor tour will take you on a hair-raising paranormal adventure, departing from the courtyard in front of the Hockey Hall of Fame. 

Get ready to see the city in a whole new light, or rather, darkness, as you uncover the eerie and supernatural tales that lurk in its shadows.

event_description:
You are invited into the beating heart of contemporary craft and design, a space where tradition meets bold reinvention, and where the maker’s hand is ever-present. 

Through the exceptional work of our current Artists-in-Residence, this exhibition explores the enduring relevance of skilled making in a world dominated by speed, automation and disposability. 

We are a cornerstone of Canada’s craft landscape, a rare incubator where artists have the time, space and support to experiment, collaborate and grow their professional careers. From glass, metal and ceramics to textiles and contemporary design, the residents featured here are not only shaping objects – they are shaping culture.  

In this context, to “meet your maker” is to engage with the processes, politics and poetics of craft and design today. It’s a chance to stand face to face with emerging visionaries who transform raw mate
short_description: You are invited into the beating heart of contemporary craft and design, a space where tradition meets bold reinvention,

event_description:
Discover how homes shape identity through the Austin family story and contemporary art at Spadina Museum. Reimagine history, reframe home.

“Home at Spadina Museum” considers how people are influenced by their home. We look at those who make it a home and those who live in it are shaped by domestic spaces. Through interpretation of the Austin family and into contemporary art, we will analyze what makes a home. Re-Imagining the Historic House Museum: A Workplace for Women. 

Step into “Home at Spadina Museum” and explore how homes are shaped by the people who live and work in them. From the Austin family to contemporary art, discover untold stories of women’s labour, care, and community. Reimagine the historic house as both a home and a workplace.

As you explore the exhibition, we invite you to reflect: "What does home mean to you?"

We are grateful to our community partners, Augusto Bitter and the Women’s Art Association of Canada.
event_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Home at Spadina Museum

event_description:
You are invited into the beating heart of contemporary craft and design, a space where tradition meets bold reinvention, and where the maker’s hand is ever-present. 

Through the exceptional work of our current Artists-in-Residence, this exhibition explores the enduring relevance of skilled making in a world dominated by speed, automation and disposability. 

We are a cornerstone of Canada’s craft landscape, a rare incubator where artists have the time, space and support to experiment, collaborate and grow their professional careers. From glass, metal and ceramics to textiles and contemporary design, the residents featured here are not only shaping objects – they are shaping culture.  

In this context, to “meet your maker” is to engage with the processes, politics and poetics of craft and design today. It’s a chance to stand face to face with emerging visionaries who transform raw mate

We are a cornerstone of Canada’s craft landscape, a rare incubator where artists have the time, space and support to experiment, collaborate and grow their professional careers. From glass, metal and ceramics to textiles and contemporary design, the residents featured here are not only shaping objects – they are shaping culture.  

In this context, to “meet your maker” is to engage with the processes, politics and poetics of craft and design today. It’s a chance to stand face to face with emerging visionaries who transform raw mate

event_description:
Discover how homes shape identity through the Austin family story and contemporary art at Spadina Museum. Reimagine history, reframe home.

“Home at Spadina Museum” considers how people are influenced by their home. We look at those who make it a home and those who live in it are shaped by domestic spaces. Through interpretation of the Austin family and into contemporary art, we will analyze what makes a home. Re-Imagining the Historic House Museum: A Workplace for Women. 

Step into “Home at Spadina Museum” and explore how homes are shaped by the people who live and work in them. From the Austin family to contemporary art, discover untold stories of women’s labour, care, and community. Reimagine the historic house as both a home and a workplace.

As you explore the exhibition, we invite you to reflect: "What does home mean to you?"

We are grateful to our community partners, Augusto Bitter and the Women’s Art Association of Canada.
event_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Home at Spadina Museum

event_description:
A quiet lake in Ontario is making a lot of noise.

Sediments from the bottom of a small lake in Ontario are revealing a remarkable record of our impact on the planet.

Just outside Toronto, Ontario lies Crawford Lake, a significant site offering a unique, comprehensive 1,000-year record of human impacts - local, regional, and global.

event_description:
What makes for a delightful picnic? Food and drink? Poetry? Music? 

Immerse yourself into the pleasures, pastimes, and artistic heritage of Iran during the Safavid dynasty (1501-1736). A royal picnic, depicted on a large, treasured tile arch from the collections, is complemented by exceptional objects from the period.

This free event is sure to get you and your family in the holiday spirit with performances of Christmas classics and festive favourites by vocal students of The Music Studio. Lyric sheets will be provided so that you can sing-along!

Discover unique gifts, enjoy seasonal goodies, along-side the all year round Farmers' Market. Don't miss this once a year special event that brings the Etobicoke community together.

event_description:
Get ready to spice up your Wednesdays this October! In collaboration with the City of Toronto, Salsa in Toronto presents Family Salsa Dance Lessons—a fun, FREE way to get moving with your loved ones. These free lessons are open to all ages and skill levels.

Live instruction provided by Salsa & Sabor.

Join us at the iconic Fort York for an energetic evening of Latin rhythms, family-friendly fun, and salsa dance instruction under the stars. 
No experience or partner required—just bring your dancing shoes and your best moves!
event_name: Family Salsa Dance Lessons at Fort York

short_name: Family Salsa Dance Lessons at Fort York

cost_notes:
Tickets are $18 + HST and are non-refundable but transferable.
Purchase advance tickets online using the City of Toronto's program registrations software. If you do not already have an account, you will need to create one. 
If you have trouble registering, please contact clodge@toronto.ca or call 416-392-6916.
event_description:
Join us for a chilling tour at Colborne Lodge in High Park. 

Visit the gravesite of John and Jemima Howard. Explore ideas about death and the afterlife from the 1800s and hear true tales of paranormal activities. Experience some of the museum’s dark stories if you dare! 

A portion of this event is outside so please dress accordingly. 
Recommended for ages 12 and up. Youth 12-16 must be accompanied by an adult.
event_name: After Dark Tours: The Unexplained at Colborne Lodge

event_description:
Making its North American premiere, the globally celebrated masterpiece reveals the true story of Ip Man, the prestigious grandmaster of the martial art Wing Chun. The story recounts his influence on the martial art from its more than 300-year-old origins in Southern China, to global popularity, and his famous student Bruce Lee.

It features two gripping, inter-woven tales about the relentless pursuit of dreams while incorporating a pulse-pounding blend of acrobatic dance, precision martial arts and cinematic staging with dramatic lighting and breathtaking visuals. 

For audience members ages eight and up.

event_description:
Choreographed by Bessie Award-winning principal dancer Soledad Barrio and artistic director Martín Santangelo, the extraordinary paintings of Francisco de Goya are brought to life through the language of flamenco dance, vocals, and guitar.

Under the direction and choreography of Santangelo, the award-winning Noche Flamenca is recognized as one the world's premier touring companies. 

Formed in 1993 by Santangelo and his wife and principal dancer, Soledad Barrio, the company has toured throughout the globe, including regular seasons in New York City, and performances in North and South America, Europe, and Australia. 

Hailed by critics for its transcendent and deeply emotional performances, Noche Flamenca has successfully brought to the stage the essence, purity, and integrity of one of the world's most complex and mysterious art forms, through a diverse theatrical body of work that expresses a rigorous, spell-binding aesthetic that exceeds the highest artistic expectations.
event_name: Soledad Barrio and Noche Flamenca: Searching for Goya
short_description: Choreographed by Bessie Award-winning principal dancer Soledad Barrio and artistic director Martín Santangelo, the extra
short_name: Soledad Barrio and Noche Flamenca: Searching for Goya

event_description:
Discover Hyunsun Park's captivating collection of gouache paintings that evoke empathy and connection. Each painting is a window into personal and shared experiences-- stories of survival, resilience, and the search for meaning.

Join the Artists for the opening reception on Saturday, August 9, 2 to 4 p.m. Light refreshments provided.

event_description:
Curated by Mikinaak Migwans, Earthwork redefines a term that until now has referred to a type of artistic practice associated within the larger conceptual framework of land art. 

In this exhibition, Migwans shifts our understanding of earthwork to refer to a way of working, rather than the making of singular objects, reclaiming the art historical framing from an Indigenous perspective. It considers multiple layers of engagement with the land, including a history of land defense movements, medicine walks, and ancestral practices of prescribed burns, alongside contemporary art.

Featured artists include Michael Belmore, BUSH Gallery (Gabrielle L’Hirondelle Hill, Peter Morin, Tania Willard), Faye HeavyShield, Art Hunter, Alex Jacobs-Blum, Mike MacDonald, Lisa Myers, Edward Poitras, and Protect the Tract Collective.
event_name: Art Museum at the University of Toronto: Earthwork
short_description: Curated by Mikinaak Migwans, Earthwork redefines a term that until now has referred to a type of artistic practice assoc
short_name: Art Museum at the University of Toronto: Earthwork

event_description:
Laura Piccinin, the creator of "LESBIHONEST", “Every Silver Lining”, and “Apothecary”, and winner of Just for Laughs'  "Outstanding English Comedy Award", brings a new, 90-minute comedic tale of outdoorsy adventure.

In "WOMAN, ALONE" as she dares to walk 336km along the East Coast of Newfoundland. While on her journey of trying not to get killed in the woods, she recounts the stories of her life, and the decisions she’s made in the face of danger (real or perceived) along the way. This sentimental and hilarious show reminds audiences to get out of their own way and GO do that thing that they really, really want to do.
short_description: Laura Piccinin, the creator of "LESBIHONEST", “Every Silver Lining”, and “Apothecary”, and winner of Just for Laughs'  "

event_description:
In the chaos of urban life, we often forget to take a moment to breathe. Take in a moment of stillness, as we inviting visitors to stand beneath something that feels alive.

The outdoor installation, made from a suspended grid of copper leaves, reimagines the shelter of a forest canopy with each leaf individually cut and hung to form a floating canopy above. By day, the leaves catch the light and scatter soft shadows across the ground. By night, lighting transforms the installation, casting intricate patterns on surrounding surfaces and shifting the atmosphere of the space entirely. As wind moves through the piece, the leaves gently sway and rustle, adding a subtle layer of sound to the experience.

Responding to its surroundings and shifting with the light, weather and movement of people passing beneath it, this work offers a dynamic and reflective space in the heart of the city. 

Designed by RAW Works, with Roland Rom Colthoff, Suleman Khan, Elmira Yousefi and Aaron Hendershot.

event_description:
A quiet lake in Ontario is making a lot of noise.

Sediments from the bottom of a small lake in Ontario are revealing a remarkable record of our impact on the planet.

Just outside Toronto, Ontario lies Crawford Lake, a significant site offering a unique, comprehensive 1,000-year record of human impacts - local, regional, and global.
short_description:

event_description:
Beginning July 1st at Scarborough Museum, experience Washed Up by Hatecopy. The project captures the essence of liminal spaces that serve as cultural hubs for the South Asian immigrant communities, using the washing machine as a vessel to carry textiles that signify our roots and drawing visitors into an environment that intertwines the past, present, and future; acknowledging the dirty laundry of Canadian History and “Truth,” and reclaiming both seen and unseen spaces.

Maria Qamar (b. 1991) is a Toronto-based pop artist whose work is focused in the South Asian diaspora and immigrant communities and their cultural experiences. The work specializes in themes regarding feminism, social change, humour, pop culture, politics and romance. The artist has been recognized both nationally and internationally with exhibits and features in the Museum of Contemporary Arts, the National Arts Centre, Sotheby’s, Phillips Auction, and the AGO.
event_name: Washed Up: Pop-Up Installation at Scarborough Museum

short_name: Washed Up: Pop-Up Installation at Scarborough Museum

event_description:
Step into the glow, we're back for the sixth year! 

This year, guests can explore the magic like never before with a brand-new layout that lets you move freely between the immersive light show and Pumpkinville at your own pace. Wander through the illuminated maze of over 1.5 million LED and RGB lights, then pop into a vibrant fall fair featuring all new glowing photo ops, installations, midway rides, carnival games, and over 15,000 pumpkins. With new scenes, dazzling photo moments, and an entirely transformed setup, this is not just a walk, it's an adventure!

event_description:
Celebrate the works of acclaimed Irish playwright, Conor McPherson.

The Weir looks in a small rural pub in the West of Ireland, where local lads spin tales of the supernatural, as they vie for the attention of a young woman who recently moved into the area. Little do they know that she has her own personal and compelling story to weave...

Directed by Co-artistic Producer, Rod Ceballos and features Richard Harte (The Boys in the Photograph), Mairi Babb (WAR HORSE), David Mackett (The Good Thief), and Enda Reilly (Toronto Bloomsday Festival).

event_description:
Making Home in Scarborough is a vibrant pop-up installation celebrating memory, identity, and belonging through cultural traditions and objects we hold dear to our hearts in generations past, present and future. 
 

Co-created through conversation and care, community members were invited to share a meaningful object, rooted in a heartfelt story. All speak to how home is made not only in buildings or borders, but in the places, people, and practices that give life meaning. 
 
As you explore the exhibition, we invite you to reflect: "What does home mean to you?" If you live in Scarborough, "What does Making Home in Scarborough Mean to you?" 
 
We are grateful for our community collaborators: Native Child and Family Services / Scarborough Child & Family Life Centre, Malvern Family Resource Centre, TDSB Newcomer Services (Malvern), Toby's Place, Scarborough Museum Youth Collective and Change Made.
event_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Making Home in Scarborough at Scarborough Museum
short_description: Making Home in Scarborough is a vibrant pop-up installation celebrating memory, identity, and belonging through cultural
short_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Making Home in Scarborough at Scarborough Mu

event_description:
This is a solo exhibition by Ukrainian-Canadian artist Olga Polstvin.

Olga is a multidisciplinary artist, cultural leader, and Master of Arts Leadership candidate at Queen’s University whose practice bridges painting, storytelling, and community engagement. Born in Kyiv, Ukraine, she carries forward the resilience and cultural memory of her heritage, weaving themes of belonging, healing, and identity into her work.
event_name: Through the Lens of Ukrainian Belonging

Olga is a multidisciplinary artist, cultural lead

event_description:
Get ready to spice up your Wednesdays this October! In collaboration with the City of Toronto, Salsa in Toronto presents Family Salsa Dance Lessons—a fun, FREE way to get moving with your loved ones. These free lessons are open to all ages and skill levels.

Live instruction provided by Salsa & Sabor.

Join us at the iconic Fort York for an energetic evening of Latin rhythms, family-friendly fun, and salsa dance instruction under the stars. 
No experience or partner required—just bring your dancing shoes and your best moves!

short_description: Beginning July 1st at Scarborough Museum, experience Washed Up by Hatecopy. The project captures the essence of liminal
short_name: Washed Up: Pop-Up Installation at Scarborough Museum

event_description:
A quiet lake in Ontario is making a lot of noise.

Sediments from the bottom of a small lake in Ontario are revealing a remarkable record of our impact on the planet.

Just outside Toronto, Ontario lies Crawford Lake, a significant site offering a unique, comprehensive 1,000-year record of human impacts - local, regional, and global.

event_description:
What makes for a delightful picnic? Food and drink? Poetry? Music? 

Immerse yourself into the pleasures, pastimes, and artistic heritage of Iran during the Safavid dynasty (1501-1736). A royal picnic, depicted on a large, treasured tile arch from the collections, is complemented by exceptional objects from the period.

event_description: Join the Ontario Society of Artists in honoring its Life Members, acknowledging their significant contributions to both the Society and the wider art community. These distinguished members actively teach, exhibit their work, sustain their artistic practices and generously volunteer their time. Representing diverse disciplines, including painting, sculpture, printmaking and photography, the Life Members embody the creative spirit and dedication that enrich the arts.
event_name: Celebrating the Art of the Ontario Society of Artists Life Members
short_description: Join the Ontario Society of Artists in honoring its Life Members, acknowledging their significant contributions to both
short_name: Celebrating the Art of the Ontario Society of Artists Life M

event_description:
A site-specific mural by Winnipeg-based artist Anna Binta Diallo, exploring themes of time, memory and interdependence through the metaphor of fossils. Using silhouettes of human forms assembled from found images, Diallo creates a visual narrative on the interconnectedness of the past, present and future. 

Originally exhibited at the Musée d’art contemporain de Montréal, it invites viewers to reflect on how contemporary actions and objects will serve as relics for future generations, emphasizing the importance and responsibility of shaping collective heritage.
