event_description:
12 Sessions | 6 Players | 1 Campaign

What happens when the world’s best improvisers decide to play an actual Dungeons & Dragons campaign, live on stage? You get The Roll Players, a show with authentic storytelling, where characters grow, laugh, and die (hopefully), with belly busting comedy created from the chaos! 

Dungeon Master: Kris Siddiqi
Players: Andy Hull, Sarah Hillier & Sharjil Rasool
NPCs: Aurora Browne, Lisa Merchant & Paul Bates

event_description:
Step into an immersive visual experience where material becomes memory, and memory becomes art. 

A compelling mixed media art exhibition that explores emotion, expression, and the sense of belonging through abstract and landscape works. From fragmented shorelines to colour-washed horizons and textured echoes of time, the exhibition invites viewers into a space of contemplation and connection, where personal and collective memories surface through layered materials and imaginative forms.

event_description:
A celebration of the city’s passion for basketball and the remarkable stories of legendary players who changed the game. Join us and experience basketball history come to life through augmented reality, where you can custom design your own basketball jersey.

Even before the Toronto Raptors and the rallying cry, “We the North” became a slogan, for over a century, basketball in Toronto was deeply rooted in the evolving social and cultural conditions of our city and its people.  

From the Canadian invention of basketball to the early women’s game in 1895, to the first professional basketball game played by the short-lived Toronto Huskies in 1946, and the recent creation of the Toronto Tempo WNBA team, these and many other milestones chart the sport’s development in the city.
short_description: A celebration of the city’s passion for basketball and the remarkable stories of legendary players who changed the game.

event_description:
A celebration of the city’s passion for basketball and the remarkable stories of legendary players who changed the game. Join us and experience basketball history come to life through augmented reality, where you can custom design your own basketball jersey.

Even before the Toronto Raptors and the rallying cry, “We the North” became a slogan, for over a century, basketball in Toronto was deeply rooted in the evolving social and cultural conditions of our city and its people.  

From the Canadian invention of basketball to the early women’s game in 1895, to the first professional basketball game played by the short-lived Toronto Huskies in 1946, and the recent creation of the Toronto Tempo WNBA team, these and many other milestones chart the sport’s development in the city.
short_description: A celebration of the city’s passion for basketball and the remarkable stories of legendary players who changed the game.

event_description:
Experience a guided sound journey that sparks joy, connection and play through music and movement. Participants will wear headphones and enter a soundscape that blends music, story and guided exploration, inviting you to listen, move and feel together.  

In an era marked by disconnection, loneliness and social division, Reset offers a counter-experience: one rooted in curiosity, shared presence and delight. The work draws on traditions of street theatre, sound art and community ritual to create a space where strangers can become participants, and where every day public space is transformed into a site of collective effervescence.

event_description: Step into the past and discover what school was like in Upper Canada in the early 1800s! Back then, only a few children could go to class and one-room schoolhouses were the center of learning. Who got to go and when did schools finally become free for everyone? Come find out as you explore the skills kids once learned; reading, writing, and practical lessons for everyday life. Try your hand at printing letters in a sand tray, then progress to writing on a slate just like real students did long ago. A fun, hands-on adventure for kids, teens, and families!

event_description:
Choreographed by Bessie Award-winning principal dancer Soledad Barrio and artistic director Martín Santangelo, the extraordinary paintings of Francisco de Goya are brought to life through the language of flamenco dance, vocals, and guitar.

Under the direction and choreography of Santangelo, the award-winning Noche Flamenca is recognized as one the world's premier touring companies. 

Formed in 1993 by Santangelo and his wife and principal dancer, Soledad Barrio, the company has toured throughout the globe, including regular seasons in New York City, and performances in North and South America, Europe, and Australia. 

Hailed by critics for its transcendent and deeply emotional performances, Noche Flamenca has successfully brought to the stage the essence, purity, and integrity of one of the world's most complex and mysterious art forms, through a diverse theatrical body of work that expresses a rigorous, spell-binding aesthetic that exceeds the highest artistic expectations.
event_name: Soledad Barrio and Noche Flamenca: Searching for Goya
short_description: Choreographed by Bessie Award-winning principal dancer Soledad Barrio and artistic director Martín Santangelo, the extra
short_name: Soledad Barrio and Noche Flamenca: Searching for Goya

The Sumi-e Artists of Canada invite you to join us for our Annual Exhibition of Japanese Ink Paintings. 

Our exhibit will feature a large collection of over one hundred traditional Japanese style watercolour paintings contributed by dozens of local artists. Guests will have the opportunity to view the gallery, meet the artists, purchase paintings, attend demonstrations, and relax in our tearoom where sushi and other snacks will be available.

event_description:
Toronto’s Favourite Holiday Panto Returns!

Get ready to root for the underdog and boo the baddies! This year, the legendary outlaw tale takes on a bold twist - our Robin is a spirited, savvy heroine leading her merry band of misfits in a fight for justice and kindness.  

Join Robin and her friends on a medieval romp through merry old Torontoshire! Journey through the lush forests of High Park, go head-to-head with the greedy Prince John, and rescue those in need - all with a hearty dose of laughter, pop hits, and plenty of surprises. 

Robin Hood delivers all the Panto fun you love, a sparkling spoof on a classic tale, hilarious comedy, dazzling musical numbers, and an intergenerational celebration that's perfect for the whole family.  

Grab your loved ones, don your green tights, and join us for a experience full of mischief, melody, and meaning.
event_name: Robin Hood: A Very Merry Family Musical
short_description:
Toronto’s Favourite Holiday Panto Returns!

short_name: Robin Hood: A Very Merry Family Musical

event_description:
Two of Canada’s greatest pianists perform exquisite repertoire for two pianos by Mozart, Chopin, and Gershwin.

Described by the New York Times as “A performer of near-superhuman technical prowess”, Marc-André Hamelin is known worldwide for his unrivaled blend of consummate musicianship and brilliant technique in the great works of the established repertoire, as well as for his intrepid exploration of the rarities of the 19th, 20th, and 21st centuries.

Silver medalist and laureate of the Krystian Zimerman Prize at the 2015 International Chopin Piano Competition in Warsaw, Charles Richard-Hamelin stands out as one of the most important musicians of his generation. 

Please join us! This concert is preceded by a short performance by talented students of The Royal Conservatory.
event_name: Marc-André Hamelin with Charles Richard-Hamelin, duo piano
short_description:
Two of Canada’s greatest pianists perform exquisite repertoire for two pianos by Mozart, Chopin, and Gershwin.

short_name: Marc-André Hamelin with Charles Richard-Hamelin, duo piano

event_description:
Admired for his artistic style, unique interpretations and vibrant tone, Hungarian-born violinist Moshe Hammer was raised in Israel and studied there with Ilona Feher. As a student of Jascha Heifetz he was a medal winner at the Concours Jacques Thibaud in Paris.

Moshe’s tours have taken him across North America, Europe, Israel and the Far-East. His performances have consistently energized critics, thrilled audiences and earned respect among his colleagues.

A naturalized Canadian, Moshe has played in concert venues around the world and performed with many symphony orchestras. He has been the founder and leader of the Toronto based chamber group, The Amadeus Ensemble. As a member of Da Camera, he has thrilled audiences in Canada, the US and Europe with regular visits to the Netherlands.
event_name: Moshe Hammer Farewell tour, with Angela Park
short_description: Admired for his artistic style, unique interpretations and vibrant tone, Hungarian-born violinist Moshe Hammer was raise
short_name: Moshe Hammer Farewell tour, with Angela Park

event_description:
Welcoming audiences into an energetic visions of stories where memory, resistance, and imagination intertwine. 

This year’s line-up follows the rhythms of identity, from the pulsing beats of Afro-Antillean music to the quiet landscapes of childhood wonder to journeys across mountains, cities, and deserts in search of home and the intimate crossings of generations, friendships and dreams. 

In these films, rupture gives way to transformation, and every frame holds the promise of renewal. We honour voices that refuse to be silenced, visions that reshape reality, and connections that reach across borders. 

This is both a celebration and a reflection, a space where stories become bridges, and where watching together creates imagination and opens innovation.
event_name: aluCine Latin Film and Media Arts Festival Toronto
short_description:

short_name: aluCine Latin Film and Media Arts Festival Toronto

event_description:
The must-see event of the Halloween season is back! From the creators of the sold-out sensation, Tales of the Grotesque (2023 - 2024), comes a new anthology of gothic horror. Experience what critics call a “devilish delight!” With fresh characters, familiar tales, and unique terrors, we bring literature’s most depraved characters to life… and death.

After a lady of the night is murdered, a mad doctor strikes a pact with the Devil to raise her from the dead. But when he comes face-to-face with her killer at a masquerade, all hell breaks loose. Descend into madness with Victor Frankenstein, Henry Jekyll, and Dorian Gray as they discover the consequences of playing God and the monstrous repercussions when the Devil comes to collect. 

An immersive horror opera set within the oldest surviving building from the Town of York, we invite you to explore Victorian Toronto through the eyes of history’s most disturbed authors, though it might just cost your soul.
short_description: The must-see event of the Halloween season is back! From the creators of the sold-out sensation, Tales of the Grotesque

cost_notes: General admission (including touring the museum buildings, food sampling and craft activities) is free / does not require advanced tickets. Some workshops are ticketed - see additional listings for further details.
event_description:
Join Scarborough Museum for a Season of Celebration! Embrace the spirit of light, love, and joy through a series of family-friendly activities centered on food, culture, and storytelling.  

Enjoy gingerbread decorating, family-friendly winter crafts and weekly workshops led by guest facilitators, including chair yoga, henna and more! See additional listings for more details. 

Community Feature: Sample a rotating selection of warm drinks and finger foods from around the world, curated by the Scarborough Museum Youth Collective and participants of Scarborough Museum’s Newcomer Storytelling Circles. Try something new or enjoy an old favourite, learn more about the stories behind these sips and bites, and share your own stories of light and warmth in our community jar!  

Treats will be available first come-first served, while quantities last.
event_name: Season of Celebration at Scarborough Museum
short_description: Join Scarborough Museum for a Season of Celebration! Embrace the spirit of light, love, and joy through a series of fami
short_name: Season of Celebration at Scarborough Museum

event_description:
In commemoration of the 80th anniversary of the end of World War II and the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. 

The series consists of 29 posters, headed by KAMEKURA Yūsaku’s masterpiece “Burning Butterflies” 1983, continued with an unbroken sequence of works of high artistic excellence. 

In addition, 49 posters will be displayed with global messages from our collection, and Toronto’s poster collection accompany the Hiroshima Appeals posters, focusing on the shared unique nature of their design creation in being non-commercial, abstract, conceptual, and reflecting on global issues and subjects.
event_name: Hiroshima Appeals: A Poster Exhibition of Global Messages
short_description: In commemoration of the 80th anniversary of the end of World War II and the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.
short_name: Hiroshima Appeals: A Poster Exhibition of Global Messages

event_description:
Photography omes alive with dance, music, and spoken word performances. Nine photographic artists join together with professionals in the fields of dance, poetry, drama, and music to present an afternoon of visual art with Ekphrasis performances in response to the photographs. 

Photographic artists are Linda Briskin, Brianna Caryll, Lucie Collins, Martha Davis, Vivian East, Kye Marshall, Jana Skarecky, Patricia Stamp, and Henrietta Walmark.

Performers responding to the visual works are dancer Brianna Clarke, musicians Taivi Alexander, Kye Marshall and Jana Skarecky, dramatists Angie Littlefield and Annie Rosenberg and poets Kate Marshall Flaherty, Bianca Lakoseljac, JC Sulzenko and Donna Wootton.
short_description: Photography omes alive with dance, music, and spoken word performances. Nine photographic artists join together with pro

event_description:
Join Scarborough Museum for a Season of Celebration! Embrace the spirit of light, love, and joy through a series of family-friendly activities centered on food, culture, and storytelling.  

Enjoy gingerbread decorating, family-friendly winter crafts and weekly workshops led by guest facilitators, including chair yoga, henna and more! See additional listings for more details. 

Community Feature: Sample a rotating selection of warm drinks and finger foods from around the world, curated by the Scarborough Museum Youth Collective and participants of Scarborough Museum’s Newcomer Storytelling Circles. Try something new or enjoy an old favourite, learn more about the stories behind these sips and bites, and share your own stories of light and warmth in our community jar!  

Treats will be available first come-first served, while quantities last.
event_name: Season of Celebration at Scarborough Museum

event_description:
Toronto has one of the largest urban forests in the world. Join the City of Toronto Urban Forestry staff for an in-library presentation on this amazing natural habitat that reaches all corners of Toronto.

We'll talk about what makes the urban forest so special and share tools to explore and understand it better. Bring questions and curiosities and leave with emboldened confidence and understanding of you City and the natural world that surrounds you!

No registration. Drop-in.

Toronto Public Library is committed to accessibility. Please call or email us if you are Deaf or have a disability and would like to request an accommodation to participate in this program. Please let us know as far in advance as possible and we will do our best to meet your request. At least least weeks' notice is preferred. Phone (416)393-7099 or email accessibleservices@tpl.ca
short_description: Toronto has one of the largest urban forests in the world. Join the City of Toronto Urban Forestry staff for an in-libra

event_description:
Join us as we celebrate the vibrant, dreamlike worlds of this Korean-Canadian artist, whose work invites quiet reflection and a deep connection to life’s dynamic flow.  

Ellee SY Lee is a Korean-Canadian artist whose semi-abstract landscape paintings explore a range of visual and emotional experiences. Immigrating to Canada as a teenager, she quickly discovered a love for art-making, with painting becoming a powerful and liberating way to connect with her subconscious and emotions.
event_name: Exhibition "In the Rhythm of Being" by Ellee SY Lee

event_description:
Celebrate music in the contexts of death, grief, comfort and healing.

We are excited to invite you to an evening of live music and community.

Music can comfort, inspire, and bring us together when words alone fall short. This is an opportunity to connect, reflect, and share in music’s impact.

Set in a warm and welcoming atmosphere, we're featuring multi-disciplinary performers including SarahRose Black, musician, clinician, and researcher, Gabi Epstein, Broadway and theatre vocalist, Mark Camelleri, pianist, arranger and Broadway music director and Jeremy Lapalme, actor and vocalist for film, television, and theatre

We are also delighted to share that Charles Osborne, musician and composer, will serve as Master of Ceremonies.

event_description: Introducing “Hidden Toronto” – the new light-hearted walking tour from the creators of The Haunted Walk that’s gonna have you chuckling with laughter and shaking your head in disbelief. Join our crew of storytelling guides as we take you on a 90-minute adventure through the hidden side of Toronto. From movie mistakes to our infamous clown riot, these fun tales of mischief and mayhem make up the fascinating story of our city. Guffaw and gasp through the city’s streets as our fun and engaging tour guides spill the beans on those little-known stories and secrets that define Toronto’s hidden personality. “Hidden Toronto” is a fun and engaging good-natured adventure, perfect for first-time visitors and locals alike.
short_description: Introducing “Hidden Toronto” – the new light-hearted walking tour from the creators of The Haunted Walk that’s gonna hav

cost_notes: All participants must be 16 or older.
event_description: Join us for a spine-chilling paranormal adventure where intimate groups of 12 or fewer will have exclusive access to investigate haunted heritage buildings – including the notorious Half Way House – in the dark! Feel the chill of the night and listen to the whispers of the past as we employ ancient and modern techniques to attempt to establish contact with the lingering spirits that call the Village home. ‘Alone in the Dark’ is as real as it gets, nothing is hidden or staged. This unforgettably eerie evening will delight ghost story enthusiasts, fearless paranormal investigators, history aficionados, urban explorers, and anyone with a curiosity about the unknown. Book your spot now—spaces fill fast! All participants must be 16 or older.
event_name: Alone in the Dark – The Village at Black Creek

event_description:
You are invited into the beating heart of contemporary craft and design, a space where tradition meets bold reinvention, and where the maker’s hand is ever-present. 

Through the exceptional work of our current Artists-in-Residence, this exhibition explores the enduring relevance of skilled making in a world dominated by speed, automation and disposability. 

We are a cornerstone of Canada’s craft landscape, a rare incubator where artists have the time, space and support to experiment, collaborate and grow their professional careers. From glass, metal and ceramics to textiles and contemporary design, the residents featured here are not only shaping objects – they are shaping culture.  

In this context, to “meet your maker” is to engage with the processes, politics and poetics of craft and design today. It’s a chance to stand face to face with emerging visionaries who transform raw mate
short_description: You are invited into the beating heart of contemporary craft and design, a space where tradition meets bold reinvention,

event_description:
Step into an immersive visual experience where material becomes memory, and memory becomes art. 

A compelling mixed media art exhibition that explores emotion, expression, and the sense of belonging through abstract and landscape works. From fragmented shorelines to colour-washed horizons and textured echoes of time, the exhibition invites viewers into a space of contemplation and connection, where personal and collective memories surface through layered materials and imaginative forms.

This pop-up installation explores the compelling stories and experiences of Toronto’s diverse communities who have fought for their sense of home, belonging and identity during periods of conflict and peace.

event_description:
One of the longest running markets of its kind in Toronto, opening annually for 46 years. With its rich and storied history, the market has become a staple event that the Weston community enjoys visiting every year. Generations of families have visited to enjoy some farm fresh produce, dairy, meats, eggs and finely prepared foods, as well as local artisans showcasing their work to the community.

We look forward to welcoming new friends to join us!
short_description: One of the longest running markets of its kind in Toronto, opening annually for 46 years. With its rich and storied hist

event_description:
A site-specific mural by Winnipeg-based artist Anna Binta Diallo, exploring themes of time, memory and interdependence through the metaphor of fossils. Using silhouettes of human forms assembled from found images, Diallo creates a visual narrative on the interconnectedness of the past, present and future. 

Originally exhibited at the Musée d’art contemporain de Montréal, it invites viewers to reflect on how contemporary actions and objects will serve as relics for future generations, emphasizing the importance and responsibility of shaping collective heritage.
short_description: A site-specific mural by Winnipeg-based artist Anna Binta Diallo, exploring themes of time, memory and interdependence t

event_description:
Born in Taiwan and raised in Australia, Ray Chen was accepted to the Curtis Institute of Music at age 15 and captured the world’s attention as first prize winner of both the Yehudi Menuhin and Queen Elizabeth Competitions. Profiled as “one to watch” by The Strad and Gramophone magazines, his profile has grown to be featured in the Forbes list of 30 Most Influential Asians under 30, and appearances in the TV series Mozart in the Jungle. He plays the 1715 “Joachim” Stradivarius violin, once owned by the famed Hungarian violinist, Joseph Joachim. 

Praised as a musician of "compelling artistry and power" by the Seattle Times, the gifted American pianist Julio Elizalde has appeared with many of the leading artists of our time.
event_name: Violinist Ray Chen with Pianist Julio Elizalde

short_name: Violinist Ray Chen with Pianist Julio Elizalde

event_description: Experience the magic of the season with a tour of Spadina Museum by lamplight. See the lavish 55-room mansion fully decorated for the holidays, just as it was in the 1920s. An experienced guide will lead you through this rare opportunity to explore the house by night. As you arrive, take in a 1920s silent film and enjoy a glass of non-alcoholic punch recreated from a historic recipe. Light up the season with the magic of the winter solstice, spreading joy, peace and festive cheer at Toronto History Museums!
event_name: Holiday Lamplight Tours at Spadina Museum

short_name: Holiday Lamplight Tours at Spadina Museum

event_description:
Join Shrek and friends for a holiday you’ll never forget!

Enjoy the humour, heart, and hijinks of this ogre-sized production. Bursting with catchy tunes, laugh-out-loud moments, and featuring a kaleidoscopic crew of fairy tale misfits – a wisecracking donkey, a fierce warrior princess, a pint-sized villain, and even a cookie with an attitude. 

It’s a fun-filled adventure for the whole family, celebrating friendship and the joy of finding your true self. Based on the smash-hit Oscar-winning film, this charmingly cheeky romp in the swamp reminds us that even in a world divided, we’re all in this together.

Enjoy the humour, heart, and hijinks of this ogre-sized produ

event_description:
Every year, responding to pressure to work outside their home countries, temporary migrant workers come to Canada to complete essential work that sustains the Canadian economy and communities; harvesting produce, caring for families, constructing houses, cooking meals, and more.

Most Canadians know nothing of the exploitation many migrant workers face.

With input and collaboration of former and current migrant farmworkers, you are invited to this forum theatre production about the experience of migrant farmworkers in Ontario.

This is an interactive presentation that was created through interviews and conversations with migrant workers who shared their experiences. After seeing the play, audiences will be invited to discuss the issues, direct the actors, or roleplay their ideas to discover how we can all create positive change.
event_name: Harvest Justice: Twice the Speed of Lightning
short_description: Every year, responding to pressure to work outside their home countries, temporary migrant workers come to Canada to com
short_name: Harvest Justice: Twice the Speed of Lightning

Learn the basics of this art technique, including the different methods like intentional pouring, flip cup, paint blowing and more.

All materials provided, including snacks and refreshments.

Must be ages 12 and up to participate. All minor participants must be accompanied by a paying adult.

event_description:
Unlock the secrets to making these delightful French pastries. 

In this class you will learn how to prepare choux pastry and identify the key steps in perfecting your mixture, the technique used to perfectly pipe profiteroles, éclairs, and a demonstration of the Paris Brest. You will be shown the ideal baking technique to ensure your choux has the best texture, how to prepare the perfect pastry cream, how to fill your choux pastry, and the secret to preparing a glossy chocolate ganache.
event_name: Eclairs, Choux Pastry and Cream Puff Masterclass
short_description:
Unlock the secrets to making these delightful French pastries. 

In this class you will learn how to prepare choux pastr
short_name: Eclairs, Choux Pastry and Cream Puff Masterclass

event_description:
Enjoy a wonderfully varied program of music from three eras and four places - Canada, England, France and Vienna. 

Maestro Arman leads the orchestra in Elgar's lyrical Serenade, the world premiere of a folk-inspired Sinfonietta by Montreal composer Petros Shoujounian. This will be the first performance of Toronto composer Colin Eatock's beautiful settings of poems by Bengali literary icon Rabindranath Tagore, a famous Romantic solo violin showpiece and a lush orchestral version of Beethoven's famous Pathétique sonata. Two exciting young Canadian soloists will be presented - soprano Kripa Nageshwar will perform the Eatock songs, and violinist Evan Pyne will appear in Saint-Saëns' brilliant Romantic virtuoso show-stopper, the Introduction and Rondo Capriccioso.
short_description:
Enjoy a wonderfully varied program of music from three eras and four places - Canada, England, France and Vienna. 

Maes

cost_notes: Registration begins on December 11 at 9 a.m.
event_description:
I’m So Glad We Had This Time Together, by 2024 Toronto Book Award winner Maurice Vellekoop, is a graphic memoir tracing his journey from a queer boy in a strict Christian home to a renowned artist. Set in 1970s Toronto, it delves into family, faith, sexuality, and art’s transformative power, blending humor and poignancy. This event will be moderated by Chris Middleton.

By the Lake Book Club hosts six Tuesday-night events from February to December with top Canadian authors and Humber Polytechnics alumni. Each in-person event features readings, discussions, Q&A, book signings, and ASL interpretation, while virtual sessions include live subtitles and audio access.
event_name: I’m So Glad We Had This Time Together by Maurice Vellekoop – By the Lake Book Club
short_description: I’m So Glad We Had This Time Together, by 2024 Toronto Book Award winner Maurice Vellekoop, is a graphic memoir tracing
short_name: I’m So Glad We Had This Time Together by Maurice Vellekoop –

event_description:
This is a contemporary form of environmental art created by artists who are  concerned about reducing waste, recycling, and making the world a better place, while raising awareness about environmental changes.

 It aims to showcases the beauty and creativity of using recycled, environmentally friendly or sustainable materials to create phenomenal artwork, using water-based paints, natural pigments and recycled materials to name a few elements. lt is art that advocates for the planet, catering to all ages and present in various mediums, including paintings, sculptures or fashion.

Presenting our second annual art exhibition, we will be utilizing selected artists to mentor African and Caribbean communities on the positioning of multicultural history and art within the Canadian cultural landscape.

event_description:
Share silliness this holiday season! 

Enjoy a rollicking comedy extravaganza for kids, parents, grandparents, aunts, uncles, and reindeer of all ages! Packed with fun and festive songs, sketches, and ridiculous improv hijinks, this one-of-a-kind interactive theatrical experience invites audience members, young and old, the chance to enjoy the comedy fun both from their seats and by joining performers onstage! Make hilarious holiday memories with us!

event_description:
Join us for an informative session on Cultural Hotspot's SPARK and Signature Funding grants. We're excited to offer this opportunity for artists, creatives, artist collectives, grassroots and resident-led groups and small to midsized community organizations based in, or who may have been displaced from, living or working in Kingston-Galloway/Orton Park (KGO) for any reason. We are offering up to $9,000 for SPARK projects and up to $20,000 for Signature projects.

During a session, participants will learn about the objectives and eligibility criteria of SPARK and Signature Funding, gain insights into the application process, including tips for crafting a competitive proposal, hear success stories from past grant recipients and learn from their experiences, engage in a Q&A session with the Cultural Hotspot team to clarify any doubts or queries, network with fellow KGO artists, creatives and art administrators to foster collaboration and community building.
event_name: Cultural Hotspot SPARK & Signature Funding: Information Sessions

Our performers will have you singing and laughing along as they put their own spin on classic songs and entertain you with their hilarious stand-up routines. Sunday Funday at Backroom Comedy Club is the perfect way to unwind after a long week.

event_description:
Welcome to Le Dolci’s exclusive 5-day Parisian Baking Series: Desserts from Paris! Perfect for beginners, this hands-on course runs 5 hours daily (plus a 30-minute lunch) and teaches the art of French pastry.

Day 1: Master fruit and chocolate tarts.
Day 2: Create flaky croissants and pain au chocolat.
Day 3: Learn enriched doughs like brioche and babka.
Day 4: Pipe and fill éclairs and cream puffs with choux pastry.
Day 5: Perfect macarons and soufflés.

Guided by expert chefs, you'll gain practical skills and pastry theory. Join us and bring the sweet taste of Paris to life!
short_description: Welcome to Le Dolci’s exclusive 5-day Parisian Baking Series: Desserts from Paris! Perfect for beginners, this hands-on

event_description:
In the chaos of urban life, we often forget to take a moment to breathe. Take in a moment of stillness, as we inviting visitors to stand beneath something that feels alive.

The outdoor installation, made from a suspended grid of copper leaves, reimagines the shelter of a forest canopy with each leaf individually cut and hung to form a floating canopy above. By day, the leaves catch the light and scatter soft shadows across the ground. By night, lighting transforms the installation, casting intricate patterns on surrounding surfaces and shifting the atmosphere of the space entirely. As wind moves through the piece, the leaves gently sway and rustle, adding a subtle layer of sound to the experience.

Responding to its surroundings and shifting with the light, weather and movement of people passing beneath it, this work offers a dynamic and reflective space in the heart of the city. 

Designed by RAW Works, with Roland Rom Colthoff, Suleman Khan, Elmira Yousefi and Aaron Hendershot.

event_description:
Celebrating art, nature and community.

Featuring over 70 original artworks created outdoors at Toronto Botanical Garden and Edwards Gardens, this curated, site-specific show invites visitors to experience the gardens through the eyes of the artists who paint here, capturing moments of light, movement, and the essence of the natural world.
event_name: Essence of the Garden: Plein Air Art Exhibition and Sale

event_description:
Join us for an in-depth conversation between artist Rosalie Favell, art historian Michelle McGeough, and Ryan Rice, Executive Director and Curator, Indigenous Art at Onsite Gallery.

In conjunction with the exhibition Rosalie Favell | Belonging (1982–2024), this special event delves into the expansive forty-year artistic journey of Rosalie Favell through dialogue centered on her lens-based practice. The conversation will reflect on the curated works featured in the retrospective that foreground themes of identity, belonging, personal discovery, and the complex intersections of Indigenous, 2SLGBTQ+ and Canadian experiences and histories.
event_name: I Searched Many Worlds: In Conversation with Rosalie Favell
short_description: Join us for an in-depth conversation between artist Rosalie Favell, art historian Michelle McGeough, and Ryan Rice, Exec
short_name: I Searched Many Worlds: In Conversation with Rosalie Favell

event_description: Born in Hamilton, Ontario to parents of Nova Scotian descent, Garnet Rogers spent many hours in front of the old floor model radio listening to Grand Ol' Opry broadcasts and harmonizing with his brother, the late folk legend Stan Rogers. Two years later, Garnet was playing the definitive 8-year-old's version of Desolation Row on his ukulele. He soon abandoned that instrument to teach himself the flute, violin and guitar.
short_description: Born in Hamilton, Ontario to parents of Nova Scotian descent, Garnet Rogers spent many hours in front of the old floor m

event_description:
Experience a guided sound journey that sparks joy, connection and play through music and movement. Participants will wear headphones and enter a soundscape that blends music, story and guided exploration, inviting you to listen, move and feel together.  

In an era marked by disconnection, loneliness and social division, Reset offers a counter-experience: one rooted in curiosity, shared presence and delight. The work draws on traditions of street theatre, sound art and community ritual to create a space where strangers can become participants, and where every day public space is transformed into a site of collective effervescence.

event_description:
Making its North American premiere, the globally celebrated masterpiece reveals the true story of Ip Man, the prestigious grandmaster of the martial art Wing Chun. The story recounts his influence on the martial art from its more than 300-year-old origins in Southern China, to global popularity, and his famous student Bruce Lee.

It features two gripping, inter-woven tales about the relentless pursuit of dreams while incorporating a pulse-pounding blend of acrobatic dance, precision martial arts and cinematic staging with dramatic lighting and breathtaking visuals. 

For audience members ages eight and up.

It features two gripping, inter-woven tales about the relentless pursuit of dreams while incorporating a pulse-pounding blend of acrobatic dance, precision martial arts and cinematic staging with dramatic lighting and breathtaking visuals. 

For audience members ages eight and up.

event_description:
The past never really stays in the past.  

A group of old classmates self-declared the “Multi-Ethnic Reject Group” reunites to pre-game their twentieth high school reunion, but nostalgia quickly turns into something darker. 

As drinks flow and old wounds resurface, they confront the choices that shaped them, the friendships that endured or crumbled, and the presence of something, or someone they can’t escape. 

Sharp, theatrical, and deeply moving, this is a reckoning for elder millennials, caught between who they were, who they’ve become, and the world they never saw coming. When the night ends, will they still recognize themselves?
short_description:
The past never really stays in the past.  

A group of old classmates self-declared the “Multi-Ethnic Reject Group” reun

event_description:
You are invited into the beating heart of contemporary craft and design, a space where tradition meets bold reinvention, and where the maker’s hand is ever-present. 

Through the exceptional work of our current Artists-in-Residence, this exhibition explores the enduring relevance of skilled making in a world dominated by speed, automation and disposability. 

We are a cornerstone of Canada’s craft landscape, a rare incubator where artists have the time, space and support to experiment, collaborate and grow their professional careers. From glass, metal and ceramics to textiles and contemporary design, the residents featured here are not only shaping objects – they are shaping culture.  

In this context, to “meet your maker” is to engage with the processes, politics and poetics of craft and design today. It’s a chance to stand face to face with emerging visionaries who transform raw mate

event_description: Join us for a spine-chilling paranormal adventure where intimate groups of 12 or fewer will have exclusive access to investigate haunted heritage buildings – including the notorious Half Way House – in the dark! Feel the chill of the night and listen to the whispers of the past as we employ ancient and modern techniques to attempt to establish contact with the lingering spirits that call the Village home. ‘Alone in the Dark’ is as real as it gets, nothing is hidden or staged. This unforgettably eerie evening will delight ghost story enthusiasts, fearless paranormal investigators, history aficionados, urban explorers, and anyone with a curiosity about the unknown. Book your spot now—spaces fill fast! All participants must be 16 or older.
event_name: Alone in the Dark – The Village at Black Creek

event_description:
What makes for a delightful picnic? Food and drink? Poetry? Music? 

Immerse yourself into the pleasures, pastimes, and artistic heritage of Iran during the Safavid dynasty (1501-1736). A royal picnic, depicted on a large, treasured tile arch from the collections, is complemented by exceptional objects from the period.

event_description:
This family-friendly exhibition invites you to uncover fresh perspectives, groundbreaking research and the astounding diversity of this ancient group of fishes.

Visitors will delve into the anatomy, behaviour, and history of sharks, from familiar favourites like tiger sharks and great whites to lesser-known species like the dwarf lanternshark—a tiny, light-producing marvel small enough to hold in your hand.

Through dozens of interactives and life-sized models, including a life-size head of the huge extinct Megalodon, join us for a unique look at these magnificent creatures, their habitats, hunting techniques, and the conservation threats that they face.

event_description:
What to Expect: 

Guidance: Experienced instructor, Natasha A, will guide you through this workshop, offering instruction and personalized tips for all individuals. You'll be shown how to make a piece of home decor which can be followed step-by-step, but you'll be encouraged to take what you learn to create a piece unique to you.

Take Home Your Art: Leave the workshop with the sculpture you create. Your piece will take 24 hours to dry, then you can use your after care package to complete your project at your leisure.

Who Should Join: Anyone interested in a therapeutic sculpting experience. Connect with others in an inspiring and intimate setting. Perfect for beginners and seasoned sculptors alike. Let your creativity flow in a serene and supportive environment.

Must be aged 12+ to participate. Participants between the ages of 12-16 years old must be accompanied by at least one 18+ adult.

Please see more Sculpting Workshops here: https://www.artboxstudiogallery.com/sculpting

event_description:
Join Jane Finch Centre's Artists-in-Residence, Taejah Daniel (Coach Milly), Vanna Nguyen and Rod Osei-Nuako (Reezy) for an outdoor art installation at Corner Commons. This Artist-in-Residence is held within Invitations to Better Worlds project and is a collaboration with the Department of Imaginary Affairs and Jane/Finch Centre. Through their residencies, the artists have brought to life their interpretations of a collective vision for better worlds for Jane and Finch. This project is an emergence of community engagement, storytelling, collective liberation, foresight and art. It is a practice in believing better worlds are possible.

A City of Toronto Cultural Hotspot Signature Project.
event_name: Invitations to Better Worlds: Artist Showcase + Meet & Greet

event_description:
Step back in time with a free visit to Spadina Museum, beautifully decorated for a 1920s Christmas. Visitors can enjoy the opulent holiday décor and period ambiance that once filled the home of the wealthy Austin family. Twinkling lights, antique ornaments, and rooms set for a classic Jazz Age celebration bring the spirit of the season to life.
As you stroll through the mansion, interpretive displays offer insights into the lavish holiday traditions of Toronto’s elite in the 1920s. In contrast, visitors will also learn about the experiences of the city’s less fortunate citizens during the same era—those who faced poverty, unemployment, and food insecurity during a time of great social and economic change.
From a grand dining room prepared for a festive feast to modest depictions of how the servants of the household marked the holidays, the experience paints a full picture of a Toronto Christmas in the early 20th century.
event_name: Jazz Age Christmas at Spadina Museum
short_description: Step back in time with a free visit to Spadina Museum, beautifully decorated for a 1920s Christmas. Visitors can enjoy t
short_name: Jazz Age Christmas at Spadina Museum

event_description:
The Southern Netherlands, better known today as Flanders, was home to revolutionary artists. 

These extraordinary painters found new ways to depict reality, portray humanity, and tell stories that created parallels to their world then and to our world today. This large-scale exhibition, featuring over 80 stunning art works and objects, medieval, renaissance, baroque paintings, sculptures and more, offering a doorway to art between 1400 to 1700. 

The exhibition's unique presentation introduces the visitor, through these rare, extraordinary artworks, to stories of enterprising townspeople, prosperous cities, and an ever-developing society.
event_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Masterworks

short_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Mast

event_description:
Did you know E.T. Seton Park was created as part of Ontario's Centennial Celebration along with the Ontario Science Centre? How about the site of a former ski jump? Or a 25' foot high dam with a 30 acre pond that is no longer there?

Join Save OSC and TPUF on Saturday, October 11th at 10 a.m. as we hike from the urban environment of Thorncliffe Park down into the historic West Don ravine and around the natural beauty of the OSC lands. Our narratives will touch on First Nations history in the area, to how the land was settled during colonial times and beyond, including a story of the Underground Railroad. Timber, agriculture and industry leading to the urbanization of the area, with a focus on some of the present community's challenges and opportunities.

Our walk begins at the entrance to E.T. Seton Park (73 Thorncliffe Park Dr.) and continues through the ravine around the OSC lands.

Participants can exit the ravine near the Ontario Science Centre or continue back to the start with us
event_name: Ravine Days Walk with Save Ontario's Science Centre and Thorncliffe Park Urban Farmers
short_description: Did you know E.T. Seton Park was created as part of Ontario's Centennial Celebration along with the Ontario Science Cent
short_name: Ravine Days Walk with Save Ontario's Science Centre and Thor

event_description:
Join Scarborough Museum for Halloween-themed fun on weekends in October! Enjoy a warm drink from the museum's kitchens, then join in on family-friendly Halloween-themed crafts, games and activities all month long. Decorate chilling cupcakes, and spark your imagination with paper crafts, a scavenger hunt, and more! 

Community Feature: sample a rotating selection of sweet treats from across the globe, curated by the Scarborough Museum Youth Collective. Try something new or enjoy an old favourite, learn more about the stories behind these sweets, and share your own sweet stories in our community jar! 

Treats will be available first come-first served, while quantities last.
short_description: Join Scarborough Museum for Halloween-themed fun on weekends in October! Enjoy a warm drink from the museum's kitchens,

event_description:
One of Toronto's oldest holiday traditions. 

First staged here in 1938, this pageant began in St. Martin-in-the-Fields church in London, England in 1928. Queen Elizabeth and her sister Margaret were taken to see it when they were little girls. The story of the Nativity is told through a series of narrated scenes linked by beautiful organ music and carols from an unseen choir.   

Close to 50 volunteers, including babies who take turns playing the role of baby Jesus, perform in the cast. The Church of the Holy Trinity, a 178-year-old architectural treasure, brings its own charm to the show.  ASL interpretation is available on Friday, December 19th.
short_description:
One of Toronto's oldest holiday traditions. 

First staged here in 1938, this pageant began in St. Martin-in-the-Fields

event_description:
This pop-up installation explores the compelling stories and experiences of Toronto’s diverse communities who have fought for their sense of home, belonging and identity during periods of conflict and peace. 

This installation is created in partnership with the Toronto Metropolitan University's Masters of Digital Media program.
event_name: Echoes of Home: Pop-Up Exhibit at Fort York
short_description: This pop-up installation explores the compelling stories and experiences of Toronto’s diverse communities who have
short_name: Echoes of Home: Pop-Up Exhibit at Fort York

event_description: Take a break in Old City Hall’s open-air courtyard — a hidden oasis in the heart of downtown. Bring your lunch, meet up with friends or simply enjoy the peaceful surroundings and heritage architecture. While you're here, look up to spot the clock tower's four gargoyles — part of the original 1899 design and removed in 1938 and reinstalled in 2002 using modern materials.
short_description: Take a break in Old City Hall’s open-air courtyard — a hidden oasis in the heart of downtown. Bring your lunch, meet up

event_description:
Minneapolis-born Cory Wong is best known for his funky guitar work and touring worldwide playing his original music on the biggest stages. 

You may have seen him as a guest with the house band on The Late Show with Stephen Colbert, as well as a member of Vulfpeck and the Fearless Flyers. 

A celebrated artist in his own right, he has released solo albums including last year’s Billboard Top 20 record Motivational Music for the Syncopated Soul, Elevator Music for an Elevated Mood, and, most recently, Live in Amsterdam’ With The Metropole Orkest, which charted at #10 on the Billboard Jazz Chart.

A spoken word poetry program for youth in the Jane and Finch community. Youth will learn the fundamentals of spoken word with Jayda Marley and Naiesha Marques and have the opportunity to present what they have learned at a final showcase for family and friends. 

A City of Toronto Cultural Hotspot Signature Project.

event_description:
Sharks have intrigued humans for as long as we have explored the oceans. The terrifying monster from the movie Jaws is what many might imagine when they think of these animals, but they are far more fascinating and complex than their depiction in popular culture.

This exhibition invites you to uncover fresh perspectives, groundbreaking research, and the astounding diversity of this ancient group of fishes.

Visitors will delve into the anatomy, behaviour, and history of sharks, from familiar favourites like tiger sharks and great whites to lesser-known species like the dwarf lanternshark—a tiny, light-producing marvel small enough to hold in your hand.

event_description:
The Sumi-e Artists of Canada invite you to join us for our Annual Exhibition of Japanese Ink Paintings. 

Our exhibit will feature a large collection of over one hundred traditional Japanese style watercolour paintings contributed by dozens of local artists. Guests will have the opportunity to view the gallery, meet the artists, purchase paintings, attend demonstrations, and relax in our tearoom where sushi and other snacks will be available.

Please join us for an afternoon of making art with butterflies!

Draw mounted Butterfly specimens up close where you can see every stunning detail. Our instructor will lead you through every stage of the creative process with group demonstrations and individual attention. Beginners welcome, all materials provided.

For participants ages 18 and up.

Get ready for the ultimate foodie experience! Treat yourself to delicious food from incredible chefs and raise a glass to being with friends and enjoying life. 

With over 200 exhibits, including Master Chef demos, international cuisine, food trucks, wine tasting, mixology classes, live music, DJ lounge, and dance parties. Indulge in delicious food and drink from some of the city’s top chefs and mixologists. Get ready to chow down and party on!

event_description:
This is our seventh solo exhibition of work by Canadian artist Sarah Anne Johnson.

This journey is presented in two chapters: “Cedar Forest” and “Mountain”. Both series expound on the artist’s “Woodland” series, offering new dimensions and depth to an already impressive body of work. 

“Mountain” offers a quiet, personal reflection on horseback trek through Jasper National Park, while “Cedar Forest” draws viewers into the mesmerizing cedar groves of British Columbia. These series exist in beautiful harmony as a meditation on the natural world, and what it mean means to experience it fully.
event_name: A Mountain and a Forest by Sarah Anne Johnson
short_description:

event_description:
Borders divide, the cosmos unites.

Canadian legend Robert Lepage returns to Canadian Stage after sold-out productions of 887 and Needles and Opium.

Set against the Cold War's fierce U.S.-Soviet rivalry, this gripping story explores the personal and political turmoil of an era defined by global tension with a uniquely Canadian perspective. Through the tale of two Quebec City brothers, Lepage's stunning use of multimedia and visual storytelling draws the audience into a world on the brink of change and portrays the impact of global conflict on the individual.
event_name: The Far Side of the Moon
short_description:
Borders divide, the cosmos unites.

Canadian legend Robert Lepage returns to Canadian Stage after sold-out productions o
short_name: The Far Side of the Moon

event_description: Join this session to learn about the climate action programs offered by the City of Toronto's Environment, Climate & Forestry division. The city offers a number of programs to support resident-led climate action initiatives; this includes the Indigenous Climate Action Grants, Neighbourhood Climate Action Champions Program, Neighbourhood Climate Action Grants, PollinateTO Grants, Women4Climate Toronto Mentorship Program, and Youth Climate Action Grants. These programs support capacity building and enable climate action projects that have the power to effect change at the local level. Learn more about how these programs support residents across the city!
event_name: Environment, Climate & Forestry's Climate Action Capacity Building Programs Webinar
short_description: Join this session to learn about the climate action programs offered by the City of Toronto's Environment, Climate & For
short_name: Environment, Climate & Forestry's Climate Action Capacity Bu

event_description:
Step back in time with a free visit to Spadina Museum, beautifully decorated for a 1920s Christmas. Visitors can enjoy the opulent holiday décor and period ambiance that once filled the home of the wealthy Austin family. Twinkling lights, antique ornaments, and rooms set for a classic Jazz Age celebration bring the spirit of the season to life.
As you stroll through the mansion, interpretive displays offer insights into the lavish holiday traditions of Toronto’s elite in the 1920s. In contrast, visitors will also learn about the experiences of the city’s less fortunate citizens during the same era—those who faced poverty, unemployment, and food insecurity during a time of great social and economic change.
From a grand dining room prepared for a festive feast to modest depictions of how the servants of the household marked the holidays, the experience paints a full picture of a Toronto Christmas in the early 20th century.
event_name: Jazz Age Christmas at Spadina Museum
short_description: Step back in time with a free visit to Spadina Museum, beautifully decorated for a 1920s Christmas. Visitors can enjoy t
short_name: Jazz Age Christmas at Spadina Museum

event_description:
Experience our world in vivid detail and see some of the most unusual species and their habitats in ways you never imagined. 

Each back-lit photograph provides exquisite quality and depth. From the photographer's eye to the camera's lens, viewers become witnesses to the lives animals live and the challenges they face. 

Emotive, surprising, and sometimes sobering, glimpses of life on our planet are showcased through exceptional talent, technical expertise, and perfectly captured moments.
event_name: Wildlife Photographer of the Year Exhibition

short_name: Wildlife Photographer of the Year Exhibition

event_description:
Two internationally acclaimed  experiences, SÉANCE and FLIGHT, are coming. 

Staged inside purpose-built 40-foot shipping containers, these genre-defying works use complete darkness, 360° binaural audio, and precisely timed physical and environmental effects to create psychologically charged alternate realities.

The Toronto season brings two of the company’s most toured experiences to Canada for the first time. With over 700,000 attendees worldwide and appearances of their work at Venice Film Festival, Tribeca, SXSW, and Edinburgh Fringe, Toronto is now invited also to step inside the dark.

Join the Artists for the opening reception on Saturday, November 1, 2 to 4 p.m. Light refreshments provided.

event_description: Explore the majestic gothic architecture and picturesque tree-lined paths of the campus as we uncover its eerie history and spine-chilling ghostly tales. As we stroll through the historic grounds, our expert guides will captivate you with chilling stories of ghostly sightings and supernatural phenomena witnessed by students, faculty, and visitors alike. Whether you’re a history buff, a believer in the paranormal, a student or alum, or just looking for a unique and spooky evening experience in Toronto, our Campus Secrets & Spectres ghost tour will leave you with a sense of wonder and intrigue as we reveal the haunted secrets of the University of Toronto’s downtown campus.
event_name: Campus Secrets and Spectres – University of Toronto Ghost Tour

short_name: Campus Secrets and Spectres – University of Toronto Ghost To

event_description:
Come and celebrate all things spooky!

Start off the day with a hike through the woodlands. We’ll stop to learn the not-so-scary truth about owls, spiders, bats, decomposers, witch hazel trees and more. 

After the hike, your group can warm up around our campfire and make Halloween themed art. We will provide roasting sticks, hot chocolate and marshmallows for everyone and you are welcome to bring any additional items you would like to roast. Costumes are strongly encouraged but optional.
short_description:
Come and celebrate all things spooky!

Start off the day with a hike through the woodlands. We’ll stop to learn the not-

event_description:
Curated by Yantong Li, a Master of Visual Studies Curatorial Studies graduate student. 

Featured artists Kent Chan, Alvin Luong, and Solveig Qu Suess interrogate the way we currently consume media about environmental precarity, inviting viewers to engage in a dialogue and sit with representations of catastrophe that deemphasize the spectacular and dramatic. 

Dwelling Under Distant Suns highlights the struggle to make visible the increasingly unpredictable landscape of the climate crisis and other human-led impacts on the environment. Using speculative storytelling and myth-making through film-based works, this exhibition brings a sense of immediacy to our planet’s growing climate crisis and the environmental dangers that feel distant or out of sight.
event_name: Art Museum at the University of Toronto: Dwelling Under Distant Suns

short_name: Art Museum at the University of Toronto: Dwelling Under Dist

Using speculative storytelling and myth-making through film-based works, this exhibition brings a sense of immediacy to our planet’s growing climate crisis and the environmental dangers that feel distant or out of sight.
event_name: Art Museum at the University of Toronto: Dwelling Under Distant Suns

Step into the glow, we're back for the sixth year! 

This year, guests can explore the magic like never before with a brand-new layout that lets you move freely between the immersive light show and Pumpkinville at your own pace. Wander through the illuminated maze of over 1.5 million LED and RGB lights, then pop into a vibrant fall fair featuring all new glowing photo ops, installations, midway rides, carnival games, and over 15,000 pumpkins. With new scenes, dazzling photo moments, and an entirely transformed setup, this is not just a walk, it's an adventure!

event_description:
Curated by Mikinaak Migwans, Earthwork redefines a term that until now has referred to a type of artistic practice associated within the larger conceptual framework of land art. 

In this exhibition, Migwans shifts our understanding of earthwork to refer to a way of working, rather than the making of singular objects, reclaiming the art historical framing from an Indigenous perspective. It considers multiple layers of engagement with the land, including a history of land defense movements, medicine walks, and ancestral practices of prescribed burns, alongside contemporary art.

Featured artists include Michael Belmore, BUSH Gallery (Gabrielle L’Hirondelle Hill, Peter Morin, Tania Willard), Faye HeavyShield, Art Hunter, Alex Jacobs-Blum, Mike MacDonald, Lisa Myers, Edward Poitras, and Protect the Tract Collective.
event_name: Art Museum at the University of Toronto: Earthwork

event_description:
The Grammy Award-winning Scottish violinist returns for another enthralling Koerner Hall concert, featuring works by Bloch, Ponce, Paganini, Sarasate, and others, along with new commissions and arrangements of traditional Scottish music.

Nicola Benedetti is one of the most sought-after violinists of her generation. Her ability to captivate audiences and her wide appeal as an advocate for classical music has made her one of the most influential artists of today. 

Winner of the Grammy Award for Best Classical Instrumental Solo in 2020, as well as Best Female Artist at both 2012 and 2013 Classical BRIT Awards, Benedetti’s most recent recording features works written especially for her by jazz musician Wynton Marsalis: Violin Concerto in D Major and Fiddle Dance Suite for Solo Violin.
short_description: The Grammy Award-winning Scottish violinist returns for another enthralling Koerner Hall concert, featuring works by Blo

cost_notes: Purchase advance tickets online using the City of Toronto's program registrations software. If you do not already have an account, you will need to create one. If you have trouble registering, please contact spadina@toronto.ca or call 416-392-6910.
event_description:
Step into the mysterious world of Victorian mourning traditions in this unique hands-on workshop exploring the art of hair jewellery. Held in the evocative setting of Spadina Museum, you'll learn how Victorian’s crafted mementos from human hair, a deeply personal and artistic form of remembrance.
Participants will discover how strands of hair were carefully woven into intricate brooches, rings, and lockets, often worn in memory of lost loved ones. After a brief historical overview and tour of relevant artifacts in the museum’s collection, you'll be guided through the process of creating your own hairwork-inspired keepsake using synthetic hair.
Whether you're a history enthusiast, jewellery maker, or simply curious about the strange and sentimental practices of the past, this workshop offers a rare glimpse into one of the most intimate Victorian traditions.
All materials provided. No prior experience required.
For for ages 12 and up. Youth 12-16 must be accompanied by an adult.
event_name: Memento Mori: Victorian Hair Jewellery Workshop at Spadina Museum
short_description: Step into the mysterious world of Victorian mourning traditions in this unique hands-on workshop exploring the art of ha
short_name: Memento Mori: Victorian Hair Jewellery Workshop at Spadina M

event_description:
Come and celebrate all things spooky!

Start off the day with a hike through the woodlands. We’ll stop to learn the not-so-scary truth about owls, spiders, bats, decomposers, witch hazel trees and more. 

After the hike, your group can warm up around our campfire and make Halloween themed art. We will provide roasting sticks, hot chocolate and marshmallows for everyone and you are welcome to bring any additional items you would like to roast. Costumes are strongly encouraged but optional.

event_description:
This Halloween, Montgomery's Inn invites visitors after dark to uncover eerie tales about the past inhabitants of the Inn and the Old Town of Islington. Visitors will explore the historic house and the Islington burying grounds, learn about Victorian death practices, and find new ways to connect with Toronto's past.

This guided tour of the historic house will be followed by a walking tour of the nearby Islington Burying grounds. Following the walking tour, guests will return to the historic house for refreshments by the fire.

Trigger warning: topics such as illness, death and other difficult topics will be discussed during this event.

This program is for ages 12 and up. Youth 12-16 years of age much be accompanied by an adult ticketholder.

Non-resident surcharge will not apply.

TICKETS ARE NON-REFUNDABLE.

event_description:
The past never really stays in the past.  

A group of old classmates self-declared the “Multi-Ethnic Reject Group” reunites to pre-game their twentieth high school reunion, but nostalgia quickly turns into something darker. 

As drinks flow and old wounds resurface, they confront the choices that shaped them, the friendships that endured or crumbled, and the presence of something, or someone they can’t escape. 

Sharp, theatrical, and deeply moving, this is a reckoning for elder millennials, caught between who they were, who they’ve become, and the world they never saw coming. When the night ends, will they still recognize themselves?

event_description:
Join Shrek and friends for a holiday you’ll never forget!

Enjoy the humour, heart, and hijinks of this ogre-sized production. Bursting with catchy tunes, laugh-out-loud moments, and featuring a kaleidoscopic crew of fairy tale misfits – a wisecracking donkey, a fierce warrior princess, a pint-sized villain, and even a cookie with an attitude. 

It’s a fun-filled adventure for the whole family, celebrating friendship and the joy of finding your true self. Based on the smash-hit Oscar-winning film, this charmingly cheeky romp in the swamp reminds us that even in a world divided, we’re all in this together.

event_description:
A meditation on time’s quiet violence, the kind that softens steel, warps memory, and leaves only traces where certainty once stood. 

Through oil, resin, wood, and fabric, these works search for the sacred in what’s worn, forgotten, or passed from use. Informed by the poetry of Dylan Thomas and the uneasy terrain of aging in a culture obsessed with youth, the series holds space for what remains when identity dissolves, when utility fades, and when beauty no longer demands to be seen.

This is not nostalgia, it is resistance. A refusal to go gentle.
short_description: A meditation on time’s quiet violence, the kind that softens steel, warps memory, and leaves only traces where certainty

event_description:
Curated by Manar Abo Touk, this is a multidisciplinary group exhibition that reimagines the gallery as a living garden, a shared space of care, restoration, and quiet resistance.

Bringing together artists who work with natural, digital, and tactile materials to navigate experiences of displacement, intergenerational grief, and mental health.

Informed by diasporic, feminist, and ecological perspectives, the exhibition explores themes of collective tending, healing practices, and the everyday rituals that sustain us.
event_name: Being Scene 2025 Curated Exhibition: Tending to What Remains
short_description: Curated by Manar Abo Touk, this is a multidisciplinary group exhibition that reimagines the gallery as a living garden,
short_name: Being Scene 2025 Curated Exhibition: Tending to What Remains

event_description: On November 11th, attend one of the City’s most evocative Remembrance Day Ceremonies at Fort York National Historic Site. All are encouraged to take part in honouring and remembering the service and sacrifice of all Canadians, from diverse backgrounds and communities, who came together to serve and defend their homes and country. This year also marks the 80th Anniversary of the end of the Second World War and the Liberation of the Netherlands. Presented in partnership with the IODE.
short_description: On November 11th, attend one of the City’s most evocative Remembrance Day Ceremonies at Fort York National Historic Site

event_description:
Join us for a celebration of the City’s cultural spaces at Old City Hall. Since 2005, Toronto the Good has brought together city builders and residents to explore the themes of urban change, uniqueness, complexity and potential. At this year’s party, we invite you to consider the value of Toronto’s cultural spaces and envision new possibilities for how we can support and retain them.

Hosted by ERA Architects in partnership with the City’s Toronto History Museums. Special guests include the Mexican city-building organization Culturans and the Toronto Biennial of Art.
short_description: Join us for a celebration of the City’s cultural spaces at Old City Hall. Since 2005, Toronto the Good has brought toget

event_description: Ten artists, two cultures, one vision. Five Atikamekw artists from Manawan, Quebec, and five African Francophone artists from the GTA come together to create ribbon skirts as art—expressions of land, culture, and connection to Turtle Island. Experience this powerful exhibition of identity and collaboration as part of free guided tours at Spadina museum.
event_name: Kichi Ukubanbisana: The Great Collaboration at Spadina Museum
short_description: Ten artists, two cultures, one vision. Five Atikamekw artists from Manawan, Quebec, and five African Francophone artists
short_name: Kichi Ukubanbisana: The Great Collaboration at Spadina Museu

event_description: Ten artists, two cultures, one vision. Five Atikamekw artists from Manawan, Quebec, and five African Francophone artists from the GTA come together to create ribbon skirts as art—expressions of land, culture, and connection to Turtle Island. Experience this powerful exhibition of identity and collaboration as part of free guided tours at Spadina museum.
event_name: Kichi Ukubanbisana: The Great Collaboration at Spadina Museum
short_description: Ten artists, two cultures, one vision. Five Atikamekw artists from Manawan, Quebec, and five African Francophone artists
short_name: Kichi Ukubanbisana: The Great Collaboration at Spadina Museu

event_description:
An adventure into the Age of Uncertanity. 

These images definitely pose more questions than providing answers. Join in on a journey that neurotically pokes at the stresses of climate change. Feel the relentless pressure of time ticking away.
Might be fun? Or not!

Four parts to this adventure. First, "Invasive Species" - creatures that are motivated by a human-altered climate to move. Followed by "My Resilient Garden" - hope, maybe not for humans, but for the rest of the world to carry on. Next up, "The Human Factor" - we started this upheaval and we are now the victims. Can we do anything but squirm? Let’s hope. Ending with "It’s About Time" a playful reminder that time is running out.
event_name: then, there's this... by David McClyment
short_description:
An adventure into the Age of Uncertanity. 

These images definitely pose more questions than providing answers. Join in
short_name: then, there's this... by David McClyment

event_description:
Through the use of sculpture, photography, video, and installation, this exhibition is a blend of different people and perspectives forming a kind of visual and sonic cacophony. It’s a nod to global (or even galactic) unity, and to the idea that despite all the noise and division, we’re more alike than not. 

In her Canadian debut, Intergalactic Planetary brings together imagery and works inspired by cities including Shanghai, Chongqing, Berlin, Tokyo, Bangkok and locations across the United States. Snelling explains, “Through this work, I ask: how can we move beyond our fears, borders, and egos to become more humane? Perhaps by staying curious, open, and willing to see each other more fully, we can take a small step toward connection, and even a glimmer of peace for the future”.

Join us on Nuit Blanche to view the exhibition's works, while DJ beats set the mood with dynamic sounds and enjoy two exhibition-inspired cocktails-one coffee-based and the other with an intergalactic twist.

event_description: A brand-new comedy show clocking in to roast the unrelenting day-to-day grind. From incompetent managers and weird co-workers to impossible customers and inboxes that are like an all-you-can-eat buffet of stupidity, no job is safe. Whether you’re hustling in the gig economy, surviving the 9-to-5, or just trying to make it through one more Zoom call without consuming a vat of medical-grade caffeine, The Second City’s cast of comedic professionals are here working overtime with their world-famous brand of sketch and improv comedy. Don’t call in sick… you’ll want to be here for this shift.

cost_notes: All participants must be 16 or older.
event_description: Join us for a spine-chilling paranormal adventure where intimate groups of 12 or fewer will have exclusive access to investigate haunted heritage buildings – including the notorious Half Way House – in the dark! Feel the chill of the night and listen to the whispers of the past as we employ ancient and modern techniques to attempt to establish contact with the lingering spirits that call the Village home. ‘Alone in the Dark’ is as real as it gets, nothing is hidden or staged. This unforgettably eerie evening will delight ghost story enthusiasts, fearless paranormal investigators, history aficionados, urban explorers, and anyone with a curiosity about the unknown. Book your spot now—spaces fill fast! All participants must be 16 or older.
event_name: Alone in the Dark – The Village at Black Creek

short_name: Alone in the Dark – The Village at Black Creek

cost_notes: Admission includes snacks. Custom beer available at cash bar, non-alcoholic beverages are also available.
event_description:
Enjoy Irish music, snacks, Victorian games, and even sip on a custom brewed beer good enough to impress Enoch Turner himself!

Ryan Manucha presents his Donner Prize winning book Booze, Cigarettes and Constitutional Dust-Ups: Canada’s Quest for Interprovincial Free Trade.

A leading expert on interprovincial trade in Canada, he is frequently called upon to advise governments and agencies. Ryan’s solutions-focused research is routinely published by Canada’s leading think tanks. He is currently a research fellow at the C.D. Howe Institute and holds a law degree from Harvard Law School and a Bachelor’s in Economics from Yale University.

Custom beer created and provided by Granite Brewery, we can't wait to see you there!

event_description:
Join us on a chilling and thrilling journey through the dark history of the city as we delve into the world of ghosts, graveyards, hangings, and haunts.

 Prepare to be captivated by spine-tingling ghost stories about haunted theatres, unsolved mysteries, secrets hiding in plain sight, and spooky historic buildings. Our outdoor tour will take you on a hair-raising paranormal adventure, departing from the courtyard in front of the Hockey Hall of Fame. 

Get ready to see the city in a whole new light, or rather, darkness, as you uncover the eerie and supernatural tales that lurk in its shadows.

event_description:
As night falls, we’ll set out on a lantern-lit stroll along the cobblestone streets of the historic Distillery District, one of Toronto’s most haunted spots! 

Learn about the tragic events that left their mark and hear spine-chilling tales of paranormal encounters from this iconic area. Feel the goosebumps rise as you explore the narrow alleyways and hidden corners where spirits are said to lurk. 

Whether you’re a history buff, a ghost enthusiast, or just looking for a unique experience, this outdoor tour is sure to captivate your imagination. Get ready to experience the thrills and chills like never before.
event_name: Spirits of the Distillery District Ghost Tour

event_description: Come and celebrate the excitement of the autumn season at Todmorden Mills Heritage Site! Enjoy a variety of fall and Halloween-themed arts and crafts or explore the historic houses with an enriched guided tour. These activities are perfect for all ages, making it easy for everyone to get in on the fun. On October 18, experience special wool demonstrations by Riverdale Farm from 1 to 3 p.m.
short_description: Come and celebrate the excitement of the autumn season at Todmorden Mills Heritage Site! Enjoy a variety of fall and Hal

event_description:
"I Am Scarborough" is a community-engaged installation at Scarborough Museum, created by artist Kseniya Tsoy during her Toronto Arts Council Animating Historic Sites residency.

Over the course of several months, Scarborough residents and museum visitors came together to fold hundreds of origami butterflies and share their stories—their journeys, the lands their families come from, and their hopes and dreams.

Now gathered and suspended in flight, these butterflies embody the vibrant diversity of Scarborough—soaring high and envisioning a bright, shared future.

Experience their collective flight at Scarborough Museum through October 2025.
event_name: I am Scarborough - Installation at Scarborough Museum

Experience their collective flight at Scarborough Museum through October 2025.
event_name: I am Scarborough - Installation at Scarborough Museum

short_name: I am Scarborough - Installation at Scarborough Museum

event_description:
Curated by Yantong Li, a Master of Visual Studies Curatorial Studies graduate student. 

Featured artists Kent Chan, Alvin Luong, and Solveig Qu Suess interrogate the way we currently consume media about environmental precarity, inviting viewers to engage in a dialogue and sit with representations of catastrophe that deemphasize the spectacular and dramatic. 

Dwelling Under Distant Suns highlights the struggle to make visible the increasingly unpredictable landscape of the climate crisis and other human-led impacts on the environment. Using speculative storytelling and myth-making through film-based works, this exhibition brings a sense of immediacy to our planet’s growing climate crisis and the environmental dangers that feel distant or out of sight.
event_name: Art Museum at the University of Toronto: Dwelling Under Distant Suns
