event_description:
Experience our world in vivid detail and see some of the most unusual species and their habitats in ways you never imagined. 

Each back-lit photograph provides exquisite quality and depth. From the photographer's eye to the camera's lens, viewers become witnesses to the lives animals live and the challenges they face. 

Emotive, surprising, and sometimes sobering, glimpses of life on our planet are showcased through exceptional talent, technical expertise, and perfectly captured moments.
event_name: Wildlife Photographer of the Year Exhibition
short_description: Experience our world in vivid detail and see some of the most unusual species and their habitats in ways you never imagi
short_name: Wildlife Photographer of the Year Exhibition

event_description:
Experience our world in vivid detail and see some of the most unusual species and their habitats in ways you never imagined. 

Each back-lit photograph provides exquisite quality and depth. From the photographer's eye to the camera's lens, viewers become witnesses to the lives animals live and the challenges they face. 

Emotive, surprising, and sometimes sobering, glimpses of life on our planet are showcased through exceptional talent, technical expertise, and perfectly captured moments.
event_name: Wildlife Photographer of the Year Exhibition

event_description:
What does home mean to you? Discover rarely seen artifacts from the City’s collections and items from community members. Explore the many ways we define, create and carry home with us. From a First World War soldier’s return ticket home to a precious family object stewarded by multiple generations, encounter belongings, voices and stories of Toronto artists, makers, entrepreneurs and community leaders as they share their unique perspectives on belonging, identity and place. These powerful objects offer fresh, heartfelt perspectives on what it means to find, make or remember home.

At Home in Toronto includes the artworks of Rebecca Baird, Carl Beam, Fred Hagan, Robert Houle, Luis Jacob, Kit Li, Raoul Olou, Yasmine Louis and Natalie Wood, as well as loaned works by local artists Doug Brown and Frantz Brent-Harris.
short_description: What does home mean to you? Discover rarely seen artifacts from the City’s collections and items from community members.

event_description:
Borders divide, the cosmos unites.

Canadian legend Robert Lepage returns to Canadian Stage after sold-out productions of 887 and Needles and Opium.

Set against the Cold War's fierce U.S.-Soviet rivalry, this gripping story explores the personal and political turmoil of an era defined by global tension with a uniquely Canadian perspective. Through the tale of two Quebec City brothers, Lepage's stunning use of multimedia and visual storytelling draws the audience into a world on the brink of change and portrays the impact of global conflict on the individual.
event_name: The Far Side of the Moon

event_description:
Beginning July 1st at Scarborough Museum, experience Washed Up by Hatecopy. The project captures the essence of liminal spaces that serve as cultural hubs for the South Asian immigrant communities, using the washing machine as a vessel to carry textiles that signify our roots and drawing visitors into an environment that intertwines the past, present, and future; acknowledging the dirty laundry of Canadian History and “Truth,” and reclaiming both seen and unseen spaces.

Maria Qamar (b. 1991) is a Toronto-based pop artist whose work is focused in the South Asian diaspora and immigrant communities and their cultural experiences. The work specializes in themes regarding feminism, social change, humour, pop culture, politics and romance. The artist has been recognized both nationally and internationally with exhibits and features in the Museum of Contemporary Arts, the National Arts Centre, Sotheby’s, Phillips Auction, and the AGO.
event_name: Washed Up: Pop-Up Installation at Scarborough Museum

event_description:
Discover Hyunsun Park's captivating collection of gouache paintings that evoke empathy and connection. Each painting is a window into personal and shared experiences-- stories of survival, resilience, and the search for meaning.

Join the Artists for the opening reception on Saturday, August 9, 2 to 4 p.m. Light refreshments provided.

event_description:
Adventure with us into the great outdoors to learn how to pack your backpack, administer first aid, navigate, follow the 7 Leave No Trace principles, and plenty of other surprising tips. 

Impress everyone by learning how to light a fire with water! 

All ages are welcome but those under the age of 16 must be accompanied by an adult. Available in English and French.
event_name: The Art of Lighting a Fire With Water
short_description: Adventure with us into the great outdoors to learn how to pack your backpack, administer first aid, navigate, follow the
short_name: The Art of Lighting a Fire With Water

event_description:
Making Home in Scarborough is a vibrant pop-up installation celebrating memory, identity, and belonging through cultural traditions and objects we hold dear to our hearts in generations past, present and future. 
 

Co-created through conversation and care, community members were invited to share a meaningful object, rooted in a heartfelt story. All speak to how home is made not only in buildings or borders, but in the places, people, and practices that give life meaning. 
 
As you explore the exhibition, we invite you to reflect: "What does home mean to you?" If you live in Scarborough, "What does Making Home in Scarborough Mean to you?" 
 
We are grateful for our community collaborators: Native Child and Family Services / Scarborough Child & Family Life Centre, Malvern Family Resource Centre, TDSB Newcomer Services (Malvern), Toby's Place, Scarborough Museum Youth Collective and Change Made.
event_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Making Home in Scarborough at Scarborough Museum
short_description: Making Home in Scarborough is a vibrant pop-up installation celebrating memory, identity, and belonging through cultural
short_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Making Home in Scarborough at Scarborough Mu

event_description:
This family-friendly exhibition invites you to uncover fresh perspectives, groundbreaking research and the astounding diversity of this ancient group of fishes.

Visitors will delve into the anatomy, behaviour, and history of sharks, from familiar favourites like tiger sharks and great whites to lesser-known species like the dwarf lanternshark—a tiny, light-producing marvel small enough to hold in your hand.

Through dozens of interactives and life-sized models, including a life-size head of the huge extinct Megalodon, join us for a unique look at these magnificent creatures, their habitats, hunting techniques, and the conservation threats that they face.

event_description: Join the Ontario Society of Artists in honoring its Life Members, acknowledging their significant contributions to both the Society and the wider art community. These distinguished members actively teach, exhibit their work, sustain their artistic practices and generously volunteer their time. Representing diverse disciplines, including painting, sculpture, printmaking and photography, the Life Members embody the creative spirit and dedication that enrich the arts.

event_description:
"I Am Scarborough" is a community-engaged installation at Scarborough Museum, created by artist Kseniya Tsoy during her Toronto Arts Council Animating Historic Sites residency.

Over the course of several months, Scarborough residents and museum visitors came together to fold hundreds of origami butterflies and share their stories—their journeys, the lands their families come from, and their hopes and dreams.

Now gathered and suspended in flight, these butterflies embody the vibrant diversity of Scarborough—soaring high and envisioning a bright, shared future.

Experience their collective flight at Scarborough Museum through October 2025.
event_name: I am Scarborough - Installation at Scarborough Museum

event_description:
This family-friendly exhibition invites you to uncover fresh perspectives, groundbreaking research and the astounding diversity of this ancient group of fishes.

Visitors will delve into the anatomy, behaviour, and history of sharks, from familiar favourites like tiger sharks and great whites to lesser-known species like the dwarf lanternshark—a tiny, light-producing marvel small enough to hold in your hand.

Through dozens of interactives and life-sized models, including a life-size head of the huge extinct Megalodon, join us for a unique look at these magnificent creatures, their habitats, hunting techniques, and the conservation threats that they face.

event_description:
Join Scarborough Museum and Veneise George for a two-part celebration of the way food and stories intertwine during the holidays!

In Part 1, participants will gather for a story-sharing circle, getting to know one another and presenting a recipe that connects them to a feeling of home during the holiday season. In Part 2, these recipes and stories will form a communal potluck-style meal! All are welcome for this family-friendly gathering. 

Veneise George is a wife, proud mom of two, entrepreneur, and the passionate force behind YAWDI'S—a premium condiment brand rooted in bold Caribbean flavors, cultural heritage, and handcrafted quality.

This workshop is part of Scarborough Museum's Season of Celebration - a series of family-friendly activities that celebrate light, love, and joy through food, culture, and storytelling.
event_name: Holiday Food & Story Sharing Circle at Scarborough Museum
short_description: Join Scarborough Museum and Veneise George for a two-part celebration of the way food and stories intertwine during the
short_name: Holiday Food & Story Sharing Circle at Scarborough Museum

cost_notes: General admission (including touring the museum buildings, food sampling and craft activities) is free / does not require advanced tickets. Some workshops are ticketed - see additional listings for further details.
event_description:
Join Scarborough Museum for a Season of Celebration! Embrace the spirit of light, love, and joy through a series of family-friendly activities centered on food, culture, and storytelling.  

Enjoy gingerbread decorating, family-friendly winter crafts and weekly workshops led by guest facilitators, including chair yoga, henna and more! See additional listings for more details. 

Community Feature: Sample a rotating selection of warm drinks and finger foods from around the world, curated by the Scarborough Museum Youth Collective and participants of Scarborough Museum’s Newcomer Storytelling Circles. Try something new or enjoy an old favourite, learn more about the stories behind these sips and bites, and share your own stories of light and warmth in our community jar!  

Treats will be available first come-first served, while quantities last.

event_description:
Join us for a hike to learn about the birds that call Tom Riley Park home. We will discuss bird migration and may even see some species like raptors or songbirds as they make their way south, as well as Mimico Creek and general urban ecology issues like bird-friendly designs, stormwater and invasive species.

Getting here: The nearest subway station is Islington station. Please walk east past the Bloor/Aberfoyle Crescent intersection. New Horizons Community Garden is north of the parking lot. If you are driving, the nearest parking lot is Carpark 512 at 3.

Accessibility: Tom Riley is paved, although we will walk over some unpaved portions of the park. There are public bathrooms at the Memorial Pool And Health Club, 44 Montgomery Rd. 

Please wear sunscreen, long sleeve tops and pants to protect against ticks, and bring water. If you have binoculars, please bring them.
event_name: Nature Walk to celebrate Ravine Days at Tom Riley Park
short_description: Join us for a hike to learn about the birds that call Tom Riley Park home. We will discuss bird migration and may even s
short_name: Nature Walk to celebrate Ravine Days at Tom Riley Park

event_description:
Step back in time with a free visit to Spadina Museum, beautifully decorated for a 1920s Christmas. Visitors can enjoy the opulent holiday décor and period ambiance that once filled the home of the wealthy Austin family. Twinkling lights, antique ornaments, and rooms set for a classic Jazz Age celebration bring the spirit of the season to life.
As you stroll through the mansion, interpretive displays offer insights into the lavish holiday traditions of Toronto’s elite in the 1920s. In contrast, visitors will also learn about the experiences of the city’s less fortunate citizens during the same era—those who faced poverty, unemployment, and food insecurity during a time of great social and economic change.
From a grand dining room prepared for a festive feast to modest depictions of how the servants of the household marked the holidays, the experience paints a full picture of a Toronto Christmas in the early 20th century.
event_name: Jazz Age Christmas at Spadina Museum

short_name: Jazz Age Christmas at Spadina Museum

Sharks have intrigued humans for as long as we have explored the oceans. The terrifying monster from the movie Jaws is what many might imagine when they think of these animals, but they are far more fascinating and complex than their depiction in popular culture.

This exhibition invites you to uncover fresh perspectives, groundbreaking research, and the astounding diversity of this ancient group of fishes.

Visitors will delve into the anatomy, behaviour, and history of sharks, from familiar favourites like tiger sharks and great whites to lesser-known species like the dwarf lanternshark—a tiny, light-producing marvel small enough to hold in your hand.

event_description:
Step into a world where classical elegance meets pop brilliance! 

Join us for an extraordinary concert that combines the timeless symphonies of Mozart with the unforgettable hits of ABBA. Feel the magic as Mozart’s masterful compositions soar alongside the infectious energy of ABBA’s legendary anthems. 

From the grandeur of the classical era to the irresistible charm of disco, this performance blends two iconic musical worlds in a celebration of harmony, rhythm, and unforgettable melodies. It’s a night you won’t want to miss, a perfect fusion of sophistication and pure pop joy! Featuring guest artists Luri Lee and students from the Glenn Gould School.
short_description:

event_description:
Beginning July 1st at Scarborough Museum, experience Washed Up by Hatecopy. The project captures the essence of liminal spaces that serve as cultural hubs for the South Asian immigrant communities, using the washing machine as a vessel to carry textiles that signify our roots and drawing visitors into an environment that intertwines the past, present, and future; acknowledging the dirty laundry of Canadian History and “Truth,” and reclaiming both seen and unseen spaces.

Maria Qamar (b. 1991) is a Toronto-based pop artist whose work is focused in the South Asian diaspora and immigrant communities and their cultural experiences. The work specializes in themes regarding feminism, social change, humour, pop culture, politics and romance. The artist has been recognized both nationally and internationally with exhibits and features in the Museum of Contemporary Arts, the National Arts Centre, Sotheby’s, Phillips Auction, and the AGO.
event_name: Washed Up: Pop-Up Installation at Scarborough Museum

event_description:
Making Home in Scarborough is a vibrant pop-up installation celebrating memory, identity, and belonging through cultural traditions and objects we hold dear to our hearts in generations past, present and future. 
 

Co-created through conversation and care, community members were invited to share a meaningful object, rooted in a heartfelt story. All speak to how home is made not only in buildings or borders, but in the places, people, and practices that give life meaning. 
 
As you explore the exhibition, we invite you to reflect: "What does home mean to you?" If you live in Scarborough, "What does Making Home in Scarborough Mean to you?" 
 
We are grateful for our community collaborators: Native Child and Family Services / Scarborough Child & Family Life Centre, Malvern Family Resource Centre, TDSB Newcomer Services (Malvern), Toby's Place, Scarborough Museum Youth Collective and Change Made.
event_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Making Home in Scarborough at Scarborough Museum

short_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Making Home in Scarborough at Scarborough Mu

event_description:
We are pleased to bring you the fifth annual Greek International Film Festival Tour of Canada (GIFFT).

This is a Canadian national film festival that will take place in 11 Canadian cities simultaneously. Those cities include: Toronto, Vancouver, Edmonton, Calgary, Regina, Winnipeg, London (Ontario), Hamilton/Niagara, Ottawa, and Halifax.

GIFFT is a showcase and celebration of Greek cinema and filmmakers of Greek Heritage. This festival will provide exciting platform for directors, writers, producers, and actors of Greek Heritage to showcase their exceptional art across Canada.

event_description:
Having established himself among the elite of his generation, David Jalbert was named by CBC in their best all-time Canadian pianists list. 

Critically lauded, he has appeared as soloist in Europe, Mexico, South Africa, and with almost every Canadian symphony orchestra, under the batons of Yannick Nézet-Séguin, Bramwell Tovey, and Tania Miller. He is a Virginia Parker Prize laureate. 

David has recorded two volumes of Prokofiev’s piano works to great acclaim. He will perform Sonatas Opp. 29 (C minor), 14 (D minor), 82 (A Major) plus 10 Pieces for Piano, Op. 12.

event_description:
The man whom Bill Graham called “the best kept secret in the music business”, the man who taught Joni Mitchell her first guitar techniques and also taught George Harrison his first lessons on Sitar, wrote the music to Donovan’s Season of the Witch and has played with many of the finest musicians in the world including Eric Clapton and Steve Winwood.

He has produced 27 albums and is known around the world for his refusal to bow down to commercialism in the music industry. He has done what many singer-songwriters don’t do, which is to continue to evolve his creative skills in his concerts. When he comes to a venue, he brings the sounds of an entire symphony orchestra in real time and plays the songs so many love as closely as possible to what was recorded on the albums. All in real time... all solo!

event_description:
This is a quarterly performance series that explores the awe inspired by humans’ most intimate experiences: sex and death. 

Hosted by Kaleigh Trace and Christa Couture, Kaleigh is a queer, disabled therapist, former sex educator, and writer who is also living with terminal cancer. The idea for this show came from her desire to have more irreverent conversations about death, and her history of having reverent conversations about sex. 

Featuring in conversation, Jody Chan: poet and grief and death worker, Rania El Mugammer: Sudanese artist and liberation educator, Brian Francis: food and fiction writer, Kaleb Roberston: curator of joy, Veronica Simmonds: sonic sorceress and Rae Spoon: musician, producer, author and national treasure.
short_description: This is a quarterly performance series that explores the awe inspired by humans’ most intimate experiences: sex and deat

event_description:
Join Jane Finch Centre's Artists-in-Residence, Taejah Daniel (Coach Milly), Vanna Nguyen and Rod Osei-Nuako (Reezy) for an outdoor art installation at Corner Commons. This Artist-in-Residence is held within Invitations to Better Worlds project and is a collaboration with the Department of Imaginary Affairs and Jane/Finch Centre. Through their residencies, the artists have brought to life their interpretations of a collective vision for better worlds for Jane and Finch. This project is an emergence of community engagement, storytelling, collective liberation, foresight and art. It is a practice in believing better worlds are possible.

A City of Toronto Cultural Hotspot Signature Project.
event_name: Invitations to Better Worlds: Artist Showcase + Meet & Greet

short_name: Invitations to Better Worlds: Artist Showcase + Meet & Greet

event_description:
Immerse yourself in the intricate sound world of Andile Khumalo, one of the most compelling composers of our time, as performed by members of Chicago’s outstanding Ensemble Dal Niente.

Step into a world where time is stretched, fractured, and reassembled. Khumalo's compositions invite deep listening, where textures shimmer, dissolve, and reappear in unexpected ways.

 Drawing from African sonic traditions, European avant-garde, spectralism, and improvisatory jazz, Khumalo’s music resists easy categorization. In works like "The Broken Mirrors of Time", time is reflected in fragments, like memory, where cultural surfaces intersect, blur and transform. The piece echoes the vibrant simultaneity of downtown Johannesburg, where multiple musics resonate with one another. Expect music that is subtle yet powerful, abstract yet deeply rooted in the social, cultural, and sonic realities of African urban life.
event_name: Tracing Hollow Traces: A Portrait of Andile Khumalo
short_description: Immerse yourself in the intricate sound world of Andile Khumalo, one of the most compelling composers of our time, as pe
short_name: Tracing Hollow Traces: A Portrait of Andile Khumalo

event_description: Experience the magic of the season with a tour of Spadina Museum by lamplight. See the lavish 55-room mansion fully decorated for the holidays, just as it was in the 1920s. An experienced guide will lead you through this rare opportunity to explore the house by night. As you arrive, take in a 1920s silent film and enjoy a glass of non-alcoholic punch recreated from a historic recipe. Light up the season with the magic of the winter solstice, spreading joy, peace and festive cheer at Toronto History Museums!
event_name: Holiday Lamplight Tours at Spadina Museum
short_description: Experience the magic of the season with a tour of Spadina Museum by lamplight. See the lavish 55-room mansion fully deco
short_name: Holiday Lamplight Tours at Spadina Museum

event_description:
Discover how homes shape identity through the Austin family story and contemporary art at Spadina Museum. Reimagine history, reframe home.

“Home at Spadina Museum” considers how people are influenced by their home. We look at those who make it a home and those who live in it are shaped by domestic spaces. Through interpretation of the Austin family and into contemporary art, we will analyze what makes a home. Re-Imagining the Historic House Museum: A Workplace for Women. 

Step into “Home at Spadina Museum” and explore how homes are shaped by the people who live and work in them. From the Austin family to contemporary art, discover untold stories of women’s labour, care, and community. Reimagine the historic house as both a home and a workplace.

As you explore the exhibition, we invite you to reflect: "What does home mean to you?"

We are grateful to our community partners, Augusto Bitter and the Women’s Art Association of Canada.
event_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Home at Spadina Museum
short_description: Discover how homes shape identity through the Austin family story and contemporary art at Spadina Museum. Reimagine hist
short_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Home at Spadina Museum

event_description:
Rob Kapilow has rightfully earned the unlikely title of “celebrity music educator”.

With sharp insights, boundless curiosity and a deep appreciation for music’s emotional power, he has been inspiring audiences for decades. This time, Kapilow delves into the vibrant energy and evocative storytelling of Spring and Summer from Vivaldi’s iconic Four Seasons, with Isabella Perron (violin) and the Canadian Chamber Orchestra. 

Bursting with color, drama, and dazzling virtuosity, these masterpieces capture the awakening of nature, the warmth of the sun and the tempestuous storms of summer, all brought to life with fresh insights that will captivate both newcomers and lifelong admirers alike.

“He is a winning combination of Leonard Bernstein and Bill Nye the Science Guy, in infectiously enthusiastic explainer of the inner mechanical workings of music, that most abstract of all arts.” - The New York Times.
event_name: What Makes It Great® with Rob Kapilow
short_description:

Planted at the crossroads of roots and soul music, his mighty voice combined with his fierce guitar work and contemporary songwriting, has gained A'Court fans across Canada and the world.

As a six-time East Coast Association Award winner and eight-time Nova Scotia Music Award winner, Charlie has earned awards for Blues, Pop, and R&B/Soul Recordings of the Year, and  been recognized as Entertainer of the Year.

event_description:
Critically acclaimed and beloved, Johannes Linstead has become recognized internationally as one of the best-selling guitarists in the Instrumental, New Age, Jazz and World Music genres.  

Bohemian Strings is Johannes’ eleventh studio album, bringing together musicians from many diverse ethnic backgrounds including Greece, Palestine, France, Canada, Australia, Iran, and the Dominican Republic. 

Emotional ballads and upbeat rumbas with Latin percussion, Middle Eastern violin, and raspy Roma vocals add a distinct spice tothis very colourful album. Chances are even if you don’t know his name, you’ve heard his music.
short_description: Critically acclaimed and beloved, Johannes Linstead has become recognized internationally as one of the best-selling gui

event_description:
Step into a retro music video playground, with wall-to-wall visuals, nostalgic cocktails and the throwback anthems you forgot you remembered. 

From giant Tamagotchis and Game Boy backdrops to Britney, Usher, and Bon Jovi lighting up the walls, it’s your favourite club hits minus the sticky floors and late-night cab ride. Think less nightclub, more time machine: dance, sing, and still be home by 11.

event_description:
A quiet lake in Ontario is making a lot of noise.

Sediments from the bottom of a small lake in Ontario are revealing a remarkable record of our impact on the planet.

Just outside Toronto, Ontario lies Crawford Lake, a significant site offering a unique, comprehensive 1,000-year record of human impacts - local, regional, and global.

event_description:
Join Shrek and friends for a holiday you’ll never forget!

Enjoy the humour, heart, and hijinks of this ogre-sized production. Bursting with catchy tunes, laugh-out-loud moments, and featuring a kaleidoscopic crew of fairy tale misfits – a wisecracking donkey, a fierce warrior princess, a pint-sized villain, and even a cookie with an attitude. 

It’s a fun-filled adventure for the whole family, celebrating friendship and the joy of finding your true self. Based on the smash-hit Oscar-winning film, this charmingly cheeky romp in the swamp reminds us that even in a world divided, we’re all in this together.

event_description:
Step into an immersive visual experience where material becomes memory, and memory becomes art. 

A compelling mixed media art exhibition that explores emotion, expression, and the sense of belonging through abstract and landscape works. From fragmented shorelines to colour-washed horizons and textured echoes of time, the exhibition invites viewers into a space of contemplation and connection, where personal and collective memories surface through layered materials and imaginative forms.

From fragmented shorelines to colour-washed horizons and textured echoes of time, the exhibition invites viewers into a space of contemplation and connection, where personal and collective memories surface through layered materials and imaginative forms.

event_description:
Join Scarborough Museum for a Season of Celebration! Embrace the spirit of light, love, and joy through a series of family-friendly activities centered on food, culture, and storytelling.  

Enjoy gingerbread decorating, family-friendly winter crafts and weekly workshops led by guest facilitators, including chair yoga, henna and more! See additional listings for more details. 

Community Feature: Sample a rotating selection of warm drinks and finger foods from around the world, curated by the Scarborough Museum Youth Collective and participants of Scarborough Museum’s Newcomer Storytelling Circles. Try something new or enjoy an old favourite, learn more about the stories behind these sips and bites, and share your own stories of light and warmth in our community jar!  

Treats will be available first come-first served, while quantities last.
event_name: Season of Celebration at Scarborough Museum

event_description:
This family-friendly exhibition invites you to uncover fresh perspectives, groundbreaking research and the astounding diversity of this ancient group of fishes.

Visitors will delve into the anatomy, behaviour, and history of sharks, from familiar favourites like tiger sharks and great whites to lesser-known species like the dwarf lanternshark—a tiny, light-producing marvel small enough to hold in your hand.

Through dozens of interactives and life-sized models, including a life-size head of the huge extinct Megalodon, join us for a unique look at these magnificent creatures, their habitats, hunting techniques, and the conservation threats that they face.

event_description: Explore the majestic gothic architecture and picturesque tree-lined paths of the campus as we uncover its eerie history and spine-chilling ghostly tales. As we stroll through the historic grounds, our expert guides will captivate you with chilling stories of ghostly sightings and supernatural phenomena witnessed by students, faculty, and visitors alike. Whether you’re a history buff, a believer in the paranormal, a student or alum, or just looking for a unique and spooky evening experience in Toronto, our Campus Secrets & Spectres ghost tour will leave you with a sense of wonder and intrigue as we reveal the haunted secrets of the University of Toronto’s downtown campus.
event_name: Campus Secrets and Spectres – University of Toronto Ghost Tour

In a magical kingdom beneath the sea, a beautiful young mermaid named Ariel longs to leave her ocean home to live in the world above. Based on the classic Disney animated feature, this is a splashy musical extravaganza. 

Prepare to be swept away by all the songs you remember from the film and be delighted by new ones written by Oscar-winning Disney tunesmith Alan Menken. This under the sea musical is spectacular fun for the whole family!

event_description:
Join us for an unforgettable night of divas, dancing, and fierce performances. Hosted by Canada’s Drag Race star Tynomi Banks, the evening features international dance legend CeCe Peniston, RuPaul’s Drag Race favourite Nina West, and beats by renowned DJ Hector Fonseca.

This is more than a party - it’s a movement. Dance the night away while supporting equitable health care and life-changing programs and initiatives for Toronto’s 2SLGBTQ+ community. Be a part of something iconic!
short_description: Join us for an unforgettable night of divas, dancing, and fierce performances. Hosted by Canada’s Drag Race star Tynomi

event_description:
The Southern Netherlands — better known today as Flanders — was home to revolutionary artists. These extraordinary painters found new ways to depict reality, portray humanity, and tell stories that created parallels to their world then - and to our world today. 

This large-scale exhibition, featuring over 80 stunning art works and objects — medieval, Renaissance, and baroque paintings, sculptures and more — offers a doorway into the Southern Netherlands of 1400 to 1700. The exhibition's unique presentation introduces the visitor, through these rare, extraordinary artworks, to stories of enterprising townspeople, prosperous cities, and an ever-developing society.
event_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Masterworks
short_description: The Southern Netherlands — better known today as Flanders — was home to revolutionary artists. These extraordinary paint
short_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Mast

Be amongst the first to see it!

event_description:
Colin Linden’s tale is the stuff of legends. Featuring in soundtracks like "O Brother Where Art Thou?" and "Inside Llewyn Davis", his music journey began when he was 11-year-olds meeting his music idol Howlin’ Wolf at a matinee show in his native Toronto.

“I’m an old man now, and I won’t be around much longer,” Wolf told him. “It’s up to you to carry it on.”

Linden still carries that frayed photograph in his wallet, along with a Sears 5/8” socket wrench in his pocket to play slide guitar. He has taken Wolf’s plea seriously, performing since he was 12 years old.
short_description: Colin Linden’s tale is the stuff of legends. Featuring in soundtracks like "O Brother Where Art Thou?" and "Inside Llewy

event_description:
Share silliness this holiday season! 

Enjoy a rollicking comedy extravaganza for kids, parents, grandparents, aunts, uncles, and reindeer of all ages! Packed with fun and festive songs, sketches, and ridiculous improv hijinks, this one-of-a-kind interactive theatrical experience invites audience members, young and old, the chance to enjoy the comedy fun both from their seats and by joining performers onstage! Make hilarious holiday memories with us!
short_description:
Share silliness this holiday season! 

Enjoy a rollicking comedy extravaganza for kids, parents, grandparents, aunts, un

event_description:
Curated by Yantong Li, a Master of Visual Studies Curatorial Studies graduate student. 

Featured artists Kent Chan, Alvin Luong, and Solveig Qu Suess interrogate the way we currently consume media about environmental precarity, inviting viewers to engage in a dialogue and sit with representations of catastrophe that deemphasize the spectacular and dramatic. 

Dwelling Under Distant Suns highlights the struggle to make visible the increasingly unpredictable landscape of the climate crisis and other human-led impacts on the environment. Using speculative storytelling and myth-making through film-based works, this exhibition brings a sense of immediacy to our planet’s growing climate crisis and the environmental dangers that feel distant or out of sight.
event_name: Art Museum at the University of Toronto: Dwelling Under Distant Suns

event_description:
Beirut, 1978 and Beirut, 2018. 

Memory is a funny thing, so quiet if left undisturbed, beyond space and time.

Two love stories twist together in two Beiruts riven by time and conflict. In 1978, two women share spit on the ends of cigarettes and yearn for tenderness under the tumult of war. In 2018, a foreigner and a local flirt over vodka sodas as their contradictions collect like condensation on the sides of their glasses. 

Poetic realism braids past and present into the green line of vegetation that bisected the concrete of Lebanon’s capital during the civil war. Named a finalist for the 2024 Governor General's Literary Award, unearths queer history that has always been there, whether our ancestors wanted it to be inherited or erased.
short_description:
Beirut, 1978 and Beirut, 2018. 

Memory is a funny thing, so quiet if left undisturbed, beyond space and time.

Two love

Immerse yourself into the pleasures, pastimes, and artistic heritage of Iran during the Safavid dynasty (1501-1736). A royal picnic, depicted on a large, treasured tile arch from the collections, is complemented by exceptional objects from the period.

event_description:
Laura Piccinin, the creator of "LESBIHONEST", “Every Silver Lining”, and “Apothecary”, and winner of Just for Laughs'  "Outstanding English Comedy Award", brings a new, 90-minute comedic tale of outdoorsy adventure.

In "WOMAN, ALONE" as she dares to walk 336km along the East Coast of Newfoundland. While on her journey of trying not to get killed in the woods, she recounts the stories of her life, and the decisions she’s made in the face of danger (real or perceived) along the way. This sentimental and hilarious show reminds audiences to get out of their own way and GO do that thing that they really, really want to do.

event_description:
A genre-defying quartet from Kyiv, returns with their signature “ethno chaos”, a bold blend of Ukrainian folk, punk, pop, rap, and global rhythms from India, Arabia, Africa, and Australia. 

Known for their powerful vocal harmonies and theatrical performances, they create an immersive, boundary-pushing sound that is both deeply rooted in Ukrainian tradition and globally inspired. Dressed in modern interpretations of traditional Ukrainian attire, DakhaBrakha delivers electrifying live shows that NPR calls “utter brilliance.”

event_description:
The Southern Netherlands — better known today as Flanders — was home to revolutionary artists. These extraordinary painters found new ways to depict reality, portray humanity, and tell stories that created parallels to their world then - and to our world today. 

This large-scale exhibition, featuring over 80 stunning art works and objects — medieval, Renaissance, and baroque paintings, sculptures and more — offers a doorway into the Southern Netherlands of 1400 to 1700. The exhibition's unique presentation introduces the visitor, through these rare, extraordinary artworks, to stories of enterprising townspeople, prosperous cities, and an ever-developing society.
event_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Masterworks

short_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Mast

event_description:
What does home mean to you? Discover rarely seen artifacts from the City’s collections and items from community members. Explore the many ways we define, create and carry home with us. From a First World War soldier’s return ticket home to a precious family object stewarded by multiple generations, encounter belongings, voices and stories of Toronto artists, makers, entrepreneurs and community leaders as they share their unique perspectives on belonging, identity and place. These powerful objects offer fresh, heartfelt perspectives on what it means to find, make or remember home.

At Home in Toronto includes the artworks of Rebecca Baird, Carl Beam, Fred Hagan, Robert Houle, Luis Jacob, Kit Li, Raoul Olou, Yasmine Louis and Natalie Wood, as well as loaned works by local artists Doug Brown and Frantz Brent-Harris.
short_description: What does home mean to you? Discover rarely seen artifacts from the City’s collections and items from community members.

event_description:
Making Home in Scarborough is a vibrant pop-up installation celebrating memory, identity, and belonging through cultural traditions and objects we hold dear to our hearts in generations past, present and future. 
 

Co-created through conversation and care, community members were invited to share a meaningful object, rooted in a heartfelt story. All speak to how home is made not only in buildings or borders, but in the places, people, and practices that give life meaning. 
 
As you explore the exhibition, we invite you to reflect: "What does home mean to you?" If you live in Scarborough, "What does Making Home in Scarborough Mean to you?" 
 
We are grateful for our community collaborators: Native Child and Family Services / Scarborough Child & Family Life Centre, Malvern Family Resource Centre, TDSB Newcomer Services (Malvern), Toby's Place, Scarborough Museum Youth Collective and Change Made.
event_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Making Home in Scarborough at Scarborough Museum
short_description: Making Home in Scarborough is a vibrant pop-up installation celebrating memory, identity, and belonging through cultural
short_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Making Home in Scarborough at Scarborough Mu

event_description:
The multi-Grammy and Emmy Award-winning vocal ensemble returns to perform a joyful program of South African freedom songs, traditional spirituals, and some classics, featuring the spirited music of Aretha Franklin, Harry Belafonte, Peter Gabriel, Kate Bush, Leonard Cohen, and more!

Formed in 2002, the Choir was created to celebrate the unique power of African gospel music and quickly established itself as a group that is “undeniably synchronized, appears unshakable, and simultaneously expresses universality and individuality” (San Francisco Classical Voice). Heralded by Nelson Mandela, Desmond Tutu, Barack Obama, and Oprah Winfrey, Soweto Gospel Choir excites audiences worldwide, uplifting the soul and spreading joy through its earthy rhythms, rich harmonies, brilliant costumes, and infectious spirit.

“Absolutely thrilling singers ... dazzling music.” (Billboard)

After the concert, enjoy a beverage and more music.
short_description: The multi-Grammy and Emmy Award-winning vocal ensemble returns to perform a joyful program of South African freedom song

event_description:
An exploration of the westward migration of Eastern European composers to Los Angeles for work in the film industry, coupled with the delight and buoyancy of Gabriela Montero’s famous classical improvisations, this time accompanying Charlie Chaplin’s film The Immigrant.

Montero’s visionary interpretations and unique compositional gifts have garnered her critical acclaim and a devoted following on the world stage. The New York Times says that “Montero’s playing had everything: crackling rhythmic brio, subtle shadings, steely power … soulful lyricism … unsentimental expressivity”. Celebrated for her exceptional musicality and ability to improvise, Montero is a frequent recitalist and chamber musician, having performed at such distinguished venues as Wigmore Hall, Carnegie Hall, Vienna Konzerthaus, Sydney Opera House, and the National Concert Hall in Taipei.
short_description: An exploration of the westward migration of Eastern European composers to Los Angeles for work in the film industry, cou

event_description:
Join over a hundred voices for an epic performance of some of the British choral tradition's most cherished works including Gustav Holst’s Psalm 148, and the Canadian premiere of Imogen Holst’s orchestration of Britten's Rejoice in the Lamb. 

These masterpieces frame Karl Jenkins’ genre-defying, cross-cultural Requiem, which combines the traditional Latin text with Japanese death poems and the resonance of a full orchestra with traditional Japanese instruments. A vibrant celebration of life's passages!
event_name: Orpheus Choir: Rejoice in the Lamb

short_name: Orpheus Choir: Rejoice in the Lamb

event_description:
Step back in time with a free visit to Spadina Museum, beautifully decorated for a 1920s Christmas. Visitors can enjoy the opulent holiday décor and period ambiance that once filled the home of the wealthy Austin family. Twinkling lights, antique ornaments, and rooms set for a classic Jazz Age celebration bring the spirit of the season to life.
As you stroll through the mansion, interpretive displays offer insights into the lavish holiday traditions of Toronto’s elite in the 1920s. In contrast, visitors will also learn about the experiences of the city’s less fortunate citizens during the same era—those who faced poverty, unemployment, and food insecurity during a time of great social and economic change.
From a grand dining room prepared for a festive feast to modest depictions of how the servants of the household marked the holidays, the experience paints a full picture of a Toronto Christmas in the early 20th century.
event_name: Jazz Age Christmas at Spadina Museum

short_name: Jazz Age Christmas at Spadina Museum

event_description:
Experience our world in vivid detail and see some of the most unusual species and their habitats in ways you never imagined. 

Each back-lit photograph provides exquisite quality and depth. From the photographer's eye to the camera's lens, viewers become witnesses to the lives animals live and the challenges they face. 

Emotive, surprising, and sometimes sobering, glimpses of life on our planet are showcased through exceptional talent, technical expertise, and perfectly captured moments.
event_name: Wildlife Photographer of the Year Exhibition
short_description: Experience our world in vivid detail and see some of the most unusual species and their habitats in ways you never imagi
short_name: Wildlife Photographer of the Year Exhibition

event_description:
Welcoming audiences into an energetic visions of stories where memory, resistance, and imagination intertwine. 

This year’s line-up follows the rhythms of identity, from the pulsing beats of Afro-Antillean music to the quiet landscapes of childhood wonder to journeys across mountains, cities, and deserts in search of home and the intimate crossings of generations, friendships and dreams. 

In these films, rupture gives way to transformation, and every frame holds the promise of renewal. We honour voices that refuse to be silenced, visions that reshape reality, and connections that reach across borders. 

This is both a celebration and a reflection, a space where stories become bridges, and where watching together creates imagination and opens innovation.
event_name: aluCine Latin Film and Media Arts Festival Toronto

event_description:
Through the use of sculpture, photography, video, and installation, this exhibition is a blend of different people and perspectives forming a kind of visual and sonic cacophony. It’s a nod to global (or even galactic) unity, and to the idea that despite all the noise and division, we’re more alike than not. 

In her Canadian debut, Intergalactic Planetary brings together imagery and works inspired by cities including Shanghai, Chongqing, Berlin, Tokyo, Bangkok and locations across the United States. Snelling explains, “Through this work, I ask: how can we move beyond our fears, borders, and egos to become more humane? Perhaps by staying curious, open, and willing to see each other more fully, we can take a small step toward connection, and even a glimmer of peace for the future”.

Join us on Nuit Blanche to view the exhibition's works, while DJ beats set the mood with dynamic sounds and enjoy two exhibition-inspired cocktails-one coffee-based and the other with an intergalactic twist.

event_description:
Beginning July 1st at Scarborough Museum, experience Washed Up by Hatecopy. The project captures the essence of liminal spaces that serve as cultural hubs for the South Asian immigrant communities, using the washing machine as a vessel to carry textiles that signify our roots and drawing visitors into an environment that intertwines the past, present, and future; acknowledging the dirty laundry of Canadian History and “Truth,” and reclaiming both seen and unseen spaces.

Maria Qamar (b. 1991) is a Toronto-based pop artist whose work is focused in the South Asian diaspora and immigrant communities and their cultural experiences. The work specializes in themes regarding feminism, social change, humour, pop culture, politics and romance. The artist has been recognized both nationally and internationally with exhibits and features in the Museum of Contemporary Arts, the National Arts Centre, Sotheby’s, Phillips Auction, and the AGO.
event_name: Washed Up: Pop-Up Installation at Scarborough Museum

event_description:
This pop-up installation explores the compelling stories and experiences of Toronto’s diverse communities who have fought for their sense of home, belonging and identity during periods of conflict and peace. 

This installation is created in partnership with the Toronto Metropolitan University's Masters of Digital Media program.
event_name: Echoes of Home: Pop-Up Exhibit at Fort York

event_description:
The Southern Netherlands — better known today as Flanders — was home to revolutionary artists. These extraordinary painters found new ways to depict reality, portray humanity, and tell stories that created parallels to their world then - and to our world today. 

This large-scale exhibition, featuring over 80 stunning art works and objects — medieval, Renaissance, and baroque paintings, sculptures and more — offers a doorway into the Southern Netherlands of 1400 to 1700. The exhibition's unique presentation introduces the visitor, through these rare, extraordinary artworks, to stories of enterprising townspeople, prosperous cities, and an ever-developing society.
event_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Masterworks
short_description: The Southern Netherlands — better known today as Flanders — was home to revolutionary artists. These extraordinary paint
short_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Mast

event_description:
This November, we remember Scarborough's very own GECO girls! Along with a pop-up panel highlighting these women, Scarborough Museum will be hosting a conversation with author and local historian, Barbara Dickson, as she discusses her book “Bomb Girls: Trading Aprons for Ammo” by the fireside, followed by a book signing. 

Challenging common gender narratives regarding war efforts, Dickson traces the lives of these women and their dangerous work at Canada’s largest fuse filling munitions factory. Ranging in age from 17 to 70, they included newcomers from countries like Nigeria, Greece, China, and Syria. If you love what you learn, limited copies will be available for purchase.

As part of the Community Memories project the City of Toronto Collections and Archives team will be part of this event. If you have family photo you'd like to preserve, they will scan and digitize it for free!

Treats and refreshments will be available on a first come-first served basis, while quantities last.
event_name: Bomb Girls: Trading Aprons for Ammo - In Conversation with Barbara Dickson at Scarborough Museum

short_name: Bomb Girls: Trading Aprons for Ammo - In Conversation with B

event_description: Join us in exploring the tension between aging, identity, and a society obsessed with youth and technology. Inspired by Dylan Thomas’ poem "Do not go gentle into that good night", this gallery exhibition challenges the notion that growing older means fading away. Instead, it celebrates the wisdom, defiance, and power that come with time.
short_description: Join us in exploring the tension between aging, identity, and a society obsessed with youth and technology. Inspired by

cost_notes: Soulpepper Theatre offers a Free 25 & Under program. See website for details.
event_description:
The past never really stays in the past.  

A group of old classmates self-declared the “Multi-Ethnic Reject Group” reunites to pre-game their twentieth high school reunion, but nostalgia quickly turns into something darker. 

As drinks flow and old wounds resurface, they confront the choices that shaped them, the friendships that endured or crumbled, and the presence of something, or someone they can’t escape. 

Sharp, theatrical, and deeply moving, this is a reckoning for elder millennials, caught between who they were, who they’ve become, and the world they never saw coming. When the night ends, will they still recognize themselves?

Good at bluffing? Prove it!

Calling all game enthusiasts in Toronto! Join in for a fun-filled time where we will be playing the social deduction game Werewolf. Whether you're a seasoned player or a newbie, this event is perfect for anyone looking to be social while sharpening their strategic thinking skills. 

Please remember kindness, respect, and safety for all. See website below for mailing list and more information.

A spoken word poetry program for youth in the Jane and Finch community. Youth will learn the fundamentals of spoken word with Jayda Marley and Naiesha Marques and have the opportunity to present what they have learned at a final showcase for family and friends. 

A City of Toronto Cultural Hotspot Signature Project.

event_description:
Singer-songwriter Jory Nash returns with his tenth studio album. 

A Folk Music Ontario Award recipient and five-time Canadian Folk Music Award nominee, he continues to blend elements of folk, jazz, blues and soul into an original stew of sound. 

Joined by Jason Fowler on guitars, Maury Lafoy on bass, Robbie Grunwald on keys, Mark Mariash on percussion and featuring an extra special guest Lori Cullen on harmony vocals.
short_description:
Singer-songwriter Jory Nash returns with his tenth studio album. 

A Folk Music Ontario Award recipient and five-time Ca

event_description: Drawing inspiration from the deep roots of folk, Celtic, Americana and bluegrass music, enjoy their timeless and refreshing sound that pays homage to their heritage while embracing contemporary influences.
short_description: Drawing inspiration from the deep roots of folk, Celtic, Americana and bluegrass music, enjoy their timeless and refresh

event_description:
In the chaos of urban life, we often forget to take a moment to breathe. Take in a moment of stillness, as we inviting visitors to stand beneath something that feels alive.

The outdoor installation, made from a suspended grid of copper leaves, reimagines the shelter of a forest canopy with each leaf individually cut and hung to form a floating canopy above. By day, the leaves catch the light and scatter soft shadows across the ground. By night, lighting transforms the installation, casting intricate patterns on surrounding surfaces and shifting the atmosphere of the space entirely. As wind moves through the piece, the leaves gently sway and rustle, adding a subtle layer of sound to the experience.

Responding to its surroundings and shifting with the light, weather and movement of people passing beneath it, this work offers a dynamic and reflective space in the heart of the city. 

Designed by RAW Works, with Roland Rom Colthoff, Suleman Khan, Elmira Yousefi and Aaron Hendershot.
short_description: In the chaos of urban life, we often forget to take a moment to breathe. Take in a moment of stillness, as we inviting v

event_description:
Curated by Mikinaak Migwans, Earthwork redefines a term that until now has referred to a type of artistic practice associated within the larger conceptual framework of land art. 

In this exhibition, Migwans shifts our understanding of earthwork to refer to a way of working, rather than the making of singular objects, reclaiming the art historical framing from an Indigenous perspective. It considers multiple layers of engagement with the land, including a history of land defense movements, medicine walks, and ancestral practices of prescribed burns, alongside contemporary art.

Featured artists include Michael Belmore, BUSH Gallery (Gabrielle L’Hirondelle Hill, Peter Morin, Tania Willard), Faye HeavyShield, Art Hunter, Alex Jacobs-Blum, Mike MacDonald, Lisa Myers, Edward Poitras, and Protect the Tract Collective.
event_name: Art Museum at the University of Toronto: Earthwork
short_description: Curated by Mikinaak Migwans, Earthwork redefines a term that until now has referred to a type of artistic practice assoc
short_name: Art Museum at the University of Toronto: Earthwork

event_description:
The celebrated New Orleans Jazz Orchestra performs a special program of your favourite holiday songs done with New Orleans style.

Founded in 2002, the orchestra celebrates the American jazz portfolio with an emphasis on developing the New Orleans jazz scene. Led by Grammy Award-winning drummer and artistic director Adonis Rose, the group is known for their versatility and high energy performances.

After the concert, enjoy a beverage and more music!

short_name: Adonis Rose and the New Orleans Jazz Orchestra present: A Cr

event_description:
Performed by “Toronto’s best young chamber musicians” (Bachtrack), this unique program charts a course across a single night, framing the emotional apotheosis within Arnold Schoenberg’s Transfigured Night, and its depiction of the tension between and reconciliation of two lovers. 

Juxtaposing three settings of Josquin de Prez’s Renaissance song Mille Regretz (1000 Regrets) with contemporary chamber works, we begin precisely at sunset in Toronto and reimagining each work as a time and corresponding emotional state over the course of the night, concluding with dawn and the lovers’ renewal.
event_name: The Happenstancers: Always Darkest … Dawn Always

short_name: The Happenstancers: Always Darkest … Dawn Always

Designed for people with physical disabilities, with a focus on mobility-friendly trails and raptor sightings. There will be plenty of rest stops and a welcoming atmosphere for participants and their support persons. 

All ages are welcome but those under the age of 16 must be accompanied by an adult. Pets are not permitted at this program. Service animals are always welcome.

French language service is available upon request. Please let us know.

event_description:
Sharks have intrigued humans for as long as we have explored the oceans. The terrifying monster from the movie Jaws is what many might imagine when they think of these animals, but they are far more fascinating and complex than their depiction in popular culture.

This exhibition invites you to uncover fresh perspectives, groundbreaking research, and the astounding diversity of this ancient group of fishes.

Visitors will delve into the anatomy, behaviour, and history of sharks, from familiar favourites like tiger sharks and great whites to lesser-known species like the dwarf lanternshark—a tiny, light-producing marvel small enough to hold in your hand.

event_description:
Three-time Grammy Award-winning violinist Hilary Hahn melds expressive musicality and technical expertise with a diverse repertoire guided by artistic curiosity. She is currently artist-in-residence at both the Chicago Symphony Orchestra and London’s Wigmore Hall, and is co-founder and vice president of artistic partnerships of the AI-music initiative Deepmusic.AI. Hahn is a prolific and celebrated recording artist whose 21 feature albums on Decca, Deutsche Grammophon, and Sony have all opened in the top ten of the Billboard charts.

Enjoy her program of Maurice Ravel: Violin Sonata No. 2 in G Major, M. 77, Bun-Ching Lam: Solitude d’automne, Lili Boulanger: Nocturne, Maurice Ravel: Pièce en forme de Habanera, M. 51, Claude Debussy: Sonata for Violin and Piano in G Minor, Scott Tixier: new duo work (North American premiere), and Gabriel Fauré: Violin Sonata No. 1 in A Major, op. 13.
event_name: Hilary Hahn on Violin with Tom Poster on Piano
short_description: Three-time Grammy Award-winning violinist Hilary Hahn melds expressive musicality and technical expertise with a diverse
short_name: Hilary Hahn on Violin with Tom Poster on Piano

event_description:
Since its formation in Berlin in 2019, the quartet has garnered more awards and honors than any other ensemble of its generation. 

With Jonathan and Lukas Schwartz on first violin and cello, and Amellie Wallner and Mayu Konoe on second violin and viola, the quartet’s name is derived from the Esperanto words “Leon” and “koro,” together meaning “Lionheart.”

The quartet has earned a reputation not only for its technical brilliance and bold artistic risk-taking, but also for its deep sensitivity to the unique sonority and emotional landscape of each work it performs. Enjoy their program of Joseph Haydn: String Quartet  in D Major, Op. 20, No. 4, Henriëtte Bosmans: String Quartet (1927) and Franz Schubert: String Quartet in D minor, D. 810 "Death and the Maiden".
short_description: Since its formation in Berlin in 2019, the quartet has garnered more awards and honors than any other ensemble of its ge

event_description:
The Southern Netherlands — better known today as Flanders — was home to revolutionary artists. These extraordinary painters found new ways to depict reality, portray humanity, and tell stories that created parallels to their world then - and to our world today. 

This large-scale exhibition, featuring over 80 stunning art works and objects — medieval, Renaissance, and baroque paintings, sculptures and more — offers a doorway into the Southern Netherlands of 1400 to 1700. The exhibition's unique presentation introduces the visitor, through these rare, extraordinary artworks, to stories of enterprising townspeople, prosperous cities, and an ever-developing society.
event_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Masterworks
short_description: The Southern Netherlands — better known today as Flanders — was home to revolutionary artists. These extraordinary paint
short_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Mast

event_description:
Acclaimed by the New York Times as “one of the finest conductors of her generation,” multiple Grammy Award-winning conductor JoAnn Falletta serves as Music Director of the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra, Music Director Laureate of the Virginia Symphony Orchestra, Principal Guest Conductor of the Brevard Music Center, and Artistic Adviser of the Hawaii Symphony Orchestra. 

Upon her appointment to the Buffalo Philharmonic, Falletta became the first woman to lead a major American ensemble. She was recently named one of the Fifty Great Conductors, past and present, by Gramophone magazine, and has been hailed for having “Toscanini’s tight control over ensemble, Walter’s affectionate balancing of inner voices, Stokowski’s gutsy showmanship, and a controlled frenzy worthy of Bernstein” by The Washington Post.

Enjoy her program of John Adams: Short Ride in a Fast Machine, Ludwig van Beethoven: Piano Concerto No. 3 in C Minor, op. 37 and Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov: Scheherazade, op. 35.
event_name: Royal Conservatory Orchestra with conductor JoAnn Falletta
short_description: Acclaimed by the New York Times as “one of the finest conductors of her generation,” multiple Grammy Award-winning condu
short_name: Royal Conservatory Orchestra with conductor JoAnn Falletta

You’ll be provided with an apron, but this can get messy, so don’t wear your best clothes. Feel free to wear neon or white to glow in our studio!

This workshop is perfect for beginners and experienced artists alike. Must be ages 10 and up to participate. All minor participants must be accompanied by one paying adult.

event_description:
Experience the Small Business Forum 2025: Small Business, Big World - the City of Toronto’s free premier full-day event dedicated to celebrating and supporting small businesses. This year's Small Business Forum 2025 will offer: 
- main stage programming with keynote speakers and expert panels,
- speed mentorship workshops where business experts share their wisdom and answer your burning questions,
- a trade show hosting a diverse display of small business services and goods providers, and
- opportunities to network, build valuable connections, and expand your reach both within Toronto and internationally.

A more in-depth agenda and program guide is in development and will be shared at www.toronto.ca/BusinessForum
event_name: Small Business Forum 2025: Small Business, Big World

event_description:
Beginning July 1st at Scarborough Museum, experience Washed Up by Hatecopy. The project captures the essence of liminal spaces that serve as cultural hubs for the South Asian immigrant communities, using the washing machine as a vessel to carry textiles that signify our roots and drawing visitors into an environment that intertwines the past, present, and future; acknowledging the dirty laundry of Canadian History and “Truth,” and reclaiming both seen and unseen spaces.

Maria Qamar (b. 1991) is a Toronto-based pop artist whose work is focused in the South Asian diaspora and immigrant communities and their cultural experiences. The work specializes in themes regarding feminism, social change, humour, pop culture, politics and romance. The artist has been recognized both nationally and internationally with exhibits and features in the Museum of Contemporary Arts, the National Arts Centre, Sotheby’s, Phillips Auction, and the AGO.
event_name: Washed Up: Pop-Up Installation at Scarborough Museum

short_name: Washed Up: Pop-Up Installation at Scarborough Museum

event_description:
Welcoming audiences into an energetic visions of stories where memory, resistance, and imagination intertwine. 

This year’s line-up follows the rhythms of identity, from the pulsing beats of Afro-Antillean music to the quiet landscapes of childhood wonder to journeys across mountains, cities, and deserts in search of home and the intimate crossings of generations, friendships and dreams. 

In these films, rupture gives way to transformation, and every frame holds the promise of renewal. We honour voices that refuse to be silenced, visions that reshape reality, and connections that reach across borders. 

This is both a celebration and a reflection, a space where stories become bridges, and where watching together creates imagination and opens innovation.
event_name: aluCine Latin Film and Media Arts Festival Toronto
short_description:
Welcoming audiences into an energetic visions of stories where memory, resistance, and imagination intertwine. 

This ye
short_name: aluCine Latin Film and Media Arts Festival Toronto

event_description:
The Nordheimer ravine sits in the Don River Watershed because the now buried brook that fed the nature there, ran to the Don. As a ravine it is a storm water basin. This walk will review the details of how the ravine was chosen early on in the city's engagement with recovery of biodiversity in the Don Watershed, and how it is maintained as an environmentally significant area. Susan Aaron has been the volunteer team leader there for 20 years

The process of revitalization will be reviewed in detail. And the dissolution of private and public lands, for a shared forest, and the stability it brings to slopes and environment will also be dealt with. The ravine forest offsets and slows an urban heat island, stabilizes weather, and offers clean air.
The notion of stopping this nature at the line of public and private lands, can end and the forest be expanded onto private lands, as a function of shared biodiversity. Living this way invites homes to be integrated with forest as sustainable.
short_description: The Nordheimer ravine sits in the Don River Watershed because the now buried brook that fed the nature there, ran to the

cost_notes: Purchase advance tickets online using the City of Toronto's program registrations software. If you do not already have an account, you will need to create one. If you have trouble registering, please contact spadina@toronto.ca or call 416-392-6910.
event_description:
Join us for an unforgettable evening of history, mystery, and the supernatural. Acclaimed author Ann McDougall will present a reading from her newly published book, A Ghost in the Room: Supernatural Adventures in Historic Houses, followed by an immersive exploration of historic techniques used in attempts to communicate with the dead  (both sincere and duplicitous).
Step inside the historic house as we uncover the Austin family's customs surrounding death and mourning, as well as the popularity of Spiritualism from mid 19th through the early 20th century. Guests will explore why the desire to communicate with the dead surged during the interwar period, and how grief and psychological trauma opened doors for both sincere belief and deception.
This event blends scholarly insight with Halloween thrill, debunking the myths while honoring the very human reasons we seek to connect with the beyond.
Costumes welcome.
Ages 12+, ages 12-16 must be accompanied by a ticketed adult.
event_name: A Skeptic’s Séance: Psychology and the Supernatural at Spadina Museum
short_description: Join us for an unforgettable evening of history, mystery, and the supernatural. Acclaimed author Ann McDougall will pres
short_name: A Skeptic’s Séance: Psychology and the Supernatural at Spadi

event_description:
Curated by Yantong Li, a Master of Visual Studies Curatorial Studies graduate student. 

Featured artists Kent Chan, Alvin Luong, and Solveig Qu Suess interrogate the way we currently consume media about environmental precarity, inviting viewers to engage in a dialogue and sit with representations of catastrophe that deemphasize the spectacular and dramatic. 

Dwelling Under Distant Suns highlights the struggle to make visible the increasingly unpredictable landscape of the climate crisis and other human-led impacts on the environment. Using speculative storytelling and myth-making through film-based works, this exhibition brings a sense of immediacy to our planet’s growing climate crisis and the environmental dangers that feel distant or out of sight.
event_name: Art Museum at the University of Toronto: Dwelling Under Distant Suns
short_description:

Featured artists Kent Chan, Alv
short_name: Art Museum at the University of Toronto: Dwelling Under Dist

event_description:
Curated by Yantong Li, a Master of Visual Studies Curatorial Studies graduate student. 

Featured artists Kent Chan, Alvin Luong, and Solveig Qu Suess interrogate the way we currently consume media about environmental precarity, inviting viewers to engage in a dialogue and sit with representations of catastrophe that deemphasize the spectacular and dramatic. 

Dwelling Under Distant Suns highlights the struggle to make visible the increasingly unpredictable landscape of the climate crisis and other human-led impacts on the environment. Using speculative storytelling and myth-making through film-based works, this exhibition brings a sense of immediacy to our planet’s growing climate crisis and the environmental dangers that feel distant or out of sight.
event_name: Art Museum at the University of Toronto: Dwelling Under Distant Suns

event_description:
Curated by Mikinaak Migwans, Earthwork redefines a term that until now has referred to a type of artistic practice associated within the larger conceptual framework of land art. 

In this exhibition, Migwans shifts our understanding of earthwork to refer to a way of working, rather than the making of singular objects, reclaiming the art historical framing from an Indigenous perspective. It considers multiple layers of engagement with the land, including a history of land defense movements, medicine walks, and ancestral practices of prescribed burns, alongside contemporary art.

Featured artists include Michael Belmore, BUSH Gallery (Gabrielle L’Hirondelle Hill, Peter Morin, Tania Willard), Faye HeavyShield, Art Hunter, Alex Jacobs-Blum, Mike MacDonald, Lisa Myers, Edward Poitras, and Protect the Tract Collective.
event_name: Art Museum at the University of Toronto: Earthwork

event_description:
Join us on a chilling and thrilling journey through the dark history of the city as we delve into the world of ghosts, graveyards, hangings, and haunts.

 Prepare to be captivated by spine-tingling ghost stories about haunted theatres, unsolved mysteries, secrets hiding in plain sight, and spooky historic buildings. Our outdoor tour will take you on a hair-raising paranormal adventure, departing from the courtyard in front of the Hockey Hall of Fame. 

Get ready to see the city in a whole new light, or rather, darkness, as you uncover the eerie and supernatural tales that lurk in its shadows.
short_description: Join us on a chilling and thrilling journey through the dark history of the city as we delve into the world of ghosts, g

event_description:
Celebrate the works of acclaimed Irish playwright, Conor McPherson.

The Weir looks in a small rural pub in the West of Ireland, where local lads spin tales of the supernatural, as they vie for the attention of a young woman who recently moved into the area. Little do they know that she has her own personal and compelling story to weave...

Directed by Co-artistic Producer, Rod Ceballos and features Richard Harte (The Boys in the Photograph), Mairi Babb (WAR HORSE), David Mackett (The Good Thief), and Enda Reilly (Toronto Bloomsday Festival).

event_description:
As night falls, we’ll set out on a lantern-lit stroll along the cobblestone streets of the historic Distillery District, one of Toronto’s most haunted spots! 

Learn about the tragic events that left their mark and hear spine-chilling tales of paranormal encounters from this iconic area. Feel the goosebumps rise as you explore the narrow alleyways and hidden corners where spirits are said to lurk. 

Whether you’re a history buff, a ghost enthusiast, or just looking for a unique experience, this outdoor tour is sure to captivate your imagination. Get ready to experience the thrills and chills like never before.
event_name: Spirits of the Distillery District Ghost Tour
short_description: As night falls, we’ll set out on a lantern-lit stroll along the cobblestone streets of the historic Distillery District,
short_name: Spirits of the Distillery District Ghost Tour

event_description:
Making Home in Scarborough is a vibrant pop-up installation celebrating memory, identity, and belonging through cultural traditions and objects we hold dear to our hearts in generations past, present and future. 
 

Co-created through conversation and care, community members were invited to share a meaningful object, rooted in a heartfelt story. All speak to how home is made not only in buildings or borders, but in the places, people, and practices that give life meaning. 
 
As you explore the exhibition, we invite you to reflect: "What does home mean to you?" If you live in Scarborough, "What does Making Home in Scarborough Mean to you?" 
 
We are grateful for our community collaborators: Native Child and Family Services / Scarborough Child & Family Life Centre, Malvern Family Resource Centre, TDSB Newcomer Services (Malvern), Toby's Place, Scarborough Museum Youth Collective and Change Made.
event_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Making Home in Scarborough at Scarborough Museum
short_description: Making Home in Scarborough is a vibrant pop-up installation celebrating memory, identity, and belonging through cultural
short_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Making Home in Scarborough at Scarborough Mu

event_description:
Welcome to Le Dolci’s exclusive 5-day Parisian Baking Series: Desserts from Paris! Perfect for beginners, this hands-on course runs 5 hours daily (plus a 30-minute lunch) and teaches the art of French pastry.

Day 1: Master fruit and chocolate tarts.
Day 2: Create flaky croissants and pain au chocolat.
Day 3: Learn enriched doughs like brioche and babka.
Day 4: Pipe and fill éclairs and cream puffs with choux pastry.
Day 5: Perfect macarons and soufflés.

Guided by expert chefs, you'll gain practical skills and pastry theory. Join us and bring the sweet taste of Paris to life!

event_description:
Autumn is a season when we embrace death and dying as we watch the leaves turn and the weather change, Mother Nature shows us how to die with grace. 

Learn about metabolizing your grief and how sound, movement, community and storytelling can alleviate symptoms, building capacity for holding your grief. Explore legacy and build a community memorial together. Come to share your grief aloud, or come to be quiet and listen to the trees. 

Giveaway opportunities present at every walk!

Start your day with some morning yoga to gently wake up your body, breath, and senses. Each class will explore some meditation, pranayama (breathwork), and other grounding techniques for the nervous system, as well as move through some movement and stretches to gently energise the body.

Suitable for all levels including beginners. Seated, standing and lying down poses will be included with different options and students are encouraged to find and choose what works best for them.

Please bring your own mat.

event_description:
We are pleased to bring you the fifth annual Greek International Film Festival Tour of Canada (GIFFT).

This is a Canadian national film festival that will take place in 11 Canadian cities simultaneously. Those cities include: Toronto, Vancouver, Edmonton, Calgary, Regina, Winnipeg, London (Ontario), Hamilton/Niagara, Ottawa, and Halifax.

GIFFT is a showcase and celebration of Greek cinema and filmmakers of Greek Heritage. This festival will provide exciting platform for directors, writers, producers, and actors of Greek Heritage to showcase their exceptional art across Canada.

This workshop is perfect for beginners and experienced artists alike. Must be ages 10 and up to participate. All minor participants must be accompanied by one paying adult.

event_description:
In this new solo work, Laurence Lemieux explores how lineage and the sentiment of belonging has affected her behaviour. 

Anne, is one of Laurence’s ancestors and the starting point of this exploration. The choreographic score draws on these findings, building a structure around individual power and belonging. 

The performance space is designed by senior artist, Edward Poitras, supported by an original composition by Aidan McConnell, lighting design by Nic Vincent, and rehearsal direction by Danielle Baskerville.
short_description: In this new solo work, Laurence Lemieux explores how lineage and the sentiment of belonging has affected her behaviour.

cost_notes: Subscribe and save up to 35% on your ticket.
event_description:
This acclaimed European ensemble unites Christian Tetzlaff, one of Europe’s leading violinists, with his sister, cellist Tanja Tetzlaff, and the dazzling Kiveli Doerken for an evening of piano trio favorites.

Originally formed in 2004, the trio found new energy when Doerken joined the siblings. 

“The accord among the three players was perfect… the entire concert felt moving and triumphant, joyful and sad all at once, just as the best music should be.” - Vladimir Jurowski for the Threepenny Review. 

Enjoy a program of Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart: Piano Trio in E major, K. 542, Bedřich Smetana: Piano Trio in G minor, Op. 15, Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky: Piano Trio in A minor, Op. 50.
short_description: This acclaimed European ensemble unites Christian Tetzlaff, one of Europe’s leading violinists, with his sister, cellist

event_description:
This is a contemporary form of environmental art created by artists who are  concerned about reducing waste, recycling, and making the world a better place, while raising awareness about environmental changes.

 It aims to showcases the beauty and creativity of using recycled, environmentally friendly or sustainable materials to create phenomenal artwork, using water-based paints, natural pigments and recycled materials to name a few elements. lt is art that advocates for the planet, catering to all ages and present in various mediums, including paintings, sculptures or fashion.

Presenting our second annual art exhibition, we will be utilizing selected artists to mentor African and Caribbean communities on the positioning of multicultural history and art within the Canadian cultural landscape.

This pop-up installation explores the compelling stories and experiences of Toronto’s diverse communities who have fought for their sense of home, belonging and identity during periods of conflict and peace. 

This installation is created in partnership with the Toronto Metropolitan University's Masters of Digital Media program.
