event_description:
Curated by Yantong Li, a Master of Visual Studies Curatorial Studies graduate student. 

Featured artists Kent Chan, Alvin Luong, and Solveig Qu Suess interrogate the way we currently consume media about environmental precarity, inviting viewers to engage in a dialogue and sit with representations of catastrophe that deemphasize the spectacular and dramatic. 

Dwelling Under Distant Suns highlights the struggle to make visible the increasingly unpredictable landscape of the climate crisis and other human-led impacts on the environment. Using speculative storytelling and myth-making through film-based works, this exhibition brings a sense of immediacy to our planet’s growing climate crisis and the environmental dangers that feel distant or out of sight.
event_name: Art Museum at the University of Toronto: Dwelling Under Distant Suns

short_name: Art Museum at the University of Toronto: Dwelling Under Dist

event_description:
Curated by Yantong Li, a Master of Visual Studies Curatorial Studies graduate student. 

Featured artists Kent Chan, Alvin Luong, and Solveig Qu Suess interrogate the way we currently consume media about environmental precarity, inviting viewers to engage in a dialogue and sit with representations of catastrophe that deemphasize the spectacular and dramatic. 

Dwelling Under Distant Suns highlights the struggle to make visible the increasingly unpredictable landscape of the climate crisis and other human-led impacts on the environment. Using speculative storytelling and myth-making through film-based works, this exhibition brings a sense of immediacy to our planet’s growing climate crisis and the environmental dangers that feel distant or out of sight.
event_name: Art Museum at the University of Toronto: Dwelling Under Distant Suns

event_description:
The most talked about play of the decade.

Sharp, provocative, and wildly entertaining theatrical sensation that has sparked conversations from Broadway to London. Now making its Canadian premiere, this electrifying play by Jeremy O. Harris turns up the heat on love, race, and relationships in ways that are bold, unexpected, and impossible to forget.  

A daring, seductive, and razor-sharp satire, audiences will be on a journey where pleasure and history meet, flipping assumptions and igniting sparks along the way. It’s a show that’s as playfully cheeky as it is thought-provoking, designed to make you feel, think, and maybe even blush.

event_description:
Matthias Goerne is one of the most versatile and internationally sought-after vocalists, and a frequent guest at renowned festivals and concert halls who has collaborated with the world’s leading orchestras, conductors, and pianists. Born in Weimar, he studied with Hans-Joachim Beyer in Leipzig, and later with Elisabeth Schwarzkopf and Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau.

Grammy Award-winning pianist Daniil Trifonov has made a spectacular ascent of the classical music world as a solo artist, champion of the concerto repertoire, chamber and vocal collaborator, and composer. Combining consummate technique with rare sensitivity and depth, his performances are a perpetual source of awe. The Times herald he is “without question the most astounding pianist of our age”

Enjoy their program of Franz Schubert: Die Winterreise, op. 89, D. 911.
event_name: Baritone Matthias Goerne with Pianist Daniil Trifonov
short_description: Matthias Goerne is one of the most versatile and internationally sought-after vocalists, and a frequent guest at renowne
short_name: Baritone Matthias Goerne with Pianist Daniil Trifonov

event_description:
The Southern Netherlands, better known today as Flanders, was home to revolutionary artists. 

These extraordinary painters found new ways to depict reality, portray humanity, and tell stories that created parallels to their world then and to our world today. This large-scale exhibition, featuring over 80 stunning art works and objects, medieval, renaissance, baroque paintings, sculptures and more, offering a doorway to art between 1400 to 1700. 

The exhibition's unique presentation introduces the visitor, through these rare, extraordinary artworks, to stories of enterprising townspeople, prosperous cities, and an ever-developing society.
event_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Masterworks

The Southern Netherlands, better known today as Flanders, was home to revolutionary artists. 

These extraordinary paint
short_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Mast

event_description:
Experience our world in vivid detail and see some of the most unusual species and their habitats in ways you never imagined. 

Each back-lit photograph provides exquisite quality and depth. From the photographer's eye to the camera's lens, viewers become witnesses to the lives animals live and the challenges they face. 

Emotive, surprising, and sometimes sobering, glimpses of life on our planet are showcased through exceptional talent, technical expertise, and perfectly captured moments.
event_name: Wildlife Photographer of the Year Exhibition

event_description:
A site-specific mural by Winnipeg-based artist Anna Binta Diallo, exploring themes of time, memory and interdependence through the metaphor of fossils. Using silhouettes of human forms assembled from found images, Diallo creates a visual narrative on the interconnectedness of the past, present and future. 

Originally exhibited at the Musée d’art contemporain de Montréal, it invites viewers to reflect on how contemporary actions and objects will serve as relics for future generations, emphasizing the importance and responsibility of shaping collective heritage.

event_description:
Making Home in Scarborough is a vibrant pop-up installation celebrating memory, identity, and belonging through cultural traditions and objects we hold dear to our hearts in generations past, present and future. 
 

Co-created through conversation and care, community members were invited to share a meaningful object, rooted in a heartfelt story. All speak to how home is made not only in buildings or borders, but in the places, people, and practices that give life meaning. 
 
As you explore the exhibition, we invite you to reflect: "What does home mean to you?" If you live in Scarborough, "What does Making Home in Scarborough Mean to you?" 
 
We are grateful for our community collaborators: Native Child and Family Services / Scarborough Child & Family Life Centre, Malvern Family Resource Centre, TDSB Newcomer Services (Malvern), Toby's Place, Scarborough Museum Youth Collective and Change Made.
event_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Making Home in Scarborough at Scarborough Museum
short_description: Making Home in Scarborough is a vibrant pop-up installation celebrating memory, identity, and belonging through cultural
short_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Making Home in Scarborough at Scarborough Mu

event_description:
A consummate musician, with a ferocious intellect, Sir András Schiff is one of the greatest pianists of our time. World-renowned as a pianist, conductor, pedagogue, and lecturer, he brings masterful and intellectual insights to his performances which have inspired audiences and critics alike. 

His many honours include the International Mozarteum Foundation’s Golden Medal, Germany’s Great Cross of Merit with Star, the Royal Philharmonic Society’s Gold Medal, a Knighthood for Services to Music, and a Doctorate from the Royal College of Music.

Sir András Schiff is no longer providing exact recital programs in advance and prefers to announce his repertoire from the stage.

Please join us! This concert is preceded by a short performance by talented students of The Royal Conservatory.
short_description: A consummate musician, with a ferocious intellect, Sir András Schiff is one of the greatest pianists of our time. World-

cost_notes: Free 25 and under program available, see website for details.
event_description:
Rural England, 1759. Halley’s Comet burns in the sky, and a young woman is sentenced to hang. But when she tries to escape the noose by claiming to be pregnant, a jury of twelve women are gathered to decide whether she is telling the truth. As tensions rise, their task becomes a reckoning: with the law, with power, and with the roles they’re forced to play in a world that silences them.

Tony-Award Nominee Lucy Kirkwood’s The Welkin (Chimerica, The Children) is a bold and blistering courtroom drama, by equal turns darkly comic and quietly devastating, this is a tale of justice, duty, and righteous dissent.

Contain warning: this show contains scenes of violence and mature content, including domestic abuse and miscarriage, descriptions of hanging and sexual assault, child death, and strong language.
short_description: Rural England, 1759. Halley’s Comet burns in the sky, and a young woman is sentenced to hang. But when she tries to esca

cost_notes: Soulpepper Theatre offers a Free 25 & Under program. See website for details.
event_description:
The past never really stays in the past.  

A group of old classmates self-declared the “Multi-Ethnic Reject Group” reunites to pre-game their twentieth high school reunion, but nostalgia quickly turns into something darker. 

As drinks flow and old wounds resurface, they confront the choices that shaped them, the friendships that endured or crumbled, and the presence of something, or someone they can’t escape. 

Sharp, theatrical, and deeply moving, this is a reckoning for elder millennials, caught between who they were, who they’ve become, and the world they never saw coming. When the night ends, will they still recognize themselves?

event_description:
The Manchester trio who inspirationally blend jazz, classical, and electronic influences, make their Koerner Hall debut with a powerful new album, Necessary Fictions, which finds pianist Chris Illingworth, bassist Nick Blacka, and drummer Jon Scott, digging deep internally to reach “what we think are our integral, authentic qualities at this moment in time.”  

"... powered by fluttering, junglist drums, slithering bass lines, and an increasing bank of Eno-esque digital manipulations. Hypnotic stuff." - The Guardian

Enjoy drinks and light refreshments and a postlude concert afterwards.
short_description: The Manchester trio who inspirationally blend jazz, classical, and electronic influences, make their Koerner Hall debut

event_description:
Extraordinary artists of The Glenn Gould School’s vocal program and the Royal Conservatory Orchestra present an Italian comedic double bill of Rossini's La cambiale di matrimonio and Puccini's Gianni Schicchi. 

Conducted by Gordon Gerrard and directed by Robert McQueen.
event_name: The Glenn Gould School Spring Opera: Serenata Italiana
short_description: Extraordinary artists of The Glenn Gould School’s vocal program and the Royal Conservatory Orchestra present an Italian
short_name: The Glenn Gould School Spring Opera: Serenata Italiana

event_description:
Curated by Mikinaak Migwans, Earthwork redefines a term that until now has referred to a type of artistic practice associated within the larger conceptual framework of land art. 

In this exhibition, Migwans shifts our understanding of earthwork to refer to a way of working, rather than the making of singular objects, reclaiming the art historical framing from an Indigenous perspective. It considers multiple layers of engagement with the land, including a history of land defense movements, medicine walks, and ancestral practices of prescribed burns, alongside contemporary art.

Featured artists include Michael Belmore, BUSH Gallery (Gabrielle L’Hirondelle Hill, Peter Morin, Tania Willard), Faye HeavyShield, Art Hunter, Alex Jacobs-Blum, Mike MacDonald, Lisa Myers, Edward Poitras, and Protect the Tract Collective.
event_name: Art Museum at the University of Toronto: Earthwork

event_description:
The Southern Netherlands — better known today as Flanders — was home to revolutionary artists. These extraordinary painters found new ways to depict reality, portray humanity, and tell stories that created parallels to their world then - and to our world today. 

This large-scale exhibition, featuring over 80 stunning art works and objects — medieval, Renaissance, and baroque paintings, sculptures and more — offers a doorway into the Southern Netherlands of 1400 to 1700. The exhibition's unique presentation introduces the visitor, through these rare, extraordinary artworks, to stories of enterprising townspeople, prosperous cities, and an ever-developing society.
event_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Masterworks
short_description: The Southern Netherlands — better known today as Flanders — was home to revolutionary artists. These extraor
short_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Mast

event_description:
This fall, immerse yourself with a bold collection of abstract works reflecting the beauty in disorder and inspired by the transformation of the autumn season.

Celebrate the season’s unpredictable rhythms with live art, refreshments, and a chance to meet the artists. Don’t miss the opportunity to experience the in-between where colours collide, textures evolve and emotions spills across the canvas.
short_description: This fall, immerse yourself with a bold collection of abstract works reflecting the beauty in disorder and inspired by t

event_description:
Born in South Korea, Kyung Wha Chung is recognised throughout the world as one of the finest violinists of her generation. A prolific recording artist, her dazzling and probing artistry has made her a much-acclaimed performer throughout her 50-year career. Lauded for her passion, musicality, and the intense excitement that she brings to her performances, Chung’s uniquely expressive interpretations of the violin literature have established her as an artist of the very highest stature. She has received many prizes and honours, including the Medal of Civil Merit, the government of South Korea’s highest honour. 

Pianist Kevin Kenner has been praised as "one of the finest American pianists to come along in years" by the Chicago Tribune. 

Please join us! This concert is preceded by a short performance by talented students of The Royal Conservatory.
event_name: Violinist Kyung Wha Chung with Pianist Kevin Kenner
short_description: Born in South Korea, Kyung Wha Chung is recognised throughout the world as one of the finest violinists of her generatio
short_name: Violinist Kyung Wha Chung with Pianist Kevin Kenner

event_description:
Join us in celebrating joy, light, and culture at Toronto’s largest Diwali celebration!

Also known as Deepavali, the Festival of Lights symbolizes the victory of light over darkness, good over evil, and knowledge over ignorance.

Bring your family, friends, and neighbors to experience stunning light displays, delicious global cuisine, live music and cultural performances, musical Ramayana, a showcase and a fun kid's zone.

event_description:
Experience Toronto like never before with this double-decker night tour. Step aboard an iconic open-top bus and embark on an enchanting journey through the sparkling city lights. Marvel at Toronto's iconic landmarks as they come to life under the night sky.

From the towering CN Tower to the historic Old Town, dive into the sights at your guide illuminates the city's rich history and vibrant culture. With panoramic views from the open-air top deck, capture breathtaking sights and create unforgettable memories.

Enjoy an evening of wonder and discovery on a double-decker night tour of Toronto with guaranteed seating on the upper level.
short_description: Experience Toronto like never before with this double-decker night tour. Step aboard an iconic open-top bus and embark o

event_description:
Discover how homes shape identity through the Austin family story and contemporary art at Spadina Museum. Reimagine history, reframe home.

“Home at Spadina Museum” considers how people are influenced by their home. We look at those who make it a home and those who live in it are shaped by domestic spaces. Through interpretation of the Austin family and into contemporary art, we will analyze what makes a home. Re-Imagining the Historic House Museum: A Workplace for Women. 

Step into “Home at Spadina Museum” and explore how homes are shaped by the people who live and work in them. From the Austin family to contemporary art, discover untold stories of women’s labour, care, and community. Reimagine the historic house as both a home and a workplace.

As you explore the exhibition, we invite you to reflect: "What does home mean to you?"

We are grateful to our community partners, Augusto Bitter and the Women’s Art Association of Canada.
event_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Home at Spadina Museum
short_description: Discover how homes shape identity through the Austin family story and contemporary art at Spadina Museum. Reimagine hist
short_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Home at Spadina Museum

event_description:
A spoken word poetry program for youth in the Jane and Finch community. Youth will learn the fundamentals of spoken word with Jayda Marley and Naiesha Marques and have the opportunity to present what they have learned at a final showcase for family and friends. 

A City of Toronto Cultural Hotspot Signature Project.
event_name: Pass the Mic: Shaping Radical Futures
short_description: A spoken word poetry program for youth in the Jane and Finch community. Youth will learn the fundamentals of spoken word
short_name: Pass the Mic: Shaping Radical Futures

event_description:
Scotland’s very own has long been ranked among our finest singers and songwriters. 

Armed with a powerful yet intensely emotive voice and passionate social conscience which is often expressed through his songs, it’s a combination that has brought frequent comparisons to the great Dick Gaughan. 

Cutting his teeth as the front person for The Paul McKenna Band, Paul travelled the world sharing his songs and stories for over a decade, playing many of the biggest venues and releasing five albums. Having honed his craft, he is now touring on his own.

Performance highlights over recent years include the Edmonton Folk Festival, Winnipeg Folk Festival, Milwaukee Irish Fest, Woodford Folk Festival, and regular appearances atCeltic Connections.
short_description:

event_description:
To kick off our 28th season, we are proud to present BEATS-BREATH, an exciting collaborative concert with shinobue master Jiro Murayama. Together, Nagata Shachu and Murayama will perform new compositions and traditional Japanese folk festival pieces featuring soaring melodies and spirited drumming.

This performance will include highlights such as a duet with Jiro Miuyrama on shinobue and Nagata Shachu member Kevin He on the shakuhachi, and a folk song performed by Nagata Shachu member Aki Takahashi on shamisen and vocals, Jiro Murayama on shinobue, and Kiyoshi Nagata on taiko.
event_name: BEATS-BREATH: Nagata Shachu and Jiro Murayama
short_description: To kick off our 28th season, we are proud to present BEATS-BREATH, an exciting collaborative concert with shinobue maste
short_name: BEATS-BREATH: Nagata Shachu and Jiro Murayama

event_description:
Enjoy a safe and empowering space for racialized youth, ages 16–29 in Scarborough to connect, create, and thrive.
 
Through music, dance, visual arts, storytelling, and games, you’ll discover new ways to build resilience and self-identity, cope with stress, find positive outlets for self-expression and connect with peers who understand your journey.

event_description: Join the Ontario Society of Artists in honoring its Life Members, acknowledging their significant contributions to both the Society and the wider art community. These distinguished members actively teach, exhibit their work, sustain their artistic practices and generously volunteer their time. Representing diverse disciplines, including painting, sculpture, printmaking and photography, the Life Members embody the creative spirit and dedication that enrich the arts.

event_description:
Calling Toronto Beatles fans!
 
Join us for our return for the third year in a row! 

Travel through time - From early Ed Sullivan to Let it Be, you’ll get all the hits. Experience this live Beatles performance through all eras of their career, performed on stage by The Liverpool 4 with the same high energy, impeccable musicianship, showmanship, fun and humour.

The show performance is two acts with a 20-minute intermission. It must be experienced to be believed. Come together and sing and dance along, clap your hands, stomp your feet, or just rattle your jewelry!

event_description: Kensington Flea is back for the 2025 season, bringing the vibrant spirit of local entrepreneurship to the heart of Kensington Market every weekend. The market features an exciting lineup of independent artisans, small businesses, vintage curators & emerging designers — all coming together to celebrate the best of Toronto’s creative culture.

event_description:
Sharks have intrigued humans for as long as we have explored the oceans. The terrifying monster from the movie Jaws is what many might imagine when they think of these animals, but they are far more fascinating and complex than their depiction in popular culture.

This exhibition invites you to uncover fresh perspectives, groundbreaking research, and the astounding diversity of this ancient group of fishes.

Visitors will delve into the anatomy, behaviour, and history of sharks, from familiar favourites like tiger sharks and great whites to lesser-known species like the dwarf lanternshark—a tiny, light-producing marvel small enough to hold in your hand.

event_description:
Making Home in Scarborough is a vibrant pop-up installation celebrating memory, identity, and belonging through cultural traditions and objects we hold dear to our hearts in generations past, present and future. 
 

Co-created through conversation and care, community members were invited to share a meaningful object, rooted in a heartfelt story. All speak to how home is made not only in buildings or borders, but in the places, people, and practices that give life meaning. 
 
As you explore the exhibition, we invite you to reflect: "What does home mean to you?" If you live in Scarborough, "What does Making Home in Scarborough Mean to you?" 
 
We are grateful for our community collaborators: Native Child and Family Services / Scarborough Child & Family Life Centre, Malvern Family Resource Centre, TDSB Newcomer Services (Malvern), Toby's Place, Scarborough Museum Youth Collective and Change Made.
event_name: Pop-Up Exhibit: Making Home in Scarborough at Scarborough Museum

event_description:
In the chaos of urban life, we often forget to take a moment to breathe. Take in a moment of stillness, as we inviting visitors to stand beneath something that feels alive.

The outdoor installation, made from a suspended grid of copper leaves, reimagines the shelter of a forest canopy with each leaf individually cut and hung to form a floating canopy above. By day, the leaves catch the light and scatter soft shadows across the ground. By night, lighting transforms the installation, casting intricate patterns on surrounding surfaces and shifting the atmosphere of the space entirely. As wind moves through the piece, the leaves gently sway and rustle, adding a subtle layer of sound to the experience.

Responding to its surroundings and shifting with the light, weather and movement of people passing beneath it, this work offers a dynamic and reflective space in the heart of the city. 

Designed by RAW Works, with Roland Rom Colthoff, Suleman Khan, Elmira Yousefi and Aaron Hendershot.
short_description: In the chaos of urban life, we often forget to take a moment to breathe. Take in a moment of stillness, as we inviting v

event_description:
Enjoy a safe and empowering space for racialized youth, ages 16–29 in Scarborough to connect, create, and thrive.
 
Through music, dance, visual arts, storytelling, and games, you’ll discover new ways to build resilience and self-identity, cope with stress, find positive outlets for self-expression and connect with peers who understand your journey.
short_description:
Enjoy a safe and empowering space for racialized youth, ages 16–29 in Scarborough to connect, create, and thrive.
 
Thro

event_description:
A celebration of the city’s passion for basketball and the remarkable stories of legendary players who changed the game. Join us and experience basketball history come to life through augmented reality, where you can custom design your own basketball jersey.

Even before the Toronto Raptors and the rallying cry, “We the North” became a slogan, for over a century, basketball in Toronto was deeply rooted in the evolving social and cultural conditions of our city and its people.  

From the Canadian invention of basketball to the early women’s game in 1895, to the first professional basketball game played by the short-lived Toronto Huskies in 1946, and the recent creation of the Toronto Tempo WNBA team, these and many other milestones chart the sport’s development in the city.
short_description: A celebration of the city’s passion for basketball and the remarkable stories of legendary players who changed the game.

event_description:
Gryphon Trio is back in collaboration with the Hilario Durán Trio to celebrate the spirit of Cuba, where irresistible rhythms, fiery passion and the visceral connections between classical and jazz come to life.

“Hilario Durán is an unparalleled pianist, as well as being a composer and arranger of the first order… one of the greatest Cuban pianists of the 20th century.” - Chucho Valdés.

short_name: Gryphon Trio and Hilario Durán Trio

event_description:
The Southern Netherlands — better known today as Flanders — was home to revolutionary artists. These extraordinary painters found new ways to depict reality, portray humanity, and tell stories that created parallels to their world then - and to our world today. 

This large-scale exhibition, featuring over 80 stunning art works and objects — medieval, Renaissance, and baroque paintings, sculptures and more — offers a doorway into the Southern Netherlands of 1400 to 1700. The exhibition's unique presentation introduces the visitor, through these rare, extraordinary artworks, to stories of enterprising townspeople, prosperous cities, and an ever-developing society.
event_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Masterworks
short_description: The Southern Netherlands — better known today as Flanders — was home to revolutionary artists. These extraor
short_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Mast

event_description: Join us in exploring the tension between aging, identity, and a society obsessed with youth and technology. Inspired by Dylan Thomas’ poem "Do not go gentle into that good night", this gallery exhibition challenges the notion that growing older means fading away. Instead, it celebrates the wisdom, defiance, and power that come with time.

event_description: Join us as we explore the supernatural side of Toronto’s historic and haunted pioneer village Featuring some of the oldest buildings in the city it is the perfect creepy backdrop for a night of spine-tingling ghost stories. Many of which have occurred to previous village guests and Haunted Walk tour guides. It is easily one of the most active sites we tour and is a must-do for paranormal enthusiasts. Not recommended for children or easily frightened adults.
event_name: Ghosts of the Village at Black Creek

event_description:
The Southern Netherlands — better known today as Flanders — was home to revolutionary artists. These extraordinary painters found new ways to depict reality, portray humanity, and tell stories that created parallels to their world then - and to our world today. 

This large-scale exhibition, featuring over 80 stunning art works and objects — medieval, Renaissance, and baroque paintings, sculptures and more — offers a doorway into the Southern Netherlands of 1400 to 1700. The exhibition's unique presentation introduces the visitor, through these rare, extraordinary artworks, to stories of enterprising townspeople, prosperous cities, and an ever-developing society.
event_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Masterworks
short_description: The Southern Netherlands — better known today as Flanders — was home to revolutionary artists. These extraor
short_name: Saints, Sinners, Lovers and Fools: 300 Years of Flemish Mast

event_description:
Celebrate the holiday season with Juno Award-winning artist Loreena McKennitt and her enchanting Under A Winter’s Moon concert, a live performance of carols and tales blends Celtic, Indigenous, and Welsh cultures.

The show also includes Gemini Award-winning actor Cedric Smith narrating the magical A Child’s Christmas in Wales and begins with Ojibway artist Christin Dennis, also known as Gzhiiquot/Fast Moving Cloud, presenting the story of Skywoman. Prepare to be transported to a world of music and spoken word that connects with our past and awakens the spirit of the season.

Loreena McKennitt’s eclectic Celtic blend of pop, folk, and world music has sold over 14 million albums worldwide. Her recordings have achieved Gold, Platinum, and multi-Platinum status in 15 countries on four continents. In 2004, McKennitt was awarded the Order of Canada and in 2013 was appointed Knight of the National Order of Arts and Letters of the Republic of France.
event_name: Loreena McKennitt: Under A Winter’s Moon I
short_description: Celebrate the holiday season with Juno Award-winning artist Loreena McKennitt and her enchanting Under A Winter’s Moon c
short_name: Loreena McKennitt: Under A Winter’s Moon I

event_description:
Korean pianist Seong-Jin Cho was brought to the world’s attention in 2015 when he won the First Prize at the Chopin International Competition in Warsaw. This “Chopin Competition winner can stand proud next to the likes of such illustrious past winners as Pollini, Argerich, and Zimerman,” said the Pianist.  

Enjoy a program of Franz Liszt: “Les jeux d’eaux à la Villa d’Este” from Années de pèlerinage, S. 163, Ludwig van Beethoven: Piano Sonata No. 15 in D Major, op. 28 (“Pastoral”), Béla Bartók: Out of Doors, Sz. 81, BB 89, Fryderyk Chopin: 14 Waltzes

Please join us! This concert is preceded by a short performance by talented students of The Royal Conservatory.
short_description: Korean pianist Seong-Jin Cho was brought to the world’s attention in 2015 when he won the First Prize at the Chopin Inte

event_description:
Beginning July 1st at Scarborough Museum, experience Washed Up by Hatecopy. The project captures the essence of liminal spaces that serve as cultural hubs for the South Asian immigrant communities, using the washing machine as a vessel to carry textiles that signify our roots and drawing visitors into an environment that intertwines the past, present, and future; acknowledging the dirty laundry of Canadian History and “Truth,” and reclaiming both seen and unseen spaces.

Maria Qamar (b. 1991) is a Toronto-based pop artist whose work is focused in the South Asian diaspora and immigrant communities and their cultural experiences. The work specializes in themes regarding feminism, social change, humour, pop culture, politics and romance. The artist has been recognized both nationally and internationally with exhibits and features in the Museum of Contemporary Arts, the National Arts Centre, Sotheby’s, Phillips Auction, and the AGO.
event_name: Washed Up: Pop-Up Installation at Scarborough Museum
short_description: Beginning July 1st at Scarborough Museum, experience Washed Up by Hatecopy. The project captures the essence of liminal
short_name: Washed Up: Pop-Up Installation at Scarborough Museum

event_description:
These celebrated musicians are frequent collaborators, captivating audiences at world-class venues like Wigmore Hall, Carnegie Hall, and the Berlin Philharmonie. 

Beyond performance, Isserlis is a passionate teacher, author, and broadcaster. As Sir John Barbirolli said, “Steven Isserlis is a musician of immense talent and insight, whose sound and interpretation leave a deep and lasting impression.”

Their thoughtfully curated program highlights Isserlis’s broad musical interests, featuring the Ritournelle by Czech composer Vítězslava Kaprálová alongside beloved cello-piano repertoire gems. The program also includes Beethoven’s 12 Variations on a Theme from The Magic Flute, Op. 66 and Sonata No. 3 in A major, Op. 69, Schumann’s 3 Fantasiestücke, Op. 73, and Kabalevsky’s Sonata. Experience an exceptional evening of profound musicianship and emotional depth from this outstanding duo.
event_name: Steven Isserlis, cello and Connie Shih, piano
short_description: These celebrated musicians are frequent collaborators, captivating audiences at world-class venues like Wigmore Hall, Ca
short_name: Steven Isserlis, cello and Connie Shih, piano

event_description:
Making its North American premiere, the globally celebrated masterpiece reveals the true story of Ip Man, the prestigious grandmaster of the martial art Wing Chun. The story recounts his influence on the martial art from its more than 300-year-old origins in Southern China, to global popularity, and his famous student Bruce Lee.

It features two gripping, inter-woven tales about the relentless pursuit of dreams while incorporating a pulse-pounding blend of acrobatic dance, precision martial arts and cinematic staging with dramatic lighting and breathtaking visuals. 

For audience members ages eight and up.
short_description: Making its North American premiere, the globally celebrated masterpiece reveals the true story of Ip Man, the prestigiou

event_description:
The phenomenal Canadian pianist Louis Lortie returns with a captivating program featuring the piano ballade. 

Popularized in the 19th century, the piano ballade is a single-movement work that often incorporates a dramatic narrative arc. The form is remarkably flexible, so while the genre remains consistent, the emotional depth and variety of the compositions, as well as Lortie’s performance, will make for fascinating and a deeply satisfying evening.

Louis Lortie has earned an extraordinary international reputation as both a recitalist and a soloist with orchestras worldwide. Enjoy his program of Gabriel Fauré: Ballade in F-sharp major, Op. 19, Claude Debussy: Ballade, Johannes Brahms: Ballades, Op. 10 (Complete) and Franz Liszt: Ballade.
short_description:
The phenomenal Canadian pianist Louis Lortie returns with a captivating program featuring the piano ballade. 

Populariz

We are excited to welcome Italian guest conductor Giovanni Pompeo, and welcome back one of the orchestra's favourite piano soloists, Anya Alexeyev, to present a program of maximum Romantic melody. 

Anya stars as the soloist in an orchestral version of César Franck's luxurious Piano Quintet, and Maestro Pompeo will lead the orchestra in one of the most beloved Romantic works in the entire repertoire, Tchaikovsky's famous Serenade.

Start your day with some morning yoga to gently wake up your body, breath, and senses. Each class will explore some meditation, pranayama (breathwork), and other grounding techniques for the nervous system, as well as move through some movement and stretches to gently energise the body.

Suitable for all levels including beginners. Seated, standing and lying down poses will be included with different options and students are encouraged to find and choose what works best for them.

Please bring your own mat.

Hosted by award-winning science communicator Anthony Morgan, enjoy a film that explores the ongoing rise and fall of lives on Earth, from the cataclysmic events that reshape our ecosystems to the creatures that survived (or did not) along the way, with live music accompaniment by artists from The Royal Conservatory. 

Arrive early and explore artifacts from the Royal Ontario Museum
short_description: Hosted by award-winning science communicator Anthony Morgan, enjoy a film that explores the ongoing rise and fall of liv

event_description:
Toronto’s alt-country and folk-rock legends make their long-awaited return.

Formed in Toronto in 1985 by Margo Timmins (vocalist), Michael Timmins (songwriter, guitarist), Peter Timmins (drummer), and Alan Anton (bassist). The Junkies first performed publicly at the Beverley Tavern and other clubs in Toronto’s Queen Street West, including The Rivoli. 

Their 1986 debut album, produced by Canadian Peter Moore, was the blues-inspired "Whites Off Earth Now!!", recorded using an ambisonic microphone in the family garage.

The group’s fame spread with their second album, "The Trinity Session", recorded in 1987 at Toronto’s Church of the Holy Trinity. Their sound, again using the ambisonic microphone, and their mix of blues, country, folk, rock, and jazz earned them both critical attention and a cult following.

After the concert, enjoy a beverage and more music.
short_description:
Toronto’s alt-country and folk-rock legends make their long-awaited return.

Formed in Toronto in 1985 by Margo Timmins

event_description:
This is a contemporary form of environmental art created by artists who are  concerned about reducing waste, recycling, and making the world a better place, while raising awareness about environmental changes.

 It aims to showcases the beauty and creativity of using recycled, environmentally friendly or sustainable materials to create phenomenal artwork, using water-based paints, natural pigments and recycled materials to name a few elements. lt is art that advocates for the planet, catering to all ages and present in various mediums, including paintings, sculptures or fashion.

Presenting our second annual art exhibition, we will be utilizing selected artists to mentor African and Caribbean communities on the positioning of multicultural history and art within the Canadian cultural landscape.

Presenting our second annual art exhibition, we will be utilizing selected artists to mentor African and Caribbean communities on the positioning of multicultural history and art within the Canadian cultural landscape.

event_description: Explore the majestic gothic architecture and picturesque tree-lined paths of the campus as we uncover its eerie history and spine-chilling ghostly tales. As we stroll through the historic grounds, our expert guides will captivate you with chilling stories of ghostly sightings and supernatural phenomena witnessed by students, faculty, and visitors alike. Whether you’re a history buff, a believer in the paranormal, a student or alum, or just looking for a unique and spooky evening experience in Toronto, our Campus Secrets & Spectres ghost tour will leave you with a sense of wonder and intrigue as we reveal the haunted secrets of the University of Toronto’s downtown campus.
event_name: Campus Secrets and Spectres – University of Toronto Ghost Tour

event_description:
Join us in celebrating joy, light, and culture at Toronto’s largest Diwali celebration!

Also known as Deepavali, the Festival of Lights symbolizes the victory of light over darkness, good over evil, and knowledge over ignorance.

Bring your family, friends, and neighbors to experience stunning light displays, delicious global cuisine, live music and cultural performances, musical Ramayana, a showcase and a fun kid's zone.

event_description:
Join us at Huntsmill Park to plant native trees and shrubs! We'll be creating valuable wildlife habitat, increasing local biodiversity and contributing to our urban tree canopy cover.

Event site conditions vary. Contact us for more information including accessibility. If you would like to request accessibility support or accommodation, contact us as soon as possible.
short_description: Join us at Huntsmill Park to plant native trees and shrubs! We'll be creating valuable wildlife habitat, increasing loca

event_description:
Through the use of sculpture, photography, video, and installation, this exhibition is a blend of different people and perspectives forming a kind of visual and sonic cacophony. It’s a nod to global (or even galactic) unity, and to the idea that despite all the noise and division, we’re more alike than not. 

In her Canadian debut, Intergalactic Planetary brings together imagery and works inspired by cities including Shanghai, Chongqing, Berlin, Tokyo, Bangkok and locations across the United States. Snelling explains, “Through this work, I ask: how can we move beyond our fears, borders, and egos to become more humane? Perhaps by staying curious, open, and willing to see each other more fully, we can take a small step toward connection, and even a glimmer of peace for the future”.

Join us on Nuit Blanche to view the exhibition's works, while DJ beats set the mood with dynamic sounds and enjoy two exhibition-inspired cocktails-one coffee-based and the other with an intergalactic twist.
short_description: Through the use of sculpture, photography, video, and installation, this exhibition is a blend of different people and p

Enjoy chef-inspired food pairings, bite size snacks and delicacies while sipping the teas. Learn the art of making a chai latte with spices like cinnamon, cardamom, ginger, clove and pepper. Create 3 seasonal special lattes and make yourself a holiday tea cocktail.

Connect with a community of tea lovers over flavor, culture and wellness.

This classically trained Italian Canadian duo will delight audiences with a curated selection of beloved songs from popular films. Experience Beatrice’s captivating voice paired with Adolfo’s expressive piano as they bring cinematic melodies to life in an unforgettable evening of music.

event_description:
Step into the glow, we're back for the sixth year! 

This year, guests can explore the magic like never before with a brand-new layout that lets you move freely between the immersive light show and Pumpkinville at your own pace. Wander through the illuminated maze of over 1.5 million LED and RGB lights, then pop into a vibrant fall fair featuring all new glowing photo ops, installations, midway rides, carnival games, and over 15,000 pumpkins. With new scenes, dazzling photo moments, and an entirely transformed setup, this is not just a walk, it's an adventure!

event_description:
Grammy Award-winning, Uzbekistan-born classical pianist, Yefim Bronfman, is internationally recognized as one of today's most acclaimed and admired pianists for his commanding technique, power, and exceptional lyrical gifts.

Enjoy a delightful program of Robert Schumann: Arabeske in C Major, op. 18, Johannes Brahms:  Piano Sonata No. 3 in F Minor, op. 5, Claude Debussy: Images, Book 2, L. 111, Sergei Prokofiev: Piano Sonata No. 7

The Philadephia Inquirer notes “It is safe to say there is no pianist around remotely like Yefim Bronfman.” and the Chicago Tribune has described Bronfman's performance as "a marvel of digital dexterity, warmly romantic sentiment, and jaw-dropping bravura." 

Please join us! This concert is preceded by a short performance by talented students of The Royal Conservatory.

event_description:
Curated by Mikinaak Migwans, Earthwork redefines a term that until now has referred to a type of artistic practice associated within the larger conceptual framework of land art. 

In this exhibition, Migwans shifts our understanding of earthwork to refer to a way of working, rather than the making of singular objects, reclaiming the art historical framing from an Indigenous perspective. It considers multiple layers of engagement with the land, including a history of land defense movements, medicine walks, and ancestral practices of prescribed burns, alongside contemporary art.

Featured artists include Michael Belmore, BUSH Gallery (Gabrielle L’Hirondelle Hill, Peter Morin, Tania Willard), Faye HeavyShield, Art Hunter, Alex Jacobs-Blum, Mike MacDonald, Lisa Myers, Edward Poitras, and Protect the Tract Collective.
event_name: Art Museum at the University of Toronto: Earthwork

event_description:
The celebrated Grammy Award-winning vocal ensemble returns with a program of a cappella choral music, ranging from Renaissance masterworks to roof-raising spirituals.

Chanticleer has been hailed as “the world’s reigning male chorus” by The New Yorker and is known around the world as "an orchestra of voices” for its wide-ranging repertoire and dazzling virtuosity. 

Founded in San Francisco in 1978 by singer and musicologist Louis Botto, Chanticleer quickly took its place as one of the most prolific recording and touring ensembles in the world, selling over one million recordings and performing thousands of live concerts to audiences around the world.

Please join us! This concert is preceded by a short performance by talented students of The Royal Conservatory.

event_description:
Borders divide, the cosmos unites.

Canadian legend Robert Lepage returns to Canadian Stage after sold-out productions of 887 and Needles and Opium.

Set against the Cold War's fierce U.S.-Soviet rivalry, this gripping story explores the personal and political turmoil of an era defined by global tension with a uniquely Canadian perspective. Through the tale of two Quebec City brothers, Lepage's stunning use of multimedia and visual storytelling draws the audience into a world on the brink of change and portrays the impact of global conflict on the individual.
event_name: The Far Side of the Moon
